their
performance
received
coldly
,
they
are
apt
to
believe
that

of

will

.
<EOS>
In

's
habits

had

taken

that
she
knew

.
<EOS>
This

received

,

,
but

.
  
<EOS>
In

same
room

DEAREST
CHILD
.
 
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
If

,

cloud
 
<EOS>
I

impossible

<EOS>
If

<EOS>
But
come
as
soon
    
as
you
can
to
your
afflicted
and

,
      
FANNY
DAVILOW
.
  
<EOS>
The
first
effect
of
this
letter
on
Gwendolen
was
half
-
stupefying
.
<EOS>
The
implicit
confidence
that
her
destiny
must
be
one
of
luxurious
ease
,
where
any
trouble
that
occurred
would
be
well
clad
and
provided
for
,
had
been
stronger
in
her
own
mind
than
in
her
mamma
's
,
being
fed
there
by
her
youthful
blood
and
that
sense
of
superior
claims
which
made
a
large
part
of
her
consciousness
.
<EOS>
It
was
almost
as
difficult
for
her
to
believe
suddenly
that
her
position
had
become
one
of
poverty
and
of
humiliating
dependence
,
as
it
would
have
been
to
get
into
the
strong
current
of
her
blooming
life
the
chill
sense
that
her
death
would
really
come
.
<EOS>
She
stood
motionless
for
a
few
minutes
,
then
tossed
off
her
hat
and
automatically
looked
in
the
glass
.
<EOS>
The
coils
of
her
smooth
light
-
brown
hair
were
still
in
order
perfect
enough
for
a
ball
-
room
;
and
as
on
other
nights
,
Gwendolen
might
have
looked
lingeringly
at
herself
for
pleasure
(
surely
an
allowable
indulgence
)
;
but
now
she
took
no
conscious
note
of
her
reflected
beauty
,
and
simply
stared
right
before
her
as
if
she
had
been
jarred
by
a
hateful
sound
and
was
waiting
for
any
sign
of
its
cause
.
<EOS>
By
-
and
-
by
she
threw
herself
in
the
corner
of
the
red
velvet
sofa
,
took
up
the
letter
again
and
read
it
twice
deliberately
,
letting
it
at
last
fall
on
the
ground
,
while
she
rested
her
clasped
hands
on
her
lap
and
sat
perfectly
still
,
shedding
no
tears
.
<EOS>
Her
impulse
was
to
survey
and
resist
the
situation
rather
than
to
wail
over
it
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
inward
exclamation
of
"
Poor
mamma
!
"
<EOS>
Her
mamma
had
never
seemed
to
get
much
enjoyment
out
of
life
,
and
if
Gwendolen
had
been
at
this
moment

feel

she
would
have
bestowed
it
on
herself
 
for
<EOS>
was
she
not
naturally
and
rightfully
the
chief
object
of
her
mamma
's
anxiety
too
?
<EOS>
But
it
was
anger
,
it
was
resistance
that
possessed
her
;
it
was
bitter
vexation
that
she
had
lost
her
gains
at
roulette
,
whereas
if
her
luck
had
continued
through
this
one
day
she
would
have
had
a
handsome
sum
to
carry
home
,
or
she
might
have
gone
on
playing
and
won
enough
to
support
them
all
.
<EOS>
Even
now
was
it
not
possible
?
<EOS>
She
had
only
four
napoleons
left
in
her
purse
,
but
she
possessed
some
ornaments
which
she
could
sell
:
a
practice
so
common
in
stylish
society
at
German
baths
that
there
was
no

to
be
ashamed

it
;
and
even

had
not
received
her

's
letter
,
she
would
probably

decided
to
get

for
an
Etruscan

which
she
happened
not
to
have
been

;
nay
,
she
might
have
done
so
with
an
agreeable
sense
that
she
was

some
intensity

escaping

.
<EOS>
With
ten
louis
at
her
disposal
and
a
return
of
her
former
luck
,
which
seemed
probable
,
what
could

do

than
go

?
<EOS>
If

friends

home

got

money
,
as

,
still
the

would

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
imagination
dwelt
on
this
course
and
created
agreeable
consequences
,
but
not
with
unbroken
confidence
and
rising

.
<EOS>
She
had

,

:
her

was
still

,

,

thrust

.
<EOS>
For
she
was
resolved
not
to

Langens
that

,

;

.
<EOS>
The

that

least

was
to
raise
money
on
her
necklace
early

the
morning
,
tell

Langens
that
her
mother
desired

immediate

without

,

.
<EOS>
She
had
no

with
her
,
and
the
Langens
might

about

,
but
her

was

.
  
<EOS>
Instead

going
to
bed
she
made
as

as
she
could

to

,

,
though
all

visited
by

scenes
that
might
take
place
on
the
coming
day
 
now
by

,

.
<EOS>
But

,

and

beholding

.
<EOS>
This

on

,
and
to

.
<EOS>
It
had

when

,

.
<EOS>
What
was
the
use
of
going

?
<EOS>
Her
cold
bath
was
refreshment
enough
,
and
she
saw
that
a

about

only

the

.
<EOS>
Before

was

gray

even

,
for

meant
to

as

.
<EOS>
And

before

she

,

.
<EOS>
It

because
one
's

little

egoistic

;
but

.
<EOS>
She

_

_

in

,

any

<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
How
could

believe

?
<EOS>
If

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Anything

,

.
  
<EOS>
Madame
von
Langen
never

,
so

needed

,

.
<EOS>

;

_
<EOS>
Czarina

<EOS>
This

:

<EOS>
This

_
<EOS>
Czarina
_

;

,

.

<EOS>
They

:
but

;

was

.
<EOS>
Who

?
<EOS>
Roulette
encourages

to

game
,

most

as

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's

that

<EOS>

'

,

thirteen

;

the

,

.

But

<EOS>
Gwendolen

<EOS>
She

<EOS>
Something

<EOS>

"
_

<EOS>
_
<EOS>
"
  
Gwendolen
reddened

.
<EOS>
A

<EOS>
It

;

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
Not

,

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen

.
<EOS>
No

One

.
<EOS>
Now

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Such

account

at

<EOS>
There

,

,
against

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
She
could

well

,
and
was

nothing
.
  
<EOS>
In

that
Gwendolen

,

,

.
        
<EOS>
"

;

with
    
rosebuds

.
"
 
<EOS>
BOOK
OF
WISDOM
.
   
<EOS>
Pity
that
Offendene
was
not
the
home
of
Miss
Harleth
's
childhood
,
or
endeared
to
her
by
family

!
<EOS>
A
human
life
,
I
think
,
should
be
well
rooted
in
some
spot
of
a
native

,

it
may
get

love
of

for
the

,
for
the

men

,

that

,

will

early

a

unmistakable
difference
amid
the
future
widening
of
knowledge
:
a
spot
where
the
definiteness
of
early
memories
may
be
inwrought
with
affection
,
and
 
kindly
acquaintance
with
all
neighbors
,
even
to
the
dogs
and
donkeys
,
may
spread
not
by
sentimental
effort
and
reflection
,
but
as
a
sweet
habit
of
the
blood
.
<EOS>
At
five
years
old
,
mortals
are
not
prepared
to
be
citizens
of
the
world
,
to
be
stimulated
by
abstract
nouns
,
to
soar
above
preference
into
impartiality
;
and
that
prejudice
in
favor
of
milk
with
which
we
blindly
begin
,
is
a
type
of
the
way
body
and
soul
must
get
nourished
at
least
for
a
time
.
<EOS>
The
best
introduction
to
astronomy
is
to
think
of
the
nightly
heavens
as
a
little
lot
of
stars
belonging
to
one
's
own
homestead
.
  
<EOS>
But
this
blessed
persistence
in
which
affection
can
take
root
had
been
wanting
in
Gwendolen
's
life
.
<EOS>
It
was
only
a
year
before
her
recall
from
Leubronn
that
Offendene
had
been
chosen
as
her
mamma
's
home
,
simply
for
its
nearness
to
Pennicote
Rectory
,
and
that
Mrs.
Davilow
,
Gwendolen
,
and
her
four
half
-
sisters
(
the
governess
and
the
maid
following
in
another
vehicle
)
had
been
driven
along
the
avenue
for
the
first
time
,
on
a
late
October
afternoon
when
the
rooks
were
crawing
loudly
above
them
,
and
the
yellow
elm
-
leaves
were
whirling
.
  
<EOS>
The
season
suited
the
aspect
of
the
old
oblong
red
-
brick
house
,
rather
too
anxiously
ornamented
with
stone
at
every
line
,
not
excepting
the
double
row
of
narrow
windows
and
the
large
square
portico
.
<EOS>
The
stone
encouraged
a
greenish
lichen
,
the
brick
a
powdery
gray
,
so
that
though
the
building
was
rigidly
rectangular
there
was
no
harshness
in
the
physiognomy
which
it
turned
to
the
three
avenues
cut
east
,
west
and
south
in
the
hundred
yards
'
breadth
of
old
plantation
encircling
the
immediate
grounds
.
<EOS>
One
would
have
liked
the
house
to
have
been
lifted
on
a
knoll
,
so
as
to
look
beyond
its
own
little
domain
to
the
long
thatched
roofs
of
the
distant
villages
,
the
church
towers
,
the
scattered
homesteads
,
the
gradual
rise
of
surging
woods
,
and
the
green
breadths
of
undulating
park
which
made
the
beautiful
face
of
the
earth
in
that
part
of
Wessex
.
<EOS>
But
though
standing
thus
behind
,
a
screen
amid
flat
pastures
,
it
had
on
one
side
a
glimpse
of
the
wider
world
in
the
lofty
curves
of
the
chalk
downs
,
grand
steadfast
forms
played
over
by
the
changing
days
.
  
<EOS>
The
house
was
but
just
large
enough
to
be
called
a
mansion
,
and
was
moderately
rented
,
having
no
manor
attached
to
it
,
and
being
rather
difficult
to
let
with
its
sombre
furniture
and
faded
upholstery
.
<EOS>
But
inside
and
outside
it
was
what
no
beholder
could
suppose
to
be
inhabited
by
retired
trades
-
people
:
a
certainty
which
was
worth
many
conveniences
to
tenants
who
not
only
had
the
taste
that
shrinks
from
new
finery
,
but
also
were
in
that
border
-
territory
of
rank
where
annexation
is
a
burning
topic
:
and
to
take
up
her
abode
in
a
house
which
had
once
sufficed
for
dowager
countesses
gave
a
perceptible
tinge
to
Mrs.
Davilow
's
satisfaction
in
having
an
establishment
of
her
own
.
<EOS>
This
,
rather
mysteriously
to
Gwendolen
,
appeared
suddenly
possible
on
the
death
of
her
step
-
father
,
Captain
Davilow
,
who
had
for
the
last
nine
years
joined
his
family
only
in
a
brief
and
fitful
manner
,
enough
to
reconcile
them
to
his
long
absences
;
but
she
cared
much
more
for
the
fact
than
for
the
explanation
.
<EOS>
All
her
prospects
had
become
more
agreeable
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
She
had
disliked
their
former
way
of
life
,
roving
from
one
foreign
watering
-
place
or
Parisian
apartment
to
another
,
always
feeling
new
antipathies
to
new
suites
of
hired
furniture
,
and
meeting
new
people
under
conditions
which
made
her
appear
of
little
importance
;
and
the
variation
of
having
passed
two
years
at
a
showy
school
,
where
,
on
all
occasions
of
display
,
she
had
been
put
foremost
,
had
only
deepened
her
sense
that
so
exceptional
a
person
as
herself
could
hardly
remain
in
ordinary
circumstances
or
in
a
social
position
less
than
advantageous
.
<EOS>
Any
fear
of
this
latter
evil
was
banished
now
that
her
mamma
was
to
have
an
establishment
;
for
on
the
point
of
birth
Gwendolen
was
quite
easy
.
<EOS>
She
had
no
notion
how
her
maternal
grandfather
got
the
fortune
inherited
by
his
two
daughters
;
but
he
had
been
a
West
Indian
 
which
seemed
to
exclude
further
question
;
and
she
knew
that
her
father
's
family
was
so
high
as
to
take
no
notice
of
her
mamma
,
who
nevertheless
preserved
with
much
pride
the
miniature
of
a
Lady
Molly
in
that
connection
.
<EOS>
She
would
probably
have
known
much
more
about
her
father
but
for
a
little
incident
which
happened
when
she
was
twelve
years
old
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
had
brought
out
,
as
she
did
only
at
wide
intervals
,
various
memorials
of
her
first
husband
,
and
while
showing
his
miniature
to
Gwendolen
recalled
with
a
fervor
which
seemed
to
count
on
a
peculiar
filial
sympathy
,
the
fact
that
dear
papa
had
died
when
his
little
daughter
was
in
long
clothes
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
immediately
thinking
of
the
unlovable
step
-
father
whom
she
had
been
acquainted
with
the
greater
part
of
her
life
while
her
frocks
were
short
,
said
    
"
Why
did
you
marry
again
,
mamma
?
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
nicer
if
you
had
not
.
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
colored
deeply
,
a
slight
convulsive
movement
passed
over
her
face
,
and
straightway
shutting
up
the
memorials
she
said
,
with
a
violence
quite
unusual
in
her
    
"
You
have
no
feeling
,
child
!
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
who
was
fond
of
her
mamma
,
felt
hurt
and
ashamed
,
and
had
never
since
dared
to
ask
a
question
about
her
father
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
not
the
only
instance
in
which
she
had
brought
on
herself
the
pain
of
some
filial
compunction
.
<EOS>
It
was
always
arranged
,
when
possible
,
that
she
should
have
a
small
bed
in
her
mamma
's
room
;
for
Mrs.
Davilow
's
motherly
tenderness
clung
chiefly
to
her
eldest
girl
,
who
had
been
born
in
her
happier
time
.
<EOS>
One
night
under
an
attack
of
pain
she
found
that
the
specific
regularly
placed
by
her
bedside
had
been
forgotten
,
and
begged
Gwendolen
to
get
out
of
bed
and
reach
it
for
her
.
<EOS>
That
healthy
young
lady
,
snug
and
warm
as
a
rosy
infant
in
her
little
couch
,
objected
to
step
out
into
the
cold
,
and
lying
perfectly
still
,
grumbling
a
refusal
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
went
without
the
medicine
and
never
reproached
her
daughter
;
but
the
next
day
Gwendolen
was
keenly
conscious
of
what
must
be
in
her
mamma
's
mind
,
and
tried
to
make
amends
by
caresses
which
cost
her
no
effort
.
<EOS>
Having
always
been
the
pet
and
pride
of
the
household
,
waited
on
by
mother
,
sisters
,
governess
and
maids
,
as
if
she
had
been
a
princess
in
exile
,
she
naturally
found
it
difficult
to
think
her
own
pleasure
less
important
than
others
made
it
,
and
when
it
was
positively
thwarted
felt
an
astonished
resentment
apt
,
in
her
cruder
days
,
to
vent
itself
in
one
of
those
passionate
acts
which
look
like
a
contradiction
of
habitual
tendencies
.
<EOS>
Though
never
even
as
a
child
thoughtlessly
cruel
,
nay
delighting
to
rescue
drowning
insects
and
watch
their
recovery
,
there
was
a
disagreeable
silent
remembrance
of
her
having
strangled
her
sister
's
canary
-
bird
in
a
final
fit
of
exasperation
at
its
shrill
singing
which
had
again
and
again
jarringly
interrupted
her
own
.
<EOS>
She
had
taken
pains
to
buy
a
white
mouse
for
her
sister
in
retribution
,
and
though
inwardly
excusing
herself
on
the
ground
of
a
peculiar
sensitiveness
which
was
a
mark
of
her
general
superiority
,
the
thought
of
that
infelonious
murder
had
always
made
her
wince
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
nature
was
not
remorseless
,
but
she
liked
to
make
her
penances
easy
,
and
now
that
she
was
twenty
and
more
,
some
of
her
native
force
had
turned
into
a
self
-
control
by
which
she
guarded
herself
from
penitential
humiliation
.
<EOS>
There
was
more
show
of
fire
and
will
in
her
than
ever
,
but
there
was
more
calculation
underneath
it
.
  
<EOS>
On
this
day
of
arrival
at
Offendene
,
which
not
even
Mrs.
Davilow
had
seen
before
 
the
place
having
been
taken
for
her
by
her
brother
-
in
-
law
,
Mr.
Gascoigne
 
when
all
had
got
down
from
the
carriage
,
and
were
standing
under
the
porch
in
front
of
the
open
door
,
so
that
they
could
have
a
general
view
of
the
place
and
a
glimpse
of
the
stone
hall
and
staircase
hung
with
sombre
pictures
,
but
enlivened
by
a
bright
wood
fire
,
no
one
spoke
;
<EOS>
mamma
,
the
four
sisters
and
the
governess
all
looked
at
Gwendolen
,
as
if
their
feelings
depended
entirely
on
her
decision
.
<EOS>
Of
the
girls
,
from
Alice
in
her
sixteenth
year
to
Isabel
in
her
tenth
,
hardly
anything
could
be
said
on
a
first
view
,
but
that
they
were
girlish
,
and
that
their
black
dresses
were
getting
shabby
.
<EOS>
Miss
Merry
was
elderly
and
altogether
neutral
in
expression
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
's
worn
beauty
seemed
the
more
pathetic
for
the
look
of
entire
appeal
which
she
cast
at
Gwendolen
,
who
was
glancing
round
at
the
house
,
the
landscape
and
the
entrance
hall
with
an
air
of
rapid
judgment
.
<EOS>
Imagine
a
young
race
-
horse
in
the
paddock
among
untrimmed
ponies
and
patient
hacks
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
dear
,
what
do
you
think
of
the
place
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
at
last
,
in
a
gentle
,
deprecatory
tone
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
is
charming
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
quickly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
romantic
place
;
anything
delightful
may
happen
in
it
;
it
would
be
a
good
background
for
anything
.
<EOS>
No
one
need
be
ashamed
of
living
here
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
certainly
nothing
common
about
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
it
would
do
for
fallen
royalty
or
any
sort
of
grand
poverty
.
<EOS>
We
ought
properly
to
have
been
living
in
splendor
,
and
have
come
down
to
this
.
<EOS>
It
would
have
been
as
romantic
as
could
be
.
<EOS>
But
I
thought
my
uncle
and
aunt
Gascoigne
would
be
here
to
meet
us
,
and
my
cousin
Anna
,
"
added
Gwendolen
,
her
tone
changed
to
sharp
surprise
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
early
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
and
entering
the
hall
<EOS>
,
she
said
to
the
housekeeper
who
came
forward
,
"
You
expect
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Gascoigne
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
madam
;
they
were
here
yesterday
to
give
particular
orders
about
the
fires
and
the
dinner
.
<EOS>
But
as
to
fires
,
I
've
had
'em
in
all
the
rooms
for
the
last
week
,
and
everything
is
well
aired
.
<EOS>
I
could
wish
some
of
the
furniture
paid
better
for
all
the
cleaning
it
's
had
,
but
I
_
think
_
<EOS>
you
'll
see
the
brasses
have

done
justice
to
.
<EOS>
I
_
think
_
<EOS>
when
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Gascoigne
come
,
they
'll
tell
you
nothing
has
been
neglected
.
<EOS>
They
'll
be
here
at
five
,

certain
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
satisfied
Gwendolen
,
who
was
not
prepared
to
have

treated
with

;
and
after

a

matted

to

there
,

tripped
down
again
,
and
followed
by
all
the
girls
looked
into
each
of
the
rooms
opening
from
the
hall
 
<EOS>
the
dining
-
room
all
dark

and
worn
red

,
with
a
copy
of
snarling
,
worrying

from
Snyders
over

-

,
and
a
Christ
breaking
bread
over

mantel
-

;
the
library
with
a
general

and
smell
of
old

-

;
and
lastly
,
the
drawing
-

,
which
was
entered
through
a
small
antechamber
crowded
with
venerable

-

.
  
<EOS>
"
Mamma
,
mamma
,
pray
come
here
!
"
<EOS>
said
Gwendolen
,
Mrs.
Davilow
having
followed
slowly
in
talk
with
the
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
"
Here
is
an
organ
.
<EOS>
I
will
be
Saint
Cecilia
:
some
one
shall
paint
me
as
Saint
Cecilia
.
<EOS>
Jocosa
<EOS>
(
this
was
her
name
for
Miss
Merry
)
,
let
down
my
hair
.
<EOS>
See
,
mamma
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
thrown
off
her
hat
and
gloves
,
and
seated
herself
before
the
organ
in
an
admirable
pose
,
looking
upward
;
while
the
submissive
and
sad
Jocosa
took
out
the
one
comb
which
fastened
the
coil
of
hair
,
and
then
shook
out
the
mass
till
it
fell
in
a
smooth
light
-
brown
stream
far
below
its
owner
's
slim
waist
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
smiled
and
said
,
"
A
charming
picture
,
my
dear
!
"
<EOS>
not
indifferent
to
the
display
of
her
pet
,
even
in
the
presence
of
a
housekeeper
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
rose
and
laughed
with
delight
.
<EOS>
All
this
seemed
quite
to
the
purpose
on
entering
a
new
house
which
was
so
excellent
a
background
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
a
queer
,
quaint
,
picturesque
room
!
<EOS>
"
she
went
on
,
looking
about
her
.
"
I
like
these
old
embroidered
chairs
,
and
the
garlands
on

,

.
<EOS>
That

nothing

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
She

no

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Gascoigne

.
<EOS>
But

was
darker

,

her

.
<EOS>
Their

lay
in

-

,

to

;
but
this
,
owing
to

difference

,

to

.
<EOS>
The
younger

had
been

,

in
her

;
the
elder
believed
herself
the
most
enviable
of

,
and
her

had
ended
in

sometimes

.
<EOS>
Many

her

,
such

,

.
<EOS>
And
there
was
much
to

's

.
<EOS>
He
had
some

,
some

,
and
the

that
were
imputed

all
leaned

.
  
<EOS>
One
of
his
advantages
was
a
fine
person
,
which
perhaps
was

more
impressive
at
fifty
-
seven
than

had

in
life
.
<EOS>
There
were
no

clerical

in
the
face
,
no

or

affected

:
in

he
could
not

,
a

which
began

,
and
iron
-
gray
,
hair
.
<EOS>
Perhaps

owed
this
freedom
from
the
sort
of
professional
make
-
up
which
penetrates
skin
,
tones
and

and
defies
all

,
to
the
fact
that
he
had
once

Captain
Gaskin
,

but

.
<EOS>
If

was

,
his
friends
might

,

?
<EOS>
He
had
a
native

,
being

both
of
opinions
and

,
because
he
felt

able

overrule

,
and
was
free
from

.
<EOS>
He
smiled
pleasantly
at
the
foible
of
a

which
he
did
not
share
 
at
floriculture
or

for
example
,
which

much

-

:

,

,
or

of
Nesselrode
's

what

.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gascoigne
's
tone
of
thinking
after
some
long

had
become
ecclesiastical
rather
than

;
not
the
modern

,
but
what

called

,
free
from

;
such

became
a
man
who
looked

national
religion
by
daylight
,
and
saw

in
its

to
other
things
.
<EOS>
No

had
greater

,

less

in

to

.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
the
worst

thrown

against
him
<EOS>
was

<EOS>
:
it
could
not

proved
that
he
forsook
the
less
fortunate
,
but
it
was
not
to

that

he
cultivated
were

a

likely

father

sons

;
and

observers
 
for
in
Wessex
,
say
<EOS>
ten

ago
,
there

whose

may
now

remarked
that
the
color

his

had

in

.
<EOS>
But

,

has

than
the
acrid
,

,
whose
secret

is

,
"
Sold
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
wondered
that
she
had
not
better

how
very
fine

man
her
uncle
was
;
but

less

.
<EOS>
At

was

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

should
control
her
,
but
she

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
He

"

Anna
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>

:

"

"

room
,
and
busied
herself
with
arranging
pieces
of
music
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
dear
child
has
had
no

,
no

,
"

Mrs.
Davilow
,
in

.
<EOS>
"
I

in

.
<EOS>
But

she

.
<EOS>
And

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
But

,

,

.
"
<EOS>
(

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

_

<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
The

.

.
<EOS>

MOLIÈRE
.
<EOS>
_
Les
Précieuses
Ridicules
.
<EOS>
_
   
<EOS>
It
would
be
a
little
hard
to
blame
the
rector
of
Pennicote
that
in
the
course
of
looking
at
things
from
every
point
of
view
,
he
looked
at
Gwendolen
as
a
girl
likely
to
make
a
brilliant
marriage
.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
be
expected
to
differ
from
his
contemporaries
in
this
matter
,
and
wish
his
niece
a
worse
end
of
her
charming
maidenhood
than
they
would
approve
as
the
best
possible
?
<EOS>
It
is
rather
to
be
set
down
to
his
credit
that
his
feelings
on
the
subject
were
entirely
good
-
natured
.
<EOS>
And
in
considering
the
relation
of
means
to
ends
,
it
would
have
been
mere
folly
to
have
been
guided
by
the
exceptional
and
idyllic
 
to
have
recommended
that
Gwendolen
should
wear
a
gown
as
shabby
as
Griselda
's
in
order
that
a
marquis
might
fall
in
love
with
her
,
or
to
have
insisted
that
since
a
fair
maiden
was
to
be
sought
,
she
should
keep
herself
out
of
the
way
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Gascoigne
's
calculations
were
of
the
kind
called
rational
,
and
he
did
not
even
think
of
getting
a
too
frisky
horse
in
order
that
Gwendolen
might
be
threatened
with
an
accident
and
be
rescued
by
a
man
of
property
.
<EOS>
He
wished
his
niece
well
,
and
he
meant
her
to
be
seen
to
advantage
in
the
best
society
of
the
neighborhood
.
  
<EOS>
Her
uncle
's
intention
fell
in
perfectly
with
Gwendolen
's
own
wishes
.
<EOS>
But
let
no
one
suppose
that
she
also
contemplated
a
brilliant
marriage
as
the
direct
end
of
her
witching
the
world
with
her
grace
on
horseback
,
or
with
any
other
accomplishment
.
<EOS>
That
she
was
to
be
married
<EOS>
some
time
or
other
she
would
have
felt
obliged
to
admit
;
and
that
her
marriage
would
not
be
of
a
middling
kind
,
such
as
most
girls
were
contented
with
<EOS>
,
she
felt
quietly
,
unargumentatively
sure
.
<EOS>
But
her
thoughts
never
dwelt
on
marriage
as
the
fulfillment
of
her
ambition
;
the
dramas
in
which
she
imagined
herself
a
heroine
were
not
wrought
up
to
that
close
.
<EOS>
To
be
very
much
sued
or
hopelessly
sighed
for
as
a
bride
was
indeed
an
indispensable
and
agreeable
guarantee
of
womanly
power
;
but
to
become
a
wife
and
wear
all
the
domestic
fetters
of
that
condition
,
was
on
the
whole
a
vexatious
necessity
.
<EOS>
Her
observation
of
matrimony
had
inclined
her
to
think
it
rather
a
dreary
state
in
which
a
woman
could
not
do
what
she
liked
,
had
more
children
than
were
desirable
,
was
consequently
dull
,
and
became
irrevocably
immersed
in
humdrum
.
<EOS>
Of
course
marriage
was
social
promotion
;
she
could
not
look
forward
to
a
single
life
;
but
promotions
have
sometimes
to
be
taken
with
bitter
herbs
 
a
peerage
will
not
quite
do
instead
of
leadership
to
the
man
who
meant
to
lead
;
and
this
delicate
-
limbed
sylph
of
twenty
meant
to
lead
.
<EOS>
For
such
passions
dwell
in
feminine
breasts
also
.
<EOS>
In
Gwendolen
's
,
however
,
they
dwelt
among
strictly
feminine
furniture
,
and
had
no
disturbing
reference
to
the
advancement
of
learning
or
the
balance
of
the
constitution
;
her
knowledge
being
such
as
with
no
sort
of
standing
-
room
or
length
of
lever
could
have
been
expected
to
move
the
world
.
<EOS>
She
meant
to
do
what
was
pleasant
to
herself
in
a
striking
manner
;
or
rather
,
whatever
she
could
do
so
as
to
strike
others
with
admiration
and
get
in
that
reflected
way
a
more
ardent
sense
of
living
,
seemed
pleasant
to
her
fancy
.
  
<EOS>
"
Gwendolen
will
not
rest
without
having
the
world
at
her
feet
,
"
said
Miss
Merry
,
the
meek
governess
:
hyperbolical
words
which
have
long
come
to
carry
the
most
moderate
meanings
;
for
who
has
not
heard
of
private
persons
having
the
world
at
their
feet
in
the
shape
of
some
half
-
dozen
items
of
flattering
regard
generally
known
in
a
genteel
suburb
?
<EOS>
And
words
could
hardly
be
too
wide
or
vague
to
indicate
the
prospect
that
made
a
hazy
largeness
about
poor
Gwendolen
on
the
heights
of
her
young
self
-
exultation
.
<EOS>
Other
people
allowed
themselves
to
be
made
slaves
of
,
and
to
have
their
lives
blown
hither
and
thither
like
empty
ships
in
which
no
will
was
present
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
to
be
so
with
her
;
she
would
no
longer
be
sacrificed
to
creatures
worth
less
than
herself
,
but
would
make
the
very
best
of
the
chances
that
life
offered
her
,
and
conquer
circumstances
by
her
exceptional
cleverness
.
<EOS>
Certainly
,
to
be
settled
at
Offendene
,
with
the
notice
of
Lady
Brackenshaw
,
the
archery
club
,
and
invitations
to
dine
with
the
Arrowpoints
,
as
the
highest
lights
in
her
scenery
,
was
not
a
position
that
seemed
to
offer
remarkable
chances
;
but
Gwendolen
's
confidence
lay
chiefly
in
herself
.
<EOS>
She
felt
well
equipped
for
the
mastery
of
life
.
<EOS>
With
regard
to
much
in
her
lot
hitherto
,
she
held
herself
rather
hardly
dealt
with
,
but
as
to
her
"
education
,
"
she
would
have
admitted
that
it
had
left
her
under
no
disadvantages
.
<EOS>
In
the
school
-
room
her
quick
mind
had
taken
readily
that
strong
starch
of
unexplained
rules
and
disconnected
facts
which
saves
ignorance
from
any
painful
sense
of
limpness
;
and
what
remained
of
all
things
knowable
,
she
was
conscious
of
being
sufficiently
acquainted
with
through
novels
,
plays
and
poems
.
<EOS>
About
her
French
and
music
,
the
two
justifying
accomplishments
of
a
young
lady
,
she
felt
no
ground
for
uneasiness
;
and
when
to
all
these
qualifications
,
negative
and
positive
,
we
add
the
spontaneous
sense
of
capability
some
happy
persons
are
born
with
,
so
that
any
subject
they
turn
their
attention
to
impresses
them
with
their
own
power
of
forming
a
correct
judgment
on
it
,
who
can
wonder
if
Gwendolen
felt
ready
to
manage
her
own
destiny
?
  
<EOS>
There
were
many
subjects
in
the
world
 
<EOS>
perhaps
the
majority
 
in
which
she
felt
no
interest
,
because
they
were
stupid
;
for
subjects
are
apt
to
appear
stupid
to
the
young
as
light
seems
dull
to
the
old
;
but
she
would
not
have
felt
at
all
helpless
in
relation
to
them
if
they
had
turned
up
in
conversation
.
<EOS>
It
must
be
remembered
that
no
one
had
disputed
her
power
or
her
general
superiority
.
<EOS>
As
on
the
arrival
at
Offendene
,
so
always
,
the
first
thought
of
those
about
her
had
been
,
what
will
Gwendolen
think
?
 
<EOS>
if
the
footman
trod
heavily
in
creaking
boots
,
or
if
the
laundress
's
work
was
unsatisfactory
,
the
maid
said
,
"
This
will
never
do
for
Miss
Harleth
"
;
if
the
wood
smoked
in
the
bedroom
fireplace
,
Mrs.
Davilow
,
whose
own
weak
eyes
suffered
much
from
this
inconvenience
,
spoke
apologetically
of
it
to
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
If
,
when
they
were
under
the
stress
of
traveling
,
she
did
not
appear
at
the
breakfast
table
till
every
one
else
had
finished
,
the
only
question
was
,
how
Gwendolen
's
coffee
and
toast
should
still
be
of
the
hottest
and
crispest
;
and
when
she
appeared
with
her
freshly
-
brushed
light
-
brown
hair
streaming
backward
and
awaiting
her
mamma
's
hand
to
coil
it
up
,
her
large
brown
eyes
glancing
bright
as
a
wave
-
washed
onyx
from
under
their
long
lashes
,
it
was
always
she
herself
who
had
to
be
tolerant
 
to
beg
that
Alice
who
sat

on
her
would
not
stick
up

shoulders
in
that

,
and
that
Isabel
,
instead
of
pushing
up
to
her
and

,
would
go
away
to
Miss
Merry
.
  
<EOS>
Always
she
was
the
princess
in
exile
,
who
in
time
of
famine
was
to
have
her
breakfast
-
roll
made
of
the
finest
-
bolted
flour
from
the
seven
thin
ears
of
wheat
,
and
in
a
general
decampment
was
to
have
her
silver
fork
kept
out
of
the
baggage
.
<EOS>
How
was
this
to
be
accounted
for
?
<EOS>
The
answer
may
seem
to
lie
quite
on
the
surface
:
 
in
her
beauty
,
a
certain
unusualness
about
her
,
a
decision
of
will
which
made
itself
felt
in
her
graceful
movements
and
clear
unhesitating
tones
,
so
that
if
she
came
into
the
room
on
a
rainy
day
when
everybody
else
was
flaccid
and
the
use
of
things
in
general
was
not
apparent
to
them
,
there
seemed
to
be
a
sudden
,
sufficient
reason
for
keeping
up
the
forms
of
life
;
and
even
the
waiters
at
hotels
showed
the
more
alacrity
in
doing
away
with
crumbs
and
creases
and
dregs
with
struggling
flies
in
them
.
<EOS>
This
potent
charm
,
added
to
the
fact
that
she
was
the
eldest
daughter
,
toward
whom
her
mamma
had
always
been
in
an
apologetic
state
of
mind
for
the
evils
brought
on
her
by
a
step
-
father
,
may
seem
so
full
a
reason
for
Gwendolen
's
domestic
empire
,
that
to
look
for
any
other
would
be
to
ask
the
reason
of
daylight
when
the
sun
is
shining
.
<EOS>
But
beware
of
arriving
at
conclusions
without
comparison
.
<EOS>
I
remember
having
seen
the
same
assiduous
,
apologetic
attention
awarded
to
persons
who
were
not
at
all
beautiful
or
unusual
,
whose
firmness
showed
itself
in
no
very
graceful
or
euphonious
way
,
and
who
were
not
eldest
daughters
with
a
tender
,
timid
mother
,
compunctious
at
having
subjected
them
to
inconveniences
.
<EOS>
Some
of
them
were
a
very
common
sort
of
men
.
<EOS>
And
the
only
point
of
resemblance
among
them
all
was
a
strong
determination
to
have
what
was
pleasant
,
with
a
total
fearlessness
in
making
themselves
disagreeable
or
dangerous
when
they
did
not
get
it
.
<EOS>
Who
is
so
much
cajoled
and
served
with
trembling
by
the
weak
females
of
a
household
as
the
unscrupulous
male
 
capable
,
if
he
has
not
free
way
at
home
,
of
going
and
doing
worse
elsewhere
?
<EOS>
Hence
I
am
forced
to
doubt
whether
even
without
her
potent
charm
and
peculiar
filial
position
<EOS>
Gwendolen
might
not
still
have
played
the
queen
in
exile
,
if
only
she
had
kept
her
inborn
energy
of
egoistic
desire
,
and
her
power
of
inspiring
fear
as
to
what
she
might
say
or
do
.
<EOS>
However
,
she
had
the
charm
,
and
those
who
feared
her
were
also
fond
of
her
;
the
fear
and
the
fondness
being
perhaps
both
heightened
by
what
may
be
called
the
iridescence
of
her
character
 
the
play
of
various
,
nay
,

.
<EOS>
For
Macbeth
's

about
the

being

,
referred
to
the

of

.
<EOS>
We
can
not

loyal

and
be
meanly

;
we
can
not
kill
and
not

same

;
but
a

is
wide
enough
for
the
loyal
and
mean

,
for
the
outlash
of
a
murderous

and
the
sharp

.
                                  
<EOS>
"
Her
wit
  
<EOS>
Values
itself
so
highly
,
that
to
her
  
All
matter
else
seems
weak
.
"
             
<EOS>
_
Much
Ado
About
Nothing
.
<EOS>
_
   
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
reception
in
the
neighborhood
fulfilled
her
uncle
's
expectations
.
<EOS>
From
Brackenshaw

to
the
Firs
at

,
where
Mr.
Quallon
the

kept

,

with
manifest

,
and
even
those

did

,
felt
a
comfort
in
having
a
new
,
striking
girl
to

;
for

who
entertain
much
must
make

their

as

make

,
on
grounds
other
than

.
<EOS>
Then
,

as

,

,
for
Mrs.
Davilow
always

as

,
and
Mr.
Gascoigne
was
everywhere
in

for

.
  
<EOS>
Among

where

was
not

,

,

.
<EOS>
One

,

;
for

<EOS>
No

's

<EOS>

,

:
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
Several

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
A

;

_

,

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,

in

,
but

,

by

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,

<EOS>

and
learned
by
heart
at
school
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
his
life
is
more
interesting
than
his
poetry
,
I
have
constructed
the
early
part
of
his
life
as
a
sort
of
romance
.
<EOS>
When
one
thinks
of
his
father
Bernardo
,
and
so
on
,
there
is
much
that
must
be
true
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Imagination
is
often
truer
than
fact
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
decisively
,
though
she
could
no
more

than
if

had
been
Coptic
or

.
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be
so

to
learn
all
about
Tasso
 
and
his
madness
especially
.
<EOS>
I
suppose
poets
are
always
a
little

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
 
"
the
poet
's
eye
in
a
fine
frenzy
rolling
"
;
and
somebody
says
of
Marlowe
      
<EOS>
"
For
that
fine
madness
still
he
did
maintain
,
  
Which
always
should
possess
the
poet
's
brain
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
But
it
was
not
always
found
out
,

?
"
said
Gwendolen
innocently
.
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
some
of
them
rolled
their
eyes
in
private
.
<EOS>
Mad
people
are
often
very
cunning
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again

shade
flitted
over
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
's
face
;
but
the
entrance
of
the
gentlemen
prevented
any

between
her
and
this
too
quick
young
lady
,
who
had
over
-
acted
her
_

_
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
here
comes
Herr
Klesmer
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
rising
;
and
presently
bringing
him
to
Gwendolen
,
she
left
them
to
a
dialogue
which
was
agreeable
on
both
sides
,
Herr
Klesmer
being
a
felicitous
combination
of
the
German
,
the
Sclave
and
the
Semite
,
with
grand
features
,
brown
hair
floating
in
artistic
fashion
,
and
brown
eyes
in
spectacles
.
<EOS>
His
English
had
little
foreignness
except
its
fluency
;
and
his
alarming
cleverness
was
made
less
formidable
just
then
by
a
certain
softening
air
of
silliness
which
will
sometimes
befall
even
genius
in
the
desire
of
being
agreeable
to
beauty
.
  
<EOS>
Music
was
soon
begun
.
<EOS>
Miss
Arrowpoint
and
Herr
Klesmer
played
a
four
-
handed
piece
on
two
pianos
,
which
convinced
the
company
in
general
that
it
was
long
,
and
Gwendolen
in
particular
that
the
neutral
,
placid
-
faced
Miss
Arrowpoint
had
a
mastery
of
the
instrument
which
put
her
own
execution
out
of
question
 
though
she
was
not
discouraged
as
to
her
often
-
praised
touch
and
style
.
<EOS>
After
this
every
one
became
anxious
to
hear
Gwendolen
sing
;
especially
Mr.
Arrowpoint
;
as
was
natural
in
a
host
and
a
perfect
gentleman
,
of
whom
no
one
had
anything
to
say
but
that
he
married
Miss
Cuttler
and
imported
the
best
cigars
;
and
he
led
her
to
the

with

.
<EOS>
Herr
Klesmer
closed
the
instrument
in
readiness
for
her
,
and
smiled
with
pleasure
at
her
approach
;
then
placed
himself
at
a
distance
of
a
few
feet
so
that
he
could
see
her
as

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
not
nervous
;
what
she
undertook
to
do
she
did
without
trembling
,
and
singing
was
an
enjoyment
to
her
.
<EOS>
Her
voice
was
a
moderately
powerful
soprano
<EOS>
(
some
one
had
told
her
it
was
like
Jenny
Lind
's
)
,
her
ear
good
,
and
she
was
able
to
keep
in
tune
,
so
that
her
singing
gave
pleasure
to
ordinary
hearers
,
and
she
had
been
used
to
unmingled
applause
.
<EOS>
She
had
the
rare
advantage
of
looking
almost
prettier
when
she
was
singing
than
at
other
times
,
and
that
Herr
Klesmer
was
in
front

her
seemed
not
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
Her
song
,
determined
on
beforehand
,
was
a
favorite
aria
of
Belini
's
,
in
which
she
felt
quite
sure
of
herself
.
  
<EOS>
"
Charming
?
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
who
had
remained
near
,
and
the
word
was
echoed
around
without
more
insincerity
than
we
recognize
in
a
brotherly
way
as
human
.
<EOS>
But
Herr
Klesmer
stood
like
a
statue
 
if
a
statue
can
be
imagined
in
spectacles
;
at
least
,
he
was
as
mute
as
a
statue
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
pressed
to
keep
her
seat
and
double
the
general
pleasure
,
and
she
did
not
wish

;
but
before

,
she
moved
a
little
toward
Herr

,

with

,
"
It
would
be
too
cruel
to
a

.
<EOS>
You
can
not
like

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

;
but

,
"

Klesmer
,
suddenly
speaking
in
an

German

with

,
quite

in

before
,
and

,
as

.
<EOS>
"
That
makes
nothing
.
<EOS>
It
is
always
acceptable
to

.
"
  
<EOS>
Was
there
ever
so
unexpected
an
assertion
of
superiority
?
<EOS>
at
least
before
the
late
Teutonic

?
<EOS>
Gwendolen
colored
deeply
,
but
,
with
her
usual

mind
,

not

by

;
and
Miss
Arrowpoint
,
who
had
been
near
enough
to

(
and

to

that

's

was
more

than

quite

good

)
,

came

"
Imagine
what

go

!
<EOS>
He

anything

English

.
<EOS>
We

put
up

his

,
and

to

.
<EOS>
It

to

;
and
one
can

when
every

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
be

to

for

the

,
"
said
Gwendolen
,

.
<EOS>
"
I
dare

I
have

ill

,
in

to
having
no
talent
 
only
liking
for

.
<EOS>
"
This
was
very
well
expressed
considering
that

had
never
entered
her
mind
before
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
it
is
true
:
<EOS>
you
have
not

well

,
"
said
Herr
Klesmer
,
quietly
.
<EOS>
Woman
was
dear
to
him
,
but
music
was
dearer
.
"
<EOS>
Still
,
you
are
not
quite
without
gifts
.
<EOS>
You
sing
in

,
and
you
have

.
<EOS>
But
you
produce
your
notes
badly
;
and
that
music
which
you
sing
is
beneath
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
form
of
melody
which
expresses
a
puerile
state
of
culture
 
a
dawdling
,
canting
,
see
-
saw
kind
of
stuff
 
the
passion
and
thought
of
people
without
any
breadth

horizon
.
<EOS>
There

a
sort

self

about
every

of
such

;
no
cries

deep
,

<EOS>
no
conflict
 
<EOS>
no
sense
of
the
universal
.
<EOS>
It
makes

small
as

listen
to

.
<EOS>
Sing
now
something
larger
.
<EOS>
And
I
shall
see
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
not
now
 
by
-
and
-
by
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
with
a

of
heart
at
the
sudden
width
of
horizon
opened
round
her
small
musical
performance
.
<EOS>
For
a
lady
desiring
to
lead
,
this
first

in
her

was

.
<EOS>
But
she
was
bent
on
not

,
and
Miss
Arrowpoint
helped

by
saying
    
"
<EOS>
Yes
,
by
-
and
-
by
.
<EOS>
I
always
require

hour
to
get

after

Herr
Klesmer
.
<EOS>
We
will
ask
him
to
play
to
us
now
:
he
is
bound
to
show
us
what
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
To
be
quite
safe
on
this
point
Herr
Klesmer
played
a
composition
of
his
own
,
a
fantasia
called
_
Freudvoll
,
Leidvoll
,
Gedankenvoll
<EOS>
_
 
<EOS>
an
extensive
commentary
on
some

ideas
not
too
grossly
evident
;
and
he
certainly
fetched
as
much

and
depth
of
passion
out
of

piano
as
that
moderately
responsive
instrument
lends
itself
to
,
having
an
imperious
magic
in
his

that
seem
to
send
a
nerve
-
thrill
through
ivory
key
and

,
and
compel
the
strings
to
make
a
quivering

for

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
in
spite
of
her
wounded
egoism
,
had
fullness
of
nature
enough
to
feel
the
power
of
this
playing
,
and
it
gradually
turned
her
inward

of
mortification
into
an
excitement
which
lifted
her
for
the

into
a
desperate

about
her
own

,
or
at
least
a
determination
to
get
a
superiority
over
them
by
laughing
at
them
as
if
they
belonged
to
somebody
else
.
<EOS>
Her
eyes
had
become
brighter
,
her
cheeks
slightly
flushed
,
and
her
tongue
ready
for
any
mischievous
remarks
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
you
would
sing
to

again
,
Miss
Harleth
,
"
said
young
Clintock
,
the

's

,
who
had

so

as

take

,

's

,
"
That
is
the
style
of
music
for

.
<EOS>
I
never
can

anything
of
this
tip
-
top

.
<EOS>
It
is
like
a
jar

,
where

can
never
tell
either

or

.
<EOS>
I

all

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
should
be

something
popular
now
 
<EOS>
another

from

would

,
"
said

Arrowpoint
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

how
bad

,

.
<EOS>
They

,
"

,

Arrowpoint
,

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
was
not

to
this

,
but
merely

,
"
Well
,
we
will
not

,
"
and

imprisoned

just

,
and

seeking

,
she

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
young

,
well
-

.
  
<EOS>
"
Exceedingly
.
<EOS>
There
seems

be
a
little
of
everything
and

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
rather

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not
with

.
<EOS>
I
like
a

everything
;
a

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

;

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Mrs.

,

's

,

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

"

;
"
I

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
One

,

;

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

;

.
<EOS>
I

's

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
I

.
<EOS>
Or
,

?
<EOS>
Because

<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
But
Gwendolen
,
nevertheless
,
continued
to
receive

from
the
family
at
Quetcham
,
not

because

have

than

,

Miss

,
who
managed

and

,
her

occupied
.
        
<EOS>
"
Croyez
-
vous
m'avoir
humiliée
pour
m'avoir
appris
que
la
terre
tourne
    
autour
du

?
<EOS>
Je
vous
jure
que
je
ne
m'en
estime
pas
moins
.
<EOS>
"
                                  
<EOS>
FONTENELLE
:
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Pluralité
des
Mondes
_
.
   
<EOS>
That
lofty
criticism
had
caused
Gwendolen
a
new
sort
of
pain
.
<EOS>
She
would
not
have
chosen
to
confess
how
unfortunate
she
thought
herself
in
not
having
had
Miss
Arrowpoint
's
musical
advantages
,
so
as
to
be
able
to
question
Herr
Klesmer
's
taste
with
the
confidence
of
thorough
knowledge
;
still
less
,
to
admit
even
to
herself
that
Miss
Arrowpoint
each
time
they
met
raised
an
unwonted
feeling
of
jealousy
in
her
:
not
in
the
least
because
she
was
an
heiress
,
but
because
it
was
really
provoking
that
a
girl
whose
appearance
you
could
not
characterize
except
by
saying
that
her
figure
was
slight
and
of
middle
stature
,
her
features
small
,
her
eyes
tolerable
,
and
her
complexion
sallow
,
had
nevertheless
a
certain
mental
superiority
which
could
not
be
explained
away
 
an
exasperating
thoroughness
in
her
musical
accomplishment
,
a
fastidious
discrimination
in
her
general
tastes
,
which
made
it
impossible
to
force
her
admiration
and
kept
you
in
awe
of
her
standard
.
<EOS>
This
insignificant
-
looking
young
lady
of
four
-
and
-
twenty
,
whom
any
one
's
eyes
would
have
passed
over
negligently
if
she
had
not
been
Miss
Arrowpoint
,
might
be
suspected
of
a
secret
opinion
that
Miss
Harleth
's
acquirements
were
rather
of
a
common
order
,
and
such
an
opinion
was
not
made
agreeable
to
think
of
by
being
always
veiled
under
a
perfect
kindness
of
manner
.
  
<EOS>
But
Gwendolen
did
not
like
to
dwell
on
facts
which
threw
an
unfavorable
light
on
itself
.
<EOS>
The
musical
Magus
who
had
so
suddenly
widened
her
horizon
was
not
always
on
the
scene
;
and
his
being
constantly
backward
and
forward
between
London
and
Quetcham
soon
began
to
be
thought
of
as
offering
opportunities
for
converting
him
to
a
more
admiring
state
of
mind
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
in
the
manifest
pleasure
her
singing
gave
at
Brackenshaw
Castle
,
the
Firs
,
and
elsewhere
,
she
recovered
her
equanimity
,
being
disposed
to
think
approval
more
trustworthy
than
objection
,
and
not
being
one
of
the
exceptional
persons
who
have
a
parching
thirst
for
a
perfection
undemanded
by
their
neighbors
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
would
have
been
rash
to
say
then
that
she
was
at
all
exceptional
inwardly
,
or
that
the
unusual
in
her
was
more
than
her
rare
grace
of
movement
and
bearing
,
and
a
certain
daring
which
gave
piquancy
to
a
very
common
egoistic
ambition
,
such
as
exists
under
many

and
is
taken
no
notice
of
.
<EOS>
For
I
suppose
that
the
set
of

head
does
not
really
determine
the
hunger
of
the
inner
self
for
supremacy
<EOS>
:
it
only
makes
a
difference
sometimes
as
to

supremacy
is
held
attainable
,
and
a

also

the
degree

can

;
especially
when
the
hungry

is
a
girl
,
whose

for
doing

has
an
ideal
limit
in
consistency
with
the
highest
breeding
and
perfect
freedom
from
the
sordid

income
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
as
inwardly
rebellious
against
the
restraints
of
family
conditions
,
and
as
ready
to
look
through

into
her
own
fundamental
want
of

for

,
as
if

had
been
sustained

the

;
but
she
really
had
no
such

,
and
would

marked

off
from
any
sort
of
theoretical

reforming
women
by

.
<EOS>
She
rejoiced
to
feel
herself
exceptional
;
but
her
horizon
was
that
of
the
genteel

where
the

's

poured
out
in
her
journal
is
full
of
vague

,

,
and

,
while
her

moves
strictly
in
the
sphere
of
fashion
;
and
if

,
the
pathos
lies
partly
,
so
to
speak
,
in
her
having
on

.
<EOS>
Here
is
a
restraint
which
nature
and
society
have
provided
on
the
pursuit
of
striking
adventure
;
so
that
a

burning
with

what
the

is
not
,

ready

all
existence
as

,
is
nevertheless

ordinary

forms

.
  
<EOS>
This

result
was
what
Gwendolen
found

with
even
in
the

of
the
first

.
<EOS>
What

.
<EOS>
Offendene
remained

,

;
but

.
  
<EOS>
Beyond

_

where
there
was
more
freedom
,
or
rather
where
there
was
a
more
complete
sway
for
Gwendolen
;
and
whatever
she
wished
became
a
ruling
purpose
for
Rex
.
<EOS>
The
charades
came
off
according
to
her
plans
;
and
also
some
other
little
scenes
not
contemplated
by
her
in
which
her
acting
was
more

.
<EOS>
It
was
at
Offendene
that
the
charades
and
_
tableaux
<EOS>
_
were
rehearsed
and
presented
,
Mrs.
Davilow
seeing
no
objection
even
to
Mr.
Middleton
's
being
invited
to
share
in
them
,
now
that
Rex
too
was
there
 
especially
as
his
services
were
indispensable
:
Warham
,
who
was
studying
for
India
with
a
Wanchester
"
coach
,
"
having
no
time
to
spare
,
and
being
generally
dismal
under
a
cram
of
everything
except
the
answers
needed
at
the
forthcoming
examination
,
which
might
disclose
the
welfare
of
our
Indian
Empire
to
be
somehow
connected
with
a
quotable
knowledge
of
Browne
's
Pastorals
.
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Middleton
was
persuaded
to
play
various
grave
parts
,
Gwendolen
having
flattered
him
on
his
enviable
immobility
of
countenance
;
and
at
first
a
little
pained
and
jealous
at
her
comradeship
with
Rex
,
he
presently
drew
encouragement
from
the
thought
that
this
sort
of
cousinly
familiarity
excluded
any
serious
passion
.
<EOS>
Indeed
,
he
occasionally
felt
that
her
more
formal
treatment
of
himself
was
such
a
sign
of
favor
as
to
warrant
his
making
advances
before

left
Pennicote
,
though
he
had
intended
to
keep
his

in

until

should
be
more

.
<EOS>
Miss
Gwendolen
,
quite
aware
that
she
was
adored
by
this
unexceptionable
young
clergyman
with
pale
whiskers
and
square
-
cut
collar
<EOS>
,
felt
nothing
more
on
the
subject
than
that
she
had
no
objection
to
being
adored
:
she
turned
her

on
him
with
calm
mercilessness
and
caused
him
many
mildly
agitating
hopes
by
seeming
always
to
avoid
dramatic
contact
with
him
 
for
all
meanings
,
we
know
,
depend
on
the
key
of
interpretation
.
  
<EOS>
Some
persons
might
have
thought
beforehand
that
a
young
man
of
Anglican
leanings
,
having
a
sense
of
sacredness
much
exercised
on
small
things
as
well
as
great
,
rarely
laughing
save
from
politeness
,
and
in
general
regarding
the

of
spades
by
their
naked

as
rather

,
would
not
have
seen
a
fitting

for
himself
in
a
girl
who
was

in

,
and
showed
none
of
the
special
grace
required
in
the

's

;
or
,
that
a
young
man
informed

reading
would
have
reflected
that
he
was
not
likely
to
meet
the

of
a
lively
,

young

like
Miss
Harleth
.
<EOS>
But
are
we
always

to
explain
why
the
facts
are
not
what
some

thought
beforehand
?
<EOS>
The
apology
lies
on
their
side
,
who
had
that
erroneous
way
of
thinking
.
  
<EOS>
As
for
Rex
,
who
would
possibly
have
been
sorry
for
poor
Middleton
if

been
aware

the
excellent
curate
's
inward
conflict
,
he
was
too
completely
absorbed
in
a
first

to
have

any

.
<EOS>
He
did
not
observe
Gwendolen
;
he
only
felt
what
she
said

did
,
and
the
back

seemed
to
be
a

of

.
<EOS>
Before

that
it

except

's
.
<EOS>
He
could
see
no
obstacles
,
poor
boy
;
his
own

seemed
a
guarantee
of
hers
,
since
it

one
with
the

in
her
image
,
so
that
he
could
no
more

than
an

could

.
<EOS>
She
sang
and
played
to
him
whenever

liked
,
was
always
glad
of
his
companionship
in

,
though
his
borrowed

were
often

,
was
ready
to
join
in
any
fun
of
his
,
and
showed
a
right
appreciation
of
Anna
.
<EOS>
No
mark
of
sympathy
seemed
absent
.
<EOS>
That
because
Gwendolen
was
the
most
perfect
creature
in
the
world
she
was
to
make
a
grand
match
,
had
not

.
<EOS>
He
had
no
conceit
 
at
least
not
more
than
goes
to
make

the
necessary

and
consistence
of

:

he

's

which
had
seemed
one
with
life
to

,
being

of

,

.
  
<EOS>
One

which

impressed

as

her

.
<EOS>
It

an

of
her

which
could
not

who
,

,

only

.
  
<EOS>
After

it

resolved
that

to
Offendene
to

which
went

.
<EOS>
Anna
had
caused
a

surprise
;
nothing
could

played

;

.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Middleton
answered

.
<EOS>
The

had

's

to

Greek

.
<EOS>
No

for

would

either

that

of

.
<EOS>
To

,

could
not

French
verse
,

improvised

would

into

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
Mr.
Gascoigne
prohibited

from
plays
:
he
usually

against
the

;

a

.
  
<EOS>
Everybody

of
Gwendolen
's
,

.
<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
"
Something
pleasant
,

,

,
"

;
"
I
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

Hermione

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
And

was

;
all

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
Klesmer
came
.
<EOS>
He
was
in
one
of
his
placid
,
silent

,
and
sat
in
serene

,
replying

all

in

-

more
or
less

as
taking
up
his
cross
meekly
in
a
world
overgrown
with

,
or
as
careful
how
he
moved
his
lion

and

.
  
<EOS>
Everything
indeed
went
off
smoothly
and
according
to
expectation
 
all
that
was
improvised
and

being
of
a
probable

until

which
showed

in

.
<EOS>
How

came
about
was
at
first
a

.
  
<EOS>
The
tableau
of
Hermione
was
doubly
striking
from
its

with
what
had
gone
before
:
it
was

perfectly
,

had

that

should

and

.
  
<EOS>
Hermione
,
her

on

,
was

by
about

,
which

of

pretty
foot
and

,
when

.
  
<EOS>
"
Music
,
awake
her
,
strike
!
"
<EOS>
said
Paulina
(
Mrs.
Davilow
,
who
,

,
had
consented
to
take

part
in
a
white
burnous
and
hood
)
.
  
<EOS>
Herr

,

had
been
good
-
natured

,

but

,

,

,

,

,

.

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

Fear
had

:

;

,
usually

,

.
<EOS>
Her

,

,
rushed

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

of

mother
's

;

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

aim

,
for

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
A

_

_

!
"

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
A

!
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

!

<EOS>

by

Vulcany
unbecoming
in
a

,
and

<EOS>

"

CHARLES
LAMB
.
   
<EOS>
The
first

of
the
unimagined
snow

.
<EOS>
Anna
was
in
the
secret
of
Rex
's
feeling
;
though

the

,
and
he
only

.
<EOS>
For

first

,
too
,
Anna
could
not
say
to
Rex
what
was
continually
in
her
mind
.
<EOS>
Perhaps

might
have

a
pain

that

,

.
<EOS>
Anna
admired
her
cousin
 
<EOS>
would
have

"

,
"

;

,

.
<EOS>

's

,
that
Gwendolen

never

.
<EOS>
What

,

.
<EOS>
Besides
,

was

something

.
<EOS>
And

!
Papa
would

.
<EOS>
And

was

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
But

that
be

!
<EOS>
Anna
,
in

,

her
too

.
  
<EOS>

Oh

,
I
can
not
bear
it
.
<EOS>
You
will
make

very

.
"
<EOS>
Here

.
  
<EOS>
"
Nannie

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
She
will
not

for

one
bit
 
<EOS>
I

never

!
<EOS>
"

the

.
<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

and

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
the

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

stage

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

"

.

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>
(

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
Still

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Several

.
<EOS>
Rex

.
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>
only

,

;
<EOS>
her

,

:
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

,

on

There

"

!

"

would
be
to
me
,
because
you
would
not
be
there
.
"
<EOS>
Silence
.
  
<EOS>
"
Should
you
mind
about
me
going
away
,
Gwendolen
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Of
course
.
<EOS>
Every
one
is
of
consequence
in
this
dreary
country
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
curtly
.
<EOS>
The
perception
that
poor
Rex
wanted
to
be
tender
made
her
curl
up
and
harden
like
a
sea
-
anemone
at
the
touch
of
a
finger
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
angry
with
me
,
Gwendolen
?
<EOS>
Why
do
you
treat
me
in
this
way
all
at
once
?
"
said
Rex
,
flushing
,
and
with
more
spirit
in
his
voice
,
as
if
he
too
were
capable
of
being
angry
.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
looked
round
at
him
and
smiled
.
<EOS>
"
Treat
you
?
<EOS>
Nonsense
!
<EOS>
I
am
only
rather
cross
.
<EOS>
Why
did
you
come
so
very
early
?
<EOS>
You
must
expect
to
find
tempers
in
dishabille
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Be
as
cross
with
me
as
you
like
 
only
do
n't
treat
me
with
indifference
,
"
said
Rex
,
imploringly
.
<EOS>
"
All
the
happiness
of
my
life
depends
on
your
loving
me
 
if
only
a
little
 
better
than
any
one
else
.
"
  
<EOS>
He
tried
to
take
her
hand
,
but
she
hastily
eluded

and
moved
to
the
other
end
of
the
hearth
,
facing
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
do
n't
make
love
to
me
!
<EOS>
I
hate
it
!
"
<EOS>
she
looked
at
him
fiercely
.
  
<EOS>
Rex
turned
pale
and
was
silent
,
but
could
not
take
his
eyes
off
her
,
and
the
impetus
was
not
yet
exhausted
that
made
hers
dart
death
at
him
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
herself
could
not
have
foreseen
that
she
should
feel
in
this
way
.
<EOS>
It
was
all
a
sudden
,
new
experience
to
her
.
<EOS>
The
day
before
she
had
been
quite
aware
that
her
cousin
was
in
love
with
her
;
she
did
not
mind
how
much
,
so
that
he
said
nothing
about
it
;
and
if
any
one
had
asked
her
why
she
objected
to
love
-
making
speeches
,
she
would
have
said
,
laughingly
,
"
<EOS>
Oh
I
am
tired
of
them
all
in
the
books
.
<EOS>
"
But
now
the
life
of
passion
had
begun
negatively
in
her
.
<EOS>
She
felt
passionately
averse
to
this
volunteered
love
.
  
<EOS>
To
Rex
at
twenty
the
joy
of
life
seemed
at
an
end
more
absolutely
than
it
can
do
to
a
man
at
forty
.
<EOS>
But
before
they
had
ceased
to
look
at

other
,
he
did
speak
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
that
last
word
you
have
to
say
to
me
,
Gwendolen
?
<EOS>
Will
it
always
be
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
could
not
help
seeing
his
wretchedness
and
feeling
a
little
regret
for
the
old
Rex
who
had
not
offended
her
.
<EOS>
Decisively
,
<EOS>
but
yet
with
some
return
of
kindness
,
she
said
    
"
About
making
love
?
<EOS>
Yes
.
<EOS>
But
I
do
n't
dislike
you
for
anything
else
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
just
a
perceptible
pause
before
he
said
a
low
"
good
-
bye
.
"
and
passed
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
Almost
immediately
after
,
she
heard
the
heavy
hall
door
bang
behind
him
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
,
too
,
had
heard
Rex
's
hasty
departure
,
and
presently
came
into
the
drawing
-
room
,
where
she
found
Gwendolen
seated
on
the
low

,
her
face
buried
,
and
her
hair
falling
over
her
figure
like
a

.
<EOS>
She
was
sobbing
bitterly
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
My
child
,
my
child
,
what
is
it
?
<EOS>
"
cried
the
mother
,
who
had
never
before
seen
her
darling
struck
down
in
this
way
,
and
felt
something
of
the
alarmed
anguish
that
women
,
feel
at
the

of
overpowering

in
a

;
for
this
child
had
been
her
ruler
.
<EOS>
Sitting
down
by
her
with

,
she
pressed
her

against
Gwendolen
's
head
,
and
then
tried
to
draw
it
upward
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
gave
way
,
and
letting
her

rest
against
her
mother
,
cried

,
"
Oh
,
mamma
,
what
can
become
of
my
life
?
<EOS>
there
is
nothing
worth
living
for
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
,
dear
?
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
.
<EOS>
Usually
she
herself
had
been
rebuked
by
her
daughter
for
involuntary
signs
of
despair
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
never
love
anybody
.
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
love
people
.
<EOS>
I
hate
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
time
will
come
,
dear
,
the
time
will
come
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
more
and

;
but

mother
's

with

,

,
"
I
ca
n't
bear
any

to

very

but
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
Then
the
mother
began
to
sob
,
for
this
spoiled
child
had
never
shown
such
dependence
on
her
before
:
and
so
they
clung
to
each
other
.
      
<EOS>
What
name
doth
Joy
most
borrow
  
When
life
is
fair
?
                    
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
What
name
doth
best
fit
Sorrow
  
<EOS>
In
young
despair
?
                    
<EOS>
"
To
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
   
<EOS>
There
was
a
much
more
lasting
trouble
at
the
rectory
.
<EOS>
Rex
arrived
there
only
to
throw
himself
on
his
bed
in
a
state
of
apparent
apathy
,
unbroken
till
the
next
day
,
when
it
began
to

interrupted
by
more

.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
said
about
his
going
to
Southampton
:
instead

,
the
chief

of
his
mother
and
Anna
was
how
to
tend
this
patient
who
did
not
want
to
be
well
,
and
from

,

in

,

an
irresponsive
,

who
met

with
a

"
Let
me
alone
.
"
<EOS>
His
father
looked
beyond
the
crisis
,
and
believed
it
to
be
the
shortest
way
out
of
an
unlucky
affair
;
but
he
was
sorry
for
the
inevitable

,
and
went
now

then
to
sit
by

in

for

,
parting
with

of

on
Rex
's
blank

,
and
a
"
God

you
,
my
boy
.
<EOS>
"
Warham
and
the
younger
children
used
to

the

the
door
to
see
this
incredible
thing
of
their
lively
brother
being
laid
low
;
but
fingers
were
immediately
shaken
at
them
to
drive
them
back
.
<EOS>
The
guardian
who
was
always
there
was
Anna
,
and
her
little
hand
was
allowed
to
rest
within
her
brother
's
,
though
he
never

a

.
<EOS>
Her

was
divided
between
anguish
for
Rex
and
reproach
of
Gwendolen
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
it
is
wicked
of
me
,
but
I
think
I
never
_
<EOS>
can
_
love
her
again
,
"
came
as
the
recurrent
burden
of
poor
little
Anna
's
inward

.
<EOS>
And
even
Mrs.
Gascoigne
had
an
angry
feeling
toward
her
niece
which
she
could
not
refrain
from
expressing
(
apologetically
)
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
of
course
it
is
better
,
and
we

to

that
she
is
not
in

;
but
really
.
<EOS>
Henry
,
I
think
she
is
hard
;
she
has

.
<EOS>
I
can
not
help
thinking
that
she
must
have
made
him
believe
something
,
or
the
disappointment
would
not
have
taken

in

.
<EOS>
And
some
blame
attaches
to
poor
Fanny
;
she
is
quite
blind
about
that
girl
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Gascoigne
answered
imperatively
:
"
<EOS>
The
less
said
on
that
point
the
better
,
Nancy
.
<EOS>
I
ought
to
have
been
more
awake
myself
.
<EOS>
As
to
the
boy
,
be
thankful
if
nothing
worse
ever
happens
to
him
.
<EOS>
Let
the
thing
die
out
as
quickly
as
possible
;
and
especially
with
regard
to
Gwendolen
 
<EOS>
let
it
be
as
if
it
had
never
been
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
rector
's
dominant
feeling
was
that
there
had
been
a
great
escape
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
in
love
with
Rex
in
return
would
have
made
a
much
harder
problem
,
the
solution
of
which
might
have
been
taken
out
of
his
hands
.
<EOS>
But
he
had
to
go
through
some
further
difficulty
.
  
<EOS>
One
fine
morning
Rex
asked
for
his
bath
,
and
made
his
toilet
as
usual
.
<EOS>
Anna
,
full
of
excitement
at
this
change
,
could
do
nothing
but
listen
for
his
coming
down
,
and
at
last
hearing

step
,
ran
to
the
foot
of
the
stairs
to
meet
him
.
<EOS>
For
the
first
time
he
gave
her
a
faint
smile
,
but
it
looked
so
melancholy
on
his
pale
face
that
she
could
hardly
help
crying
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nannie
!
"
<EOS>
he
said
gently
,
taking
her
hand
and
leading
her
slowly
along
with
him
to
the
drawing
-
room
.
<EOS>
His
mother
was
there
,
and
when
she
came
to
kiss
him
,
he
said
:
"
What
a
plague
I
am
!
"
  
<EOS>
Then
he
sat
still
and
looked
out
of
the
bow
-
window
on
the
lawn
and
shrubs
covered
with
hoar
-

,
across
which
the
sun
was
sending
faint
occasional
gleams
:
 
something
like
that
sad
smile
on
Rex
's
face
,
Anna
thought
.
<EOS>
He
felt
as
if
he
had
had
a
resurrection
into
a
new
world
,
and
did
not
know
what
to
do
with
himself
there
,
the
old
interests
being
left
behind
.
<EOS>
Anna
sat
near
him
,
pretending
to
work
,
but
really
watching
him
with
yearning
looks
.
<EOS>
Beyond
the
garden
hedge
there
was
a
road
where
wagons
and
carts
sometimes
went
on
field
-
work
:
a
railed
opening
was
made
in
the
hedge
,
because
the
upland
with
its
bordering
wood
and

of
ash
-
trees
against
the
sky
was
a
pretty
sight
.
<EOS>
Presently
there
came
along
a
wagon
laden
with
timber
;
the
horses
were
straining
their
grand
muscles
,
and
the
driver
having
cracked
his
whip
,
ran
along
anxiously
to
guide
the
leader
's
head
,
fearing
a
swerve
.
<EOS>
Rex
seemed
to
be
shaken
into
attention
,
rose
and
looked
till
the
last
quivering
trunk
of
the
timber
had
disappeared
,
and
then
walked
once
or
twice
along
the
room
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Gascoigne
was
no
longer
there
,
and
when
he
came
to
sit
down
again
,
Anna
,
seeing
a
return
of
speech
in
her
brother
's

,
could
not

the
impulse
to
bring
a
little
stool
and
seat
herself
against
his
knee
,
looking
up
at
him
with
an
expression
which
seemed
to
say
,
"
Do
speak
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
And
he
spoke
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
'll
tell
you
what
I
'm
thinking
of
,
Nannie
.
<EOS>
I
will
go
to
Canada
,
or
somewhere
of
that
sort
.
"
<EOS>
(
Rex
had
not
studied
the
character
of
our
colonial
possessions
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
Rex
,
not
for
always
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
to
get
my
bread
there
.
<EOS>
I
should
like
to
build
a
hut
,
and
work
hard
at
clearing
,
and
have
everything
wild
about
me
,
and
a
great
wide
quiet
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
not
take
me
with
you
?
"
<EOS>
said
Anna
,
the
big
tears
coming
fast
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
could
I
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
like
it
better
than
anything
;
and
settlers
go
with
their
families
.
<EOS>
I
would
sooner
go
there
than
stay
here
in
England
.
<EOS>
I
could
make
the
fires
,
and
mend
the
clothes
,
and
cook
the
food
;
and
I
could
learn
how
to
make
the
bread
before
we
went
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
nicer
than
anything
 
like
playing
at
life
over
again
,
as
we
used
to
do
when
we
made
our
tent
with
the
drugget
,
and
had
our
little
plates
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Father
and
mother
would
not
let
you

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
think
they
would
,
when
I
explained

.
<EOS>
It
would
save
money
;
and
papa
would
have
more
to
bring
up
the
boys
with
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
further
talk
of
the
same
practical
kind
at

,
and
it
ended
in
Rex
's
being
obliged
to
consent
that
Anna
should
go
with
him
when
he
spoke
to
his
father
on
the

.
  
<EOS>
Of
course
it
was
when
the
rector
was
alone
in
his
study
.
<EOS>
Their
mother
would
become
reconciled
to
whatever
he
decided
on
,
but
mentioned
to
her
first
,
the
question
would
have
distressed
her
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
my
children
!
"
said
Mr.
Gascoigne
,
cheerfully
,
as
they
entered
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
comfort
to
see
Rex
about
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
we
sit
down
with
you
a
little
,
papa
?
"
said
Anna
.
<EOS>
"
Rex
has
something
to
say
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
With
all
my
heart
.
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
noticeable
group
that
these
three
creatures
made
,
each
of
them
with
a
face
of
the
same
structural
type
 
<EOS>
the
straight
brow
,
the
nose
suddenly
straightened
from
an
intention
of
being
aquiline
,
the
short

lip
,
the
short
but
strong
and
well
-
hung
chin
:
<EOS>
there
was
even
the
same
tone
of
complexion
and
set
of
the

.
<EOS>
The
gray
-
haired
father
was
at
once

<EOS>
Brackenshaw

,
where

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

What

No

Pre

,

<EOS>
Perhaps

<EOS>
And

<EOS>
Who

<EOS>
They
prompt

The

"

"

;

.
<EOS>
Archery
has
no

;
breaks

's

,

;

,
which
for

.
<EOS>
And

;

.
<EOS>
These

,

Altogether

,

.
  
<EOS>
And

-

.
<EOS>
There

,

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
Here

seemed
a

.
<EOS>
It

.
  
<EOS>
"
That

,
"

<EOS>
"
First

!
<EOS>
tremendously

,
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Her

;

.
<EOS>
Not

:

;

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Short

,
<EOS>
what

_

_

?
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
The

might
have

than

.
<EOS>
We
English
are
a

,
and
any
chance

us
will
present

of

;
but

,

.
<EOS>

was
enough
:
she
herself
was
determined
to
see
nobody
in
particular
,
or
to
turn
her
eyes
any
way
except
toward
Lady
Brackenshaw
,
but
her
thoughts
undeniably
turned
in
other
ways
.
<EOS>
It
entered
a
little
into
her
pleasure
that
Herr
Klesmer
must
be
observing
her
at
a
moment
when
music
was
out
of
the
question
,
and
his
superiority
very
far
in
the
back
-
ground
;
for
vanity
is
as
ill
at
ease
under
indifference
as
tenderness
is
under
a
love
which
it
can
not
return
;
and
the
unconquered
Klesmer
threw
a
trace
of
his
malign
power
even
across
her
pleasant
consciousness
that
Mr.
Grandcourt
was
seeing
her
to
the
utmost
advantage
,
and
was
probably
giving
her
an
admiration
unmixed
with
criticism
.
<EOS>
She
did
not
expect
to
admire
_
him
_
,
but
that
was
not
necessary
to
her
peace
of
mind
.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
met
Lady
Brackenshaw
's
gracious
smile
without
blushing
(
which
only
came
to
her
when
she
was
taken
by
surprise
)
,
but
with
a
charming
gladness
of
expression
,
and
then
bent
with
easy
grace
to
have
the
star
fixed
near
her
shoulder
.
<EOS>
That
little
ceremony
had
been
over
long
enough
for
her
to
have
exchanged
playful
speeches
and
received
congratulations
as
she
moved
among
the
groups
who
were
now
interesting
themselves
in
the
results
of
the
scoring
;
but
it
happened
that
she
stood
outside
examining
the
point
of
an
arrow
with
rather
an
absent
air
when
Lord
Brackenshaw
came
up
to
her
and
said
:
  
"
Miss
Harleth
,
here
is
a
gentleman
who
is
not
willing
to
wait
any
longer
for
an
introduction
.
<EOS>
He
has
been
getting
Mrs.
Davilow
to
send
me
with
him
.
<EOS>
Will
you
allow
me
to
introduce
Mr.
Mallinger
Grandcourt
?
"
    
<EOS>
MEETING
STREAMS
.
      
<EOS>
The
beginning
of
an
acquaintance
whether
with
persons
or
things
is
to
    
get
a
definite
outline
for
our
ignorance
.
   
<EOS>
Mr.
Grandcourt
's
wish
to
be
introduced
had
no
suddenness
for
Gwendolen
;
but
when
Lord
Brackenshaw
moved
aside
a
little
for
the
prefigured
stranger
to
come
forward
<EOS>
and
she
felt
herself
face
to
face
with
the
real
man
<EOS>
,
there
was
a
little
shock
which
flushed
her
cheeks
and
vexatiously
deepened
with
her
consciousness
of
it
.
<EOS>
The
shock
came
from
the
reversal
of
her
expectations
:
Grandcourt
could
hardly
have
been
more
unlike
all
her
imaginary
portraits
of
him
.
<EOS>
He
was
slightly
taller
than
herself
,
and
their
eyes
seemed
to
be
on
a
level
;
there
was
not
the
faintest
smile
on
his
face
as
he
looked
at
her
,
not
a
trace
of
self
-
consciousness
or
anxiety
in
his
bearing
:
when
he
raised
his
hat
he
showed
an
extensive
baldness
surrounded
with
a
mere
fringe
of
reddish
-
blonde
hair
,
but
he
also
showed
a
perfect
hand
;
the
line
of
feature
from
brow
to
chin
undisguised
by
beard
was
decidedly
handsome
,
with
only
moderate
departures
from
the
perpendicular
,
and
the
slight
whisker
too
was
perpendicular
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
possible
for
a
human
aspect
to
be
freer
from
grimace
or
solicitous
wrigglings
:
also
it
was
perhaps
not
possible
for
a
breathing
man
wide
awake
to
look
less
animated
.
<EOS>
The
correct
Englishman
,
drawing
himself
up
from
his
bow
into
rigidity
,
assenting
severely
,
and
seemed
to
be
in
a
state
of
internal
drill
,
suggests
a
suppressed
vivacity
,
and
may
be
suspected
of
letting
go
with
some
violence
when
he
is
released
from
parade
;
but
Grandcourt
's
bearing
had
no
rigidity
,
it
inclined
rather
to
the
flaccid
.
<EOS>
His
complexion
had
a
faded
fairness
resembling
that
of
an
actress
when
bare
of
the
artificial
white
and
red
;
his
long
narrow
gray
eyes
expressed
nothing
but
indifference
.
<EOS>
Attempts
at
description
are
stupid
:
who
can
all
at
once
describe
a
human
being
?
<EOS>
even
when
he
is
presented
to
us
we
only
begin
that
knowledge
of
his
appearance
which
must
be
completed
by
innumerable
impressions
under
differing
circumstances
.
<EOS>
We
recognize
the
alphabet
;
we
are
not
sure
of
the
language
.
<EOS>
I
am
only
mentioning
the
point
that
Gwendolen
saw
by
the
light
of
a
prepared
contrast
in
the
first
minutes
of
her
meeting
with
Grandcourt
:
they
were
summed
up
in
the
words
,
"
He
is
not
ridiculous
.
"
<EOS>
But
forthwith
Lord
Brackenshaw
was
gone
,
and
what
is
called
conversation
had
begun
,
the
first
and
constant
element
in
it
being
that
Grandcourt
looked
at
Gwendolen
persistently
with
a
slightly
exploring
gaze
,
but
without
change
of
expression
,
while
she
only
occasionally

at

with
a
flash
of
observation
a
little

by
coquetry
.
<EOS>
Also
,
after
her
answers
there
was
a
longer
or
shorter
pause
before
he
spoke
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
used
to
think
archery
was
a
great
bore
,
"
Grandcourt
began
.
<EOS>
He
spoke
with
a
fine

,
but
with
a
certain
broken
drawl
,
as
of
a
distinguished
personage
with
a
distinguished
cold
on
his
chest
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
converted
to
-
day
?
"
said
Gwendolen
.
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,
during
which
she
imagined
various
degrees
and
modes

opinion
about
herself
that
might

Grandcourt
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
since
I
saw
you
shooting
.
<EOS>
In
things
of
this
sort
one
generally
sees
people
missing

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

are
a
first
-

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,

,
having

of
Grandcourt
,

of

to

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
left
off
shooting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
then
you
are
a
formidable
person
.
<EOS>
People
who
have
done
things
once
and
left

,

using

.
<EOS>
I
hope
you
have
not

all

,

I
practice

great

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,

Gwendolen
made
several

of

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
What
do

call

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,

I

,

.
<EOS>
But

have
not
left
off

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,
wherein

Grandcourt
's
position
,
and
decided
that
he
was
the
most

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
One
must
do
something
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
do

care
about
the
turf
?
 
<EOS>
or
is
that
among
the
things
you
have
left
off
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,

Gwendolen
thought
that
a
man
of

calm
,
cold

might
be
less
disagreeable
as
a

than
other
men
,
and
not

his
wife
's

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
I
run
a
horse
now
and

;
but
I
do

go
in
for

thing
as
some

do
.
<EOS>
Are
you
fond
of
horses
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
indeed
:
I
never
like
my
life
so
well
as
when
I
am
on
horseback
,
having
a
great

.
<EOS>
I
think
of
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
only
feel

strong
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,
wherein

,
but

that

not

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
Do

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't

.
<EOS>
When

I
never

.
<EOS>
It
seems

that

I

.
<EOS>
I

go

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause

Gwendolen
had
run

.
)
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Everything

poor

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
_
You
_

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
(
Pause
,

)
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

)
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

)
  
<EOS>
"
Miss

.
<EOS>
No
 
<EOS>
that

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
He

.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen

_

-

<EOS>
And

,

hers
 
<EOS>
a
sort

few

How

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

taking

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
It

Juliet
Fenn
,

last
<EOS>

:
<EOS>
underhung

resembling

.
<EOS>
(
Surely
,

,

,

,

.
)
  
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
Every

else

,

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Who
this

she

;

what
was
Grandcourt
's

.
<EOS>
Precisely

:

,
but

,
who
was

now

,

,

finger

his
waistcoat
-
pocket
,
and
his
right
slightly

thin

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

style
Miss
Arrowpoint
admires
most
,
"
was

that
glanced

's

,
while
her

and

.
<EOS>
But

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

,

Davilow

"

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The
"
yes
"
in

the
usual

.
  
<EOS>
"
You

Gwendolen
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
You
ca

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

fat

_

"

<EOS>
In

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mrs.

<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

.

The

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

.

.

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

you
do
me
the
honor
 
<EOS>
the
next
 
or
another
quadrille
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should
have

,
"
said

looking

,
"
but
I
am
engaged
for
the
next
to
Mr.
Clintock
 
<EOS>
and

;

.
<EOS>
"
She

's

,

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
I

"

.
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Yes

,
"

.
<EOS>
Always

the

.
<EOS>
"
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
no
 
not

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
That

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

?
"
<EOS>
Here

"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

_
<EOS>
au

_
.

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
the

.
<EOS>
No

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Gwendolen

,

than
a
ball
under
,

a

along

.

Gwendolen

Robin

:

,

,

;

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Impossible

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
was

,
and
Mr.
Lush
's
prominent
eyes
,
fat

figure
,
and
strong

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
To

from
his

,

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

;
but

thus

.
<EOS>
They

into

,

.
<EOS>
The
other

there
were
at
a
distance

would

,
but

end
where

,
and
the
second
wide
opening
into

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
,
when

half
turned
round
,

"
Do
you
like
this

thing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
If

had

to

half

,
she

have

,
and
could
only

.
<EOS>
But
for
some

reason

was
a

of

she

<EOS>
she
dared
not

:
she

that

Grandcourt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

,

"
kind

"
was

whether

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
She

,
and

among

Davilow
had

.
<EOS>
As

her

was
vacant
,
but
she

,
and
,

,

.
<EOS>
There

no

:
her

came

before

,

,

,

,
"
Gwendolen
,

,

.
"
<EOS>
Having

of
this

,

of

's
,

imagined

that
her
daughter

make

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
hardly
a
bow
that
Gwendolen
gave
 
rather
<EOS>
,
it

the
slightest
forward

away

the
physiognomy
that
inclined

her
,
and
she
immediately

her

,

,
"
I

burnous
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No

,

Mr.
Lush
was

,
and
had

burnous
in

:
to

,

;
and
,

,

,
"
Pray

?
"
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

,
"
No
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
A
man
who
forgave
this
would
have
much

,
supposing

;

burnous
Mr.

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
quietly

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
You
had

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Thanks
;
perhaps

,
"
said

,
rising
,
and

burnous
on

.
  
<EOS>
After
that
,
Mr.
Grandcourt
exchanged
a

with
Mrs.
Davilow
,
and
,
in

,
asked

to
call
at
Offendene
the
next
day
.
<EOS>
He
was
evidently
not
offended
by
the
insult
directed
toward
his
friend
.
<EOS>
Certainly
Gwendolen
's
refusal
of
the
burnous
from
Mr.
Lush
was
open
to
the
interpretation
that
she
wished
to
receive
it
from
Mr.
Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
But
she
,
poor
child
,
had
no
design
in
this
action
,
and
was
simply
following
her
antipathy
and
inclination
,
confiding
in
them
as
she
did
in
the
more
reflective
judgments
into
which
they
entered
as
sap
into
leafage
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
had
no
sense
that
these
men
were
dark
enigmas
to
her
,
or
that
she
needed
any
help
in
drawing
conclusions
about
them
 
Mr.
Grandcourt
at
least
.
<EOS>
The
chief
question
was
,
how
far
his
character
and
ways
might
answer
her
wishes
;
and
unless
she
were
satisfied
about
that
,
she
had
said
to
herself
that
she
would
not
accept
his
offer
.
  
<EOS>
Could
there
be
a
slenderer
,
more
insignificant
thread
in
human
history
than
this
consciousness
of
a
girl
,
busy
with
her
small
inferences
of
the
way
in
which
she
could
make
her
life
pleasant
?
 
<EOS>
in
a
time
,
too
,
when
ideas
were
with
fresh
vigor
making
armies
of
themselves
,
and
the
universal
kinship
was
declaring
itself
fiercely
;
when
women
on
the
other
side
of
the
world
would
not
mourn
for
the
husbands
and
sons
who
died
bravely
in
a
common
cause
,
and
men
stinted
of
bread
on
our
side
of
the
world
heard
of
that
willing
loss
and
were
patient
:
a
time
when
the
soul
of
man
was
walking
to
pulses
which
had
for
centuries
been
beating
in
him
unfelt
,
until
their
full
sum
made
a
new
life
of
terror
or
of
joy
.
  
<EOS>
What
in
the
midst
of
that
mighty
drama
are
girls
and
their
blind
visions
?
<EOS>
They
are
the
Yea
or
Nay
of
that
good
for
which
men
are
enduring
and
fighting
.
<EOS>
In
these
delicate
vessels
is
borne
onward
through
the
ages
the
treasure
of
human
affections
.
      
<EOS>
"
O
gentlemen
,
the
time
of
life
is
short
;
  
To
spend
that
shortness
basely
were
too
long
,
  
If
life
did
ride
upon
a
dial
's
point
,
  
Still
ending
at
the
arrival
of
an
hour
.
"
                  
<EOS>
SHAKESPEARE
:
<EOS>
_
Henry
IV
_
.
   
<EOS>
On
the
second
day
after
the
Archery
Meeting
,
Mr.
Henleigh
Mallinger
Grandcourt
was
at
his
breakfast
-
table
with
Mr.
Lush
.
<EOS>
Everything
around
them
was
agreeable
:
the
summer
air
through
the
open
windows
,
at
which
the
dogs
could
walk
in
from
the
old
green
turf
on
the
lawn
;
the
soft
,
purplish
coloring
of
the
park
beyond
,
stretching
toward
a
mass
of
bordering
wood
;
the
still
life
in
the
room
,
which
seemed
the
stiller
for
its
sober
antiquated
elegance
,
as
if
it
kept
a
conscious
,
well
-
bred
silence
,
unlike
the
restlessness
of
vulgar
furniture
.
  
<EOS>
Whether
the
gentlemen
were
agreeable
to
each
other
was
less
evident
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grandcourt
had
drawn
his
chair
aside
so
as
to
face
the
lawn
,
and
with
his
left
leg
over
another
chair
,
and
his
right
elbow
on
the
table
,
was
smoking
a
large
cigar
,
while
his
companion
was
still
eating
.
<EOS>
The
dogs
 
half
-
a
-
dozen
of
various
kinds
were
moving
lazily
in
and
out
,
taking
attitudes
of
brief
attention
 
gave
a
vacillating
preference
first
to
one
gentleman
,
then
to
the
other
;
being
dogs
in
such
good
circumstances
that
they
could
play
at
hunger
,
and
liked
to
be
served
with
delicacies
which
they
declined
to
put
in
their
mouths
;
all
except
Fetch
,
the
beautiful
liver
-
colored
water
-
spaniel
,
which
sat
with
its
forepaws
firmly
planted
and
its
expressive
brown
face
turned
upward
,
watching
Grandcourt
with
unshaken
constancy
.
<EOS>
He
held
in
his
lap
a
tiny
Maltese
dog
with
a
tiny
silver
collar
and
bell
,
and
when
he
had
a
hand
unused
by
cigar
or
coffee
-
cup
,
it
rested
on
this
small
parcel
of
animal
warmth
.
<EOS>
I
fear
that
Fetch
was
jealous
,
and
wounded
that
her
master
gave
her
no
word
or
look
;
at
last
it
seemed
that
she
could
bear
this
neglect
no
longer
,
and
she
gently
put
her
large
silky
paw
on
her
master
's
leg
.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
looked
at
her
with
unchanged
face
for
half
a
minute
,
and
then
took
the
trouble
to
lay
down
his
cigar
while
he
lifted
the
unimpassioned
Fluff
close
to
his
chin
and
gave
it
caressing
pats
,
all
the
while
gravely
watching
Fetch
,
who
,
poor
thing
,
whimpered
interruptedly
,
as
if
trying
to
repress
that
sign
of
discontent
,
and
at
last
rested
her
head
beside
the
appealing
paw
,
looking
up
with
piteous
beseeching
.
<EOS>
So
,
at
least
,
a
lover
of
dogs
must
have
interpreted
Fetch
,
and
Grandcourt
kept
so
many
dogs
that
he
was
reputed
to
love
them
;
at
any
rate
,
his
impulse
to
act
just
in
that
way
started
from
such
an
interpretation
.
<EOS>
But
when
the
amusing
anguish
burst
forth
in
a
howling
bark
,
Grandcourt
pushed
Fetch
down
without
speaking
,
and
,
depositing
Fluff
carelessly
on
the
table
(
where
his
black
nose
predominated
over
a
salt
-
cellar
)
,
began
to
look
to
his
cigar
,
and
found
,
with
some
annoyance
against
Fetch
as
the
cause
,
that
the
brute
of
a
cigar
required
relighting
.
<EOS>
Fetch
,
having
begun
to
wail
,
found
,
like
others
of
her
sex
,
that
it
was
not
easy
to
leave
off
;
indeed
,
the
second
howl
was
a
louder
one
,
and
the
third
was
like
unto
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
Turn
out
that
brute
,
will
you
?
"
said
Grandcourt
to
Lush
,
without
raising
his
voice
or
looking
at
him
 
as
if
he
counted
on
attention
to
the
smallest
sign
.
  
<EOS>
And
Lush
immediately
rose
,
lifted
Fetch
,
though
she
was
rather
heavy
,
and
he
was
not
fond
of
stooping
,
and
carried
her
out
,
disposing
of
her
in
some
way
that
took
him
a
couple
of
minutes
before
he
returned
.
<EOS>
He
then
lit
a
cigar
,
placed
himself
at
an
angle
where
he
could
see
Grandcourt
's
face
without
turning
,
and
presently
said
    
"
Shall
you
ride
or
drive
to
Quetcham
to
-
day
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
not
going
to
Quetcham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
did
not
go
yesterday
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
smoked
in
silence
for
half
a
minute
,
and
then
said
    
"
I
suppose
you
sent
my
card
and
inquiries
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
went
myself
at
four
,
and
said
you
were
sure
to
be
there
shortly
.
<EOS>
They
would
suppose
some
accident
prevented
you
from
fulfilling
the
intention
.
<EOS>
Especially
if
you
go
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Silence
for
a
couple
of
minutes
.
<EOS>
Then
Grandcourt
said
,
"
What
men
are
invited
here
with
their
wives
?
"
  
<EOS>
Lush
drew
out
a
note
-
book
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Captain
and
Mrs.
Torrington
come
next
week
.
<EOS>
Then
there
are
Mr.
Hollis
and
Lady
Flora
,
and
the
Cushats
and
the
Gogoffs
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Rather
a
ragged
lot
,
"
remarked
Grandcourt
,
after
a
while
.
<EOS>
"
Why
did
you
ask
the
Gogoffs
?
<EOS>
When
you
write
invitations
in
my
name
,
be
good
enough
to
give
me
a
list
,
instead
of
bringing
down
a
giantess
on
me
without
my
knowledge
.
<EOS>
She
spoils
the
look
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
invited
the
Gogoffs
yourself
when
you
met
them
in
Paris
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
has
my
meeting
them
in
Paris
to
do
with
it
?
<EOS>
I
told
you
to
give
me
a
list
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
,
like
many
others
,
had
two
remarkably
different
voices
.
<EOS>
Hitherto
we
have
heard
him
speaking
in
a
superficial
interrupted
drawl
<EOS>
suggestive
chiefly
of
languor
and
_
<EOS>
ennui
_
.
<EOS>
But
this
last
brief
speech
was
uttered
in
subdued
inward
,
yet
distinct
,
tones
,
which
Lush
had
long
been
used
to
recognize
as
the
expression
of
a
peremptory
will
.
  
<EOS>
"
Are
there
any
other
couples
you
would
like
to
invite
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
think
of
some
decent
people
,
with
a
daughter
or
two
.
<EOS>
And
one
of
your
damned
musicians
.
<EOS>
But
not
a
comic
fellow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wonder
if
Klesmer
would
consent
to
come
to
us
when
he
leaves
Quetcham
.
<EOS>
Nothing
but
first
-
class
music
will
go
down
with
Miss
Arrowpoint
.
"
  
<EOS>
Lush
spoke
carelessly
,
but
he
was
really
seizing
an
opportunity
and
fixing
an
observant
look
on
Grandcourt
,
who
now
for
the
first
time
,
turned
his
eyes
toward
his
companion
,
but
slowly
and
without
speaking
until
he
had
given
two
long
luxuriant
puffs
,
when
he
said
,
perhaps
in
a
lower
tone
than
ever
,
but
with
a
perceptible
edge
of
contempt
    
<EOS>
"
What
in
the
name
of
nonsense
have
I
to
do
with
Miss
Arrowpoint
and
her
music
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
something
,
"
said
Lush
,
jocosely
.
<EOS>
"
You
need
not
give
yourself
much
trouble
,
perhaps
.
<EOS>
But
some
forms
must
be
gone
through
before
a
man
can
marry
a
million
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Very
likely
.
<EOS>
But
I
am
not
going
to
marry
a
million
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
's
a
pity
 
to
fling
away
an
opportunity
of
this
sort
,
and
knock
down
your
own

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
_
Your
_
plans
,
I
suppose
you
mean
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
some
debts
,
you
know
,
and
things
may
turn
out
inconveniently
after
all
.
<EOS>
The
heirship
is
not
_
absolutely
_
certain
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
did
not
answer
,
and
Lush
went
on
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
really
is
a
fine
opportunity
.
<EOS>
The
father
and
mother
ask
for
nothing
better
,
I
can
see
,
and
the
daughter
's
looks
and
manners
require
no
allowances
,
any
more
than
if
she
had
n't
a
sixpence
.
<EOS>
She
is
not
beautiful
;
but
equal
to
carrying
any
rank
.
<EOS>
And
she
is
not
likely
to
refuse
such
prospects
as
you
can
offer
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
not
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
The
father
and
mother
would
let
you
do
anything
you
like
with
