.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
should
not
like
to
do
anything
with
them
.
"
  
<EOS>
Here
it
was
Lush
who
made
a
little
pause
before
speaking
again
,
and
then
he
said
in
a
deep
voice
of
remonstrance
,
"
<EOS>
Good
God
,
Grandcourt
!
<EOS>
after
your
experience
,
will
you
let
a
whim
interfere
with
your
comfortable
settlement
in
life
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Spare
your
oratory
.
<EOS>
I
know
what
I
am
going
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"
<EOS>
Lush
put
down
his
cigar
and
thrust
his
hands
into
his
side
pockets
,
as
if
he
had
to
face
something
exasperating
,
but
meant
to
keep
his
temper
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
marry
the
other
girl
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Have
you
fallen
in
love
?
"
<EOS>
This
question
carried
a
strong
sneer
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
going
to
marry
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
made
her
an
offer
already
,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
is
a
young
lady
with
a
will
of
her
own
,
I
fancy
.
<EOS>
Extremely
well
fitted
to
make
a
rumpus
.
<EOS>
She
would
know
what
she
liked
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
She
does
n't
like
you
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
with
the
ghost
of
a

.
  
<EOS>
"
Perfectly
true
,
"
said
Lush
,
adding
again
in
a
markedly

tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
However
,
if
you
and
she
are
devoted
to
each
other
,
that
will
be
enough
.
"
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
took
no
notice
of
this
speech
,
but
sipped
his
coffee
,
rose
,
and
strolled
out
on
the
lawn
,
all
the
dogs
following
him
.
  
<EOS>
Lush
glanced
after
him
a
moment
,
then
resumed
his
cigar
and
lit
it
,
but
smoked
slowly
,
consulting
his
beard
with
inspecting
eyes
and
fingers
,
till
he
finally
stroked
it
with
an
air
of
having
arrived
at
some
conclusion
,
and
said
in
a
subdued
voice
    
"
Check
,
old
boy
!
"
  
<EOS>
Lush
,
being
a
man
of
some
ability
,
had
not
known
Grandcourt
for
fifteen
years
without
learning
what
sort
of
measures
were
useless
with
him
,
though
what
sort
might
be
useful
remained
often
dubious
.
<EOS>
In
the
beginning
of
his
career
he
held
a
fellowship
,
and
was
near
taking
orders
for
the
sake
of
a
college
living
,
but
not
being
fond
of
that
prospect
accepted
instead
the
office
of
traveling
companion
to
a
marquess
,
and
afterward
to
young
Grandcourt
,
who
had
lost
his
father
early
,
and
who
found
Lush
so
convenient
that
he
had
allowed
him
to
become
prime
minister
in
all
his
more
personal
affairs
.
<EOS>
The
habit
of
fifteen
years
had
made
Grandcourt
more
and
more
in
need
of
Lush
's
handiness
,
and
Lush
more
and
more
in
need
of
the
lazy
luxury
to
which
his
transactions
on
behalf
of
Grandcourt
made
no
interruption
worth
reckoning
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
say
that
the
same
lengthened
habit
had
intensified
Grandcourt
's
want
of
respect
for
his
companion
since
that
want
had
been
absolute
from
the
beginning
,
but
it
had
confirmed
his
sense
that
he
might
kick
Lush
if
he
chose
 
only
he
never
did
choose
to
kick
any
animal
,
because
the
act
of
kicking
is
a
compromising
attitude
,
and
a
gentleman
's
dogs
should
be
kicked
for
him
.
<EOS>
He
only
said
things
which
might
have
exposed
himself
to
be
kicked
if
his
confidant
had
been
a
man
of
independent
spirit
.
<EOS>
But
what
son
of
a
vicar
who
has
stinted
his
wife
and
daughters
of
calico
in
order
to
send
his
male
offspring
to
Oxford
,
can
keep
an
independent
spirit
when
he
is
bent
on
dining
with
high
discrimination
,
riding
good
horses
,
living
generally
in
the
most
luxuriant
honey
-
blossomed
clover
 
and
all
without
working
?
<EOS>
Mr.
Lush
had
passed
for
a
scholar
once
,
and
had
still
a
sense
of
scholarship
when
he
was
not
trying
to
remember
much
of
it
;
but
the
bachelor
's
and
other
arts
which
soften
manners
are
a
time
-
honored
preparation
for
sinecures
;
and
Lush
's
present
comfortable
provision
was
as
good
a
sinecure
in
not
requiring
more
than
the
odor
of
departed
learning
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
unconscious
of
being
held
kickable
,
but
he
preferred
counting
that
estimate
among
the
peculiarities
of
Grandcourt
's
character
,
which
made
one
of
his
incalculable
moods
or
judgments
as
good
as
another
.
<EOS>
Since
in
his
own
opinion
he
had
never
done
a
bad
action
,
it
did
not
seem
necessary
to
consider
whether
he
should
be
likely
to
commit
one
if
his
love
of
ease
required
it
.
<EOS>
Lush
's
love
of
ease
was
well
-
satisfied
at
present
,
and
if
his
puddings
were
rolled
toward
him
in
the
dust
,
he
took
the
inside
bits
and
found
them
relishing
.
  
<EOS>
This
morning
,
for
example
,
though
he
had
encountered
more
annoyance
than
usual
,
he
went
to
his
private
sitting
-
room
and
played
a
good
hour
on
the
violoncello
.
      
<EOS>
"
Philistia
,
be
thou
glad
of
me
!
"
   
<EOS>
Grandcourt
having
made
up
his
mind
to
marry
Miss
Harleth
,
showed
a
power
of
adapting
means
to
ends
.
<EOS>
During
the
next
fortnight
there
was
hardly
a
day
on
which
by
some
arrangement
or
other
he
did
not
see
her
,
or
prove
by
emphatic
attentions
that
she
occupied
his
thoughts
.
<EOS>
His
cousin
,
Mrs.
Torrington
,
was
now
doing
the
honors
of
his
house
,
so
that
Mrs.
Davilow
and
Gwendolen
could
be
invited
to
a
large
party
at
Diplow
in
which
there
were
many
witnesses
how
the
host
distinguished
the
dowerless
beauty
,
and
showed
no
solicitude
about
the
heiress
.
<EOS>
The
world
 
<EOS>
I
mean
Mr.
Gascoigne
and
all
the
families
worth
speaking
of
within
visiting
distance
of
Pennicote
 
felt
an
assurance
on
the
subject
which
in

rector
's
mind
converted
itself
into
a
resolution
to
do
his
duty
by
his
niece
and
see

.
<EOS>
Indeed
the
wonder
to
him
and
<EOS>

Davilow
was
that

presented

not

;
and
in

himself

.
<EOS>
When

to

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

served
to
heighten

determination
on
another

.
<EOS>
He
had
never
admitted

that
Gwendolen
might
refuse
him
,
but
 
heaven
help
us
all
!
 
<EOS>
we
are
often
unable
to
act
on
our
certainties
;
our
objection
to
a
contrary
issue
(
were
it
possible
)
is
so
strong
that
it
rises
like
a
spectral
illusion
between
us
and
our
certainty
;
we
are
rationally
sure
that
the
blind
worm
can
not
bite
us
mortally
,
but
it
would
be
so
intolerable
to
be
bitten
,
and
the
creature
has
a
biting
look
 
we
decline
to
handle
it
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
asked
leave
to
have
a
beautiful
horse
of
his
brought
for
Gwendolen
to
ride
.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
was
to
accompany
her
in
the
carriage
,
and
they
were
to
go
to
Diplow
to
lunch
,
Grandcourt

them
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
mid
-

time
,
not
too
warm
for
a
noonday

of
five

to
be

;
the
poppies
glowed
on
the

of
the
fields
,
there
was
enough

to
move
gently
like
a

among

of
uncut

,
and
to
wing
the
shadow

;
here

were

,
there

were

under
the
last

from
a
wide
space
of
stubble
,
but
everywhere

green

made
a
broader

for
the
corn

fields
,
and
the

took

.
<EOS>
The

lay
through
a
bit

where

looked
much
as

where

to

that

.
  
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen

cantering

,

's

.
<EOS>
Here

to

all

,
and

could
only

's

.
<EOS>
Certainly

,

,

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

or
<EOS>
as

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

not

<EOS>
Grandcourt

,

ability
<EOS>

,

"

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

Mamma

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

No

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

something

,

's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Damn

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
He
was

,

full
of
an

,

.
<EOS>
Did

?
<EOS>
It

he

.
<EOS>
Or

?
<EOS>
Equally
a
delusion
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
make

in

that
could

.
<EOS>
But

,

:

.
<EOS>
She

,

?
  
<EOS>
However
,

,

_

But

"

"

<EOS>

,

Davilow

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
We

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
What

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

_

.

:

.

,

.

Mr.

The

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

delightful
prospect
for
the
sport
's
sake
<EOS>
:

not

.
<EOS>
To

"
  
"

.

"

"

<EOS>
Gwendolen

<EOS>
It

<EOS>

Still

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
I

It

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

Miss

.

<EOS>
This
apparent
forgetfulness
might
be
taken
for
the
distraction
of
a
lover
so
absorbed
in
thinking
of
the
beloved
object
as
to
forget
an
appointment
which
would
bring
him
into
her
actual
presence
.
<EOS>
And
the
good
-
natured
Earl
gave
Gwendolen
a
distant
jocose
hint
to
that
effect
,
which
she
took
with
suitable
quietude
.
<EOS>
But
the
thought
in
her
mind
was
"
Can
he
too
be
starting
away
from
a
decision
?
<EOS>
"
It
was
not
exactly
a
pleasant
thought
to
her
;
but
it
was
near
the
truth
.
<EOS>
"
Starting
away
,
"
however
,
was
not
the
right
expression
for
the
languor
of
intention
that
came
over
Grandcourt
,
like
a
fit
of
diseased
numbness
,
when
an
end
seemed
within
easy
reach
:
to
desist
then
,
when
all
expectation
was
to
the
contrary
,
became
another
gratification
of
mere
will
,
sublimely
independent
of
definite
motive
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
he
had
begun
a
second
large
cigar
in
a
vague
,
hazy
obstinacy
which
,
if
Lush
or
any
other
mortal
who
might
be
insulted
with
impunity
had
interrupted
by
overtaking
him
with
a
request
for
his
return
,
would
have
expressed
itself
by
a
slow
removal
of
his
cigar
,
to
say
in
an
undertone
,
"
You
'll
be
kind
enough
to
go
to
the
devil
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
But
he
was
not
interrupted
,
and
the
rovers
set
off
without
any
visible
depression
of
spirits
,
leaving
behind
only
a
few
of
the
less
vigorous
ladies
,
including
Mrs.
Davilow
,
who
preferred
a
quiet
stroll
free
from
obligation
to
keep
up
with
others
.
<EOS>
The
enjoyment
of
the
day
was
soon
at
its
highest
pitch
,
the
archery
getting
more
spirited
and
the
changing
scenes
of
the
forest
from
roofed
grove
to
open
glade
growing
lovelier
with
the
lengthening
shadows
,
and
the
deeply
-
felt
but
undefinable
gradations
of
the
mellowing
afternoon
.
<EOS>
It
was
agreed
that
they
were
playing
an
extemporized
"
As
you
like
it
;
"
and
when
a
pretty
compliment
had
been
turned
to
Gwendolen
about
her
having
the
part
of
Rosalind
,
she
felt
the
more
compelled
to
be
surpassing
in
loveliness
.
<EOS>
This
was
not
very
difficult
to
her
,
for
the
effect
of
what
had
happened
to
-
day
was
an
excitement
which
needed
a
vent
 
a
sense
of
adventure
rather
than
alarm
,
and
a
straining
toward
the
management
of
her
retreat
,
so
as
not
to
be
impeded
.
  
<EOS>
The
roving
had
been
lasting
nearly
an
hour
before
the
arrival
at
the
Whispering
Stones
,
two
tall
conical
blocks
that
leaned
toward
each
other
like
gigantic
gray
-
mantled
figures
.
<EOS>
They
were
soon
surveyed
and
passed
by
with
the
remark
that
they
would
be
good
ghosts
on
a
starlit
night
.
<EOS>
But
a
soft
sunlight
was
on
them
now
,
and
Gwendolen
felt
daring
.
<EOS>
The
stones
were
near
a
fine
grove
of
beeches
,
where
the
archers
found
plenty
of
marks
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
far
are
we
from
Green
Arbor
now
?
"
said
Gwendolen
,
having
got
in
front
by
the
side
of
the
warden
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
not
more
than
half
a
mile
,
taking
along
the
avenue
we
're
going
to
cross
up
there
:
<EOS>
but
I
shall
take
round
a
Couple
of
miles
,
by
the
High
Cross
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
falling
back
among
the
rest
,
when
suddenly
they
seemed
all
to
be
hurrying
obliquely
forward
under
the
guidance
of
Mr.
Lush
,
and
lingering
a
little
where
she
was
,
she
perceived
her
opportunity
of
slipping
away
.
<EOS>
Soon
she
was
out
of
sight
,
and
without
running
she
seemed
to
herself
to
fly
along
the
ground
and
count
the
moments
nothing
till
she
found
herself
back
again
at
the
Whispering
Stones
.
<EOS>
They
turned
their
blank
gray
sides
to
her
:
what
was
there
on
the
other
side
?
<EOS>
If
there
were
nothing
after
all
?
<EOS>
That
was
her
only
dread
now
 
to
have
to
turn
back
again
in
mystification
;
and
walking
round
the
right
-
hand
stone
without
pause
,
she
found
herself
in
front
of
some
one
whose
large
dark
eyes
met
hers
at
a
foot
's
distance
.
<EOS>
In
spite
of
expectation
,
she
was
startled
and
shrank
bank
,
but
in
doing
so
she
could
take
in
the
whole
figure
of
this
stranger
and
perceive
that
she
was
unmistakably
a
lady
,
and
one
who
must
have
been
exceedingly
handsome
.
<EOS>
She
perceived
,
also
,
that
a
few
yards
from
her
were
two
children
seated
on
the
grass
.
  
<EOS>
"
Miss
Harleth
?
"
said
the
lady
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
.
<EOS>
"
All
Gwendolen
's
consciousness
was
wonder
.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
accepted
Mr.
Grandcourt
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
promised
to
tell
you
something
.
<EOS>
And
you
will
promise
to
keep
my
secret
.
<EOS>
However
you
may
decide
you
will
not
tell
Mr.
Grandcourt
,
or
any
one
else
,
that
you
have
seen
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
promise
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Lydia
Glasher
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Grandcourt
ought
not
to
marry
any
one
but
me
.
<EOS>
I
left
my
husband
and
child
for
him
nine
years
ago
.
<EOS>
Those
two
children
are
his
,
and
we
have
two
others
 
girls
 
who
are
older
.
<EOS>
My
husband
is
dead
now
,
and
Mr.
Grandcourt
ought
to
marry
me
.
<EOS>
He
ought
to
make
that
boy
his
heir
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
looked
at
the
boy
as
she
spoke
,
and
Gwendolen
's
eyes
followed
hers
.
<EOS>
The
handsome
little
fellow
was
puffing
out
his
cheeks
in
trying
to
blow
a
tiny
trumpet
which
remained
dumb
.
<EOS>
His
hat
hung
backward
by
a
string
,
and
his
brown
curls
caught
the
sun
-
rays
.
<EOS>
He
was
a
cherub
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
women
's
eyes
met
again
,
and
Gwendolen
said
proudly
,
"
I
will
not
interfere
with
your
wishes
.
"
<EOS>
She
looked
as
if
she
were
shivering
,
and
her
lips
were
pale
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
are
very
attractive
,
Miss
Harleth
.
<EOS>
But
when
he
first
knew
me
,
I
too
was
young
.
<EOS>
Since
then
my
life
has
been
broken
up
and
embittered
.
<EOS>
It
is
not
fair
that
he
should
be
happy
and
I
miserable
,
and
my
boy
thrust
out
of
sight
for
another
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
These
words
were
uttered
with
a
biting
accent
,
but
with
a
determined
abstinence
from
anything
violent
in
tone
or
manner
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
watching
Mrs.
Glasher
's
face
while
she
spoke
,
felt
a
sort
of
terror
:
it
was
as
if
some

vision
had
come
to
her
in
a
dream
and
said
,
"
I
am
a
woman
's
life
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
anything
more
to
say
to
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
asked
in
a
low
tone
,
but
still
proud
and
coldly
.
<EOS>
The
revulsion
within
her
was
not
tending
to
soften
her
.
<EOS>
Everyone
seemed
hateful
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
.
<EOS>
You
know
what
I
wished
you
to
know
.
<EOS>
You
can
inquire
about
me
if
you
like
.
<EOS>
My
husband
was
Colonel
Glasher
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
go
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
moving
away
with
a
ceremonious
inclination
,
which
was
returned
with
equal
grace
.
  
<EOS>
In
a
few
minutes
Gwendolen
was
in
the
beech
grove
again
but
her
party
had
gone
out
of
sight
and
apparently
had
not
sent
in
search
of
her
,
for
all
was
solitude
till
she
had
reached
the
avenue
pointed

by
the
warden
.
<EOS>
She
determined
to
take
this
way
back
to
Green
Arbor
,
which
she

quickly
;
rapid

seeming
to

just
now
a

of
suspending
the
thoughts
which
might
prevent
her
from
behaving
with
due

.
<EOS>
She
had
already
made
up
her
mind
<EOS>
what
step
she
would
take
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
was
of
course
astonished
to
see
Gwendolen
returning
alone
,
and
was
not
without
some
uneasiness
which
the
presence
of
other
ladies
hindered
her
from

.
<EOS>
In

to
her
words
of
surprise
Gwendolen
<EOS>
said
    
"
Oh
,
I
have
been
rather
silly
.
<EOS>
I
lingered
behind
to
look
at
the
Whispering
Stones
,
and
the
rest
hurried
on
after
something
,
<EOS>
so

.
<EOS>
I
thought
it
best
to
come

by
the
short
way
 
the

that
the

had
told

of
.
<EOS>
I
'm
not
sorry
after
all
.
<EOS>
I
had
had

walking
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
party
did
not
meet
Mr.
Grandcourt
,
I

,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
with

,

.
<EOS>
"
And
we
did
n't
see
any
carvings
on
the

,

.
<EOS>
Where
can
he
be
?
<EOS>
I
should
think
he
has

into

pool

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
With
all
Gwendolen
's
resolve
not
to
betray
any

,
she
could
not
help
it
that
her
tone
was
unusually
high
and
hard
,
and
her
mother
felt
sure
that
something
unpropitious
had
happened
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
thought
that
the
self
-

young
lady
was
much

,
and
that
Mr.
Grandcourt
was
probably
seeing
reason
to
change

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
you
have
no

,
mamma
,
I

,
"
said
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
"
I
am
tired
.
<EOS>
And
every
one
will
be
going
soon
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
assented
;
but
by

was

as
,
ready
 
the

on

's

the

,

Grandcourt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
there

!
"

Lord
Brackenshaw
,

Gwendolen
,

was

's

.
<EOS>
"
We

Grandcourt

.
<EOS>
Lush

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
However
,

.
<EOS>
The

he

a
near

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
are

?
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
Lord

gave

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
we
are

,
"

,

,

Scotch
fashion
.
  
<EOS>
"
May
I
call
at
Offendene
to
-

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Oh
yes
,
if
you
like
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
sweeping

from

with
her

.
<EOS>
Her
voice
was
light
and
sharp
as
the
first
touch
of

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
accepted
his
arm
to
lead
her
to
the

;
but
while

was

,
Gwendolen
with
incredible

had
got
in
advance
of
them
,
and
had
sprung
into
the

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
got
in
,
mamma
,
because
I
wished
to
be
on
this
side
,
"
she
said
,
apologetically
.
<EOS>
But
she
had
avoided
Grandcourt
's
touch
:
he
only
lifted
his
hat
and
walked
away
 
with
the
not
unsatisfactory
impression
that
she
meant
to
show
herself
offended
by
his
neglect
.
  
<EOS>
The
mother
and
daughter
drove
for
five
minutes
in
silence
.
<EOS>
Then
Gwendolen
said
,
"
I
intend
to
join
the
Langens
at
Dover
,
mamma
.
<EOS>
I
shall
pack
up
immediately
on
getting
home
,
and
set
off
by
the
early
train
.
<EOS>
I
shall
be
at
Dover
almost
as
soon
as
they
are
;
we
can
let
them
know
by
telegraph
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Good
heavens
,
child
!
<EOS>
what
can
be
your
reason
for
saying
so
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My
reason
for
saying

,
mamma
,
is
that
I
mean
to
do

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
why
do
you
mean
to
do

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
wish
to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Is

because
you
are

with
Mr.
Grandcourt
's

in

-

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
enter
into
such

.
<EOS>
I
am
not
going
in
any
case
to

Mr.
Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
Do
n't
interest

further
about

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
can
I
say
to
your
uncle
,

?
<EOS>
Consider
the
position

place

in
.
<EOS>
You
led
him
to
believe
only
last
night
that
you

Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
am

you

,
mamma
,
dear
,
but
<EOS>
I
ca
n't
help
it
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
with
still
harder
resistance
in
her
tone
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Whatever
you
or
my
uncle
may
think
or
do
,
I
shall
not

,
and
I
shall

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't

what
comes

.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
care
if
I
never
marry
any

.
<EOS>
There
is
nothing
worth
caring
for
.
<EOS>
I
believe
all
men
are
bad
,
and
I
hate
them
.
<EOS>
"
  
"

"

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
She

<EOS>

<EOS>

not

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
had
certainly
hardened
in

:
her

's

little

,
which

not

the

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's

,

,

<EOS>
Is

?
<EOS>
It

_

<EOS>
Perspective

.
<EOS>
What

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
SIR
THOMAS
BROWNE
.
   
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
we
have
seen
,

,

.
<EOS>
We

,

,

.
  
<EOS>

not

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
's

were
of
the
intermittent
,
flickering

:
never

.
<EOS>
But
a
great

goes
on

strong

:

are
carefully

,

,
<EOS>
even

proposing

august

without
the

.
<EOS>
And
a
man
may

good
appearance
in
high

positions
 
may

,

.
<EOS>
Also
,

may

,
and
may

,

in
 
good

easily

mere

and

,
and
at

nothing

.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

Mr.

presumptive

.

.

Grandcourt
,

the

's
inclinations
concerning
Diplow
,
and
he
was
gratified
to

the

of
the

in

:

in
the
least
likely
that
he

,
his

of
power
would
have
been

by
his
being

.
<EOS>
The

had
told
for
something
among

which
had
made

ask
for
a
year
's

,

,

the

in
the

might
decide

not

with

of

;
 
a
man
who
has

,
in

of

the
hunting
is
less
good
,
naturally
desiring
a
third
where

is

.
<EOS>
Also
,

had
thrown

to

the

that

would
woo
and
win
Miss
Arrowpoint
,
and
in

case
ready
money

less
of

.
<EOS>
Hence

,

,

.

_

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It

knits

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

.

,

-

.
<EOS>
Old

"
  
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

a

.
<EOS>
(

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
Decidedly

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
This

was

;
nevertheless
it
had
passed

's

that

to

interest
this
girl
had
raised

,

.
<EOS>
But
his
history
had
given
him
a
stronger
bias
in
another

.
<EOS>
He
felt
himself
in
no
sense
free
.
        
<EOS>
Men
,
like
planets
,
have
both
a
visible
and
an
invisible
history
.
<EOS>
The
    
astronomer
threads
the
darkness
with
strict
deduction
,
accounting
so
    
for
every
visible
arc
in
the
wanderer
's
orbit
;
and
the
narrator
of
    
human
actions
,
if
he
did
his
work
with
the
same
completeness
,
would
    
have
to
thread
the
hidden
pathways
of
feeling
and
thought
which
lead
    
up
to
every
moment
of
action
,
and
to
those
moments
of
intense
    
suffering
which
take
the
quality
of
action
 
like
the
cry
of
    
Prometheus
,
whose
chained
anguish
seems
a
greater
energy
than
the
sea
    
and
sky
he
invokes
and
the
deity
he
defies
.
   
<EOS>
Deronda
's
circumstances
,
indeed
,
had
been
exceptional
.
<EOS>
One
moment
had
been
burned
into
his
life
as
its
chief
epoch
 
a
moment
full
of
July
sunshine
and
large
pink
roses
shedding
their
last
petals
on
a
grassy
court
enclosed
on
three

by
a

.
<EOS>
Imagine
him
in
such
a
scene
:
a
boy
of

,

on
the
grass
where
it
was
in
shadow
,
his

propped
on
his

over
a
book
,
while
his
tutor
,

,
sat

camp
-

under

.
<EOS>
Deronda
's
book
was
Sismondi
's
"
History
of
the
Italian
Republics
"
;
 
the
lad
had
a
passion
for
history
,
eager
to
know
how
time
had
been
filled
up
since
the
flood
,
and
how
things
were
carried
on
in
the

.
<EOS>
Suddenly
he
let
down
his
left
arm
and

his

,
saying
in
purest

"
<EOS>
Mr.
Fraser
,
how
was
it
that
the
popes
and
cardinals
always
had
so
many

?
"
  
<EOS>
The

,
an
able
young
Scotchman
,
who
acted

Sir
Hugo
Mallinger
's

,
roused

from
his

,
answered
with
the
clear
-
cut
emphatic
chant
which
makes
a
truth
doubly
telling
in
Scotch
utterance
    
<EOS>
"
Their
own
children
were
called
nephews
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
said
Deronda
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
was
just
for
the
propriety
of
the
thing
;
because
,
as
you
know
very
well
,
priests
do
n't
marry
,
and
the
children
were
illegitimate
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mr.
Fraser
,
thrusting
out
his
lower
lip
and
making
his
chant
of
the
last
word
the
more
emphatic
for
a
little
impatience
at
being

,
had
already
turned
his

on
his

again
,
while
Deronda
,
as

something
had
stung
him
,
started

in

with

to

tutor
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
always
called
Sir
Hugo
Mallinger
his
uncle
,
and
when

once

to
him
to

about
his
father
and
mother
,
the
baronet
had
answered
,
"
You
lost
your
father
and
mother
when
you
were
quite
a
little
one
;
that
is
why
I
take
care
of
you
.
"
<EOS>
Daniel
then
straining
to
discern
something
in
that
early
twilight
,
had
a
dim
sense
of
having
been
kissed
very
much
,
and
surrounded
by
thin
,

,

,
till
his
fingers
caught

something

,
which
hurt
him
,
and
he
began
to
cry
.
<EOS>
Every
other
memory
he
had
was
of
the
little
world
in
which

still
lived
.
<EOS>
And
at
that
time
he
did
not
mind
about
learning
more
,
for
he
was
too
fond
of
Sir
Hugo
to

for
the
loss
of
unknown
parents
.
<EOS>
Life
was
very
delightful
to
the
lad
,
with
an
uncle
who
was
always
indulgent
and
cheerful
 
a
fine
man
in
the
bright
noon

life
,
whom

thought

perfect
,
and
whose

was
one

,

a

,

.
<EOS>
Diplow
lay
in
another

,
and
was
a

landless
place
which
had
come
into
the
family
from
a
rich
lawyer
on
the
female

who

of

;
whereas

had

,
and

had

,

,

.
<EOS>
Two

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
This

had

,

,

that

Grandcourt

In

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

the

,

;

<EOS>
Still

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
A

happy
<EOS>
careless

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
The

but

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

never

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Some

<EOS>
Daniel

,

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
The

about

who

wrong
 
<EOS>
yes
,
a

:
<EOS>
and

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Those

.
<EOS>
The

for

,

.
<EOS>
The

of

between

,

"

<EOS>
The

past

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
One

<EOS>
Daniel

not

<EOS>
Since

,

<EOS>
One

"
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>
Every

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
"

;

!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
But

turned

,
left

,
and

broad
window
-

,
which

.
<EOS>
Here

.
<EOS>
This

had

.
<EOS>
And

had

.
<EOS>
He
knew

what

,
and
without

himself
 
<EOS>
for
he
was
a
boy
of

perceptions
and
easily

own

in
that
of
Robert
Bruce
 
<EOS>
he
had
never

,
or

a
very

uncle

.
<EOS>
It

(

)

,

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

's

altogether
in

:

was
one
in
which

not
<EOS>
_
ennui
_

,

,
aptitudes
;

had

uncle

father

a

,
and

.
<EOS>
He

,
who
to

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
That

have

,

an

.
<EOS>
Would
it
ever
be
mentioned
to

?
<EOS>
Would
the
time
come
when
his
uncle
would
tell

everything
?
<EOS>
He

Sir

That

.

.

.
<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
Things

,

<EOS>
Daniel

<EOS>
Every

<EOS>

<EOS>
Sir

that

Miss
Raymond
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

love
 
and
much

to

usual

<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
No

.
<EOS>
But

;

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
And
,

,

Mallinger

<EOS>
He

,

;

<EOS>
The

,

,

met

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>
By

,

charming

,

,

,

;

the

.
<EOS>
Daniel
no
longer
held
a
wavering
opinion
about
his
own
birth
.
<EOS>
His

had

,

,

The

the

<EOS>

,
having
the
growing
fascination
inherent
in
all
thinking
which
demands
intensity
,
was
making
him
a
more
exclusive
worker
than
he
had
been
before
.
  
<EOS>
But
here
came
the
old
check
which
had
been
growing
with
his
growth
.
<EOS>
He
found
the
inward
bent
toward
comprehension
and
thoroughness
diverging
more
and
more
from
the
track
marked
out
by
the
standards
of
examination
:
he
felt
a
heightening
discontent
with
the
wearing
futility
and
enfeebling
strain
of
a
demand
for
excessive
retention
and
dexterity
without
any
insight
into
the
principles
which
form
the
vital
connections
of
knowledge
.
<EOS>
(
Deronda
's
undergraduateship
occurred
fifteen
years
ago
,
when
the
perfection
of
our
university
methods
was
not
yet
indisputable
.
)
<EOS>
In
hours
when
his
dissatisfaction
was
strong
upon
him
he
reproached
himself
for
having
been
attracted
by
the
conventional
advantage
of
belonging
to
an
English
university
,
and
was
tempted
toward
the
project
of
asking
Sir
Hugo
to
let
him
quit
Cambridge
and
pursue
a
more
independent
line
of
study
abroad
.
<EOS>
The
germs
of
this
inclination
had
been
already
stirring
in
his
boyish
love
of
universal
history
,
which
made
him
want
to
be
at
home
in
foreign
countries
,
and
follow
in
imagination
the
traveling
students
of
the
middle
ages
.
<EOS>
He
longed
now
to
have
the
sort
of
apprenticeship
to
life
which
would
not
shape
him
too
definitely
,
and
rob
him
of
the
choice
that
might
come
from
a
free
growth
.
<EOS>
One
sees
that
Deronda
's
demerits
were
likely
to
be
on
the
side
of
reflective
hesitation
,
and
this
tendency
was
encouraged
by
his
position
;
there
was
no
need
for
him
to
get
an
immediate
income
,
or
to
fit
himself
in
haste
for
a
profession
;
and
his
sensibility
to
the
half
-
known
facts
of
his
parentage
made
him
an
excuse
for
lingering
longer
than
others
in
a
state
of
social
neutrality
.
<EOS>
Other
men
,
he
inwardly
said
,
had
a
more
definite
place
and
duties
.
<EOS>
But
the
project
which
flattered
his
inclination
might
not
have
gone
beyond
the
stage
of
ineffective
brooding
,
if
certain
circumstances
had
not
quickened
it
into
action
.
  
<EOS>
The
circumstances
arose
out
of
an
enthusiastic
friendship
which
extended
into
his
after
-
life
.
<EOS>
Of
the
same
year
with
himself
,
and
occupying
small
rooms
close
to
his
,
was
a
youth
who
had
come
as
an
exhibitioner
from
Christ
's
Hospital
,
and
had
eccentricities
enough
for
a
Charles
Lamb
.
<EOS>
Only
to
look
at
his
pinched
features
and
blonde
hair
hanging
over
his
collar
reminded
one
of
pale
quaint
heads
by
early
German
painters
;
and
when
this
faint
coloring
was
lit
up
by
a
joke
,
there
came
sudden
creases
about
the
mouth
and
eyes
which
might
have
been
moulded
by
the
soul
of
an
aged
humorist
.
<EOS>
His
father
,
an
engraver
of
some
distinction
,
had
been
dead
eleven
years
,
and
his
mother
had
three
girls
to
educate
and
maintain
on
a
meagre
annuity
.
<EOS>
Hans
Meyrick
 
he
had
been
daringly
christened
after
Holbein
 
felt
himself
the
pillar
,
or
rather
the
knotted
and
twisted
trunk
,
round
which
these
feeble
climbing
plants
must
cling
.
<EOS>
There
was
no
want
of
ability
or
of
honest
well
-
meaning
affection
to
make
the
prop
trustworthy
:
<EOS>
the
ease
and
quickness
with
which
he
studied
might
serve
him
to
win
prizes
at
Cambridge
,
as
he
had
done
among
the
Blue
Coats
,
in
spite
of
irregularities
.
<EOS>
The
only
danger
was
,
that
the
incalculable
tendencies
in
him
might
be
fatally
timed
,
and
that
his
good
intentions
might
be
frustrated
by
some
act
which
was
not
due
to
habit
but
to
capricious
,
scattered
impulses
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
be
said
to
have
any
one
bad
habit
;
yet
at
longer
or
shorter
intervals
he
had
fits
of
impish
recklessness
,
and
did
things
that
would
have
made
the
worst
habits
.
  
<EOS>
Hans
in
his
right
mind
,
however
,
was
a
lovable
creature
,
and
in
Deronda
he
had
happened
to
find
a
friend
who
was
likely
to
stand
by
him
with
the
more
constancy
,
from
compassion
for
these
brief
aberrations
that
might
bring
a
long
repentance
.
<EOS>
Hans
,
indeed
,
shared
Deronda
's
rooms
nearly
as
much
as
he
used
his
own
:
to
Deronda
he
poured
himself
out
on
his
studies
,
his
affairs
,
his
hopes
;
the
poverty
of
his
home
,
and
his
love
for
the
creatures
there
;
the
itching
of
his
fingers
to
draw
,
and
his
determination
to
fight
it
away
for
the
sake
of
getting
some
sort
of
a
plum
that
he
might
divide
with
his
mother
and
the
girls
.
<EOS>
He
wanted
no
confidence
in
return
,
but
seemed
to
take
Deronda
as
an
Olympian
who
needed
nothing
 
an
egotism
in
friendship
which
is
common
enough
with
mercurial
,
expansive
natures
.
<EOS>
Deronda
was
content
,
and
gave
Meyrick
all
the
interest
he
claimed
,
getting
at
last
a
brotherly
anxiety
about
him
,
looking
after
him
in
his
erratic
moments
,
and
contriving
by
adroitly
delicate
devices
not
only
to
make
up
for
his
friend
's
lack
of
pence
,
but
to
save
him
from
threatening
chances
.
<EOS>
Such
friendship
easily
becomes
tender
:
the
one
spreads
strong
sheltering
wings
that
delight
in
spreading
,
the
other
gets
the
warm
protection
which
is
also
a
delight
.
<EOS>
Meyrick
was
going
in
for
a
classical
scholarship
,
and
his
success
,
in
various
ways
momentous
,
was
the
more
probable
from
the
steadying
influence
of
Deronda
's
friendship
.
  
<EOS>
But
an
imprudence
of
Meyrick
's
,
committed
at
the
beginning
of
the
autumn
term
,
threatened
to
disappoint
his
hopes
.
<EOS>
With
his
usual
alternation
between
unnecessary
expense
and
self
-
privation
,
he
had
given
too
much
money
for
an
old
engraving
which
fascinated
him
,
and
to
make
up
for
it
,
had
come
from
London
in
a
third
-
class
carriage
with
his
eyes
exposed
to
a
bitter
wind
and
any
irritating
particles
the
wind
might
drive
before
it
.
<EOS>
The
consequence
was
a
severe
inflammation
of
the
eyes
,
which
for
some
time
hung
over
him
the
threat
of
a
lasting
injury
.
<EOS>
This
crushing
trouble
called
out
all
Deronda
's
readiness
to
devote
himself
,
and
he
made
every
other
occupation
secondary
to
that
of
being
companion
and
eyes
to
Hans
,
working
with
him
and
for
him
at
his
classics
,
that
if
possible
his
chance
of
the
classical
scholarship
might
be
saved
.
<EOS>
Hans
,
to
keep
the
knowledge
of
his
suffering
from
his
mother
and
sisters
,
alleged
his
work
as
a
reason
for
passing
the
Christmas
at
Cambridge
,
and
his
friend
stayed
up
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Deronda
relaxed
his
hold
on
his
mathematics
,
and
Hans
,
reflecting
on
this
,
at
length
said
:
"
<EOS>
Old
fellow
,
while
you
are
hoisting
me
you
are
risking
yourself
.
<EOS>
With
your
mathematical
cram
one
may
be
like
Moses
or
Mahomet
or
somebody
of
that
sort
who
had
to
cram
,
and
forgot
in
one
day
what
it
had
taken
him
forty
to
learn
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
would
not
admit
that
he
cared
about
the
risk
,
and
he
had
really
been
beguiled
into
a
little
indifference
by
double
sympathy
:
he
was
very
anxious
that
Hans
should
not
miss
the
much
-
needed
scholarship
,
and
he
felt
a
revival
of
interest
in
the
old
studies
.
<EOS>
Still
,
when
Hans
,
rather
late
in
the
day
,
got
able
to
use
his
own
eyes
,
Deronda
had
tenacity
enough
to
try
hard
and
recover
his
lost
ground
.
<EOS>
He
failed
,
however
;
but
he
had
the
satisfaction
of
seeing
Meyrick
win
.
  
<EOS>
Success
,
as
a
sort
of
beginning
that
urged
completion
,
might
have
reconciled
Deronda
to
his
university
course
;
but
the
emptiness
of
all
things
,
from
politics
to
pastimes
,
is
never
so
striking
to
us
as
when
we
fail
in
them
.
<EOS>
The
loss
of
the
personal
triumph
had
no
severity
for
him
,
but
the
sense
of
having
spent
his
time
ineffectively
in
a
mode
of
working
which
had
been
against
the
grain
,
gave
him
a
distaste
for
any
renewal
of
the
process
,
which
turned
his
imagined
project
of
quitting
Cambridge
into
a
serious
intention
.
<EOS>
In
speaking
of
his
intention
to
Meyrick
he
made
it
appear
that
he
was
glad
of
the
turn
events
had
taken
 
glad
to
have
the
balance
dip
decidedly
,
and
feel
freed
from
his
hesitations
;
but
he
observed
that
he
must
of
course
submit
to
any
strong
objection
on
the
part
of
Sir
Hugo
.
  
<EOS>
Meyrick
's
joy
and
gratitude
were
disturbed
by
much
uneasiness
.
<EOS>
He
believed
in
Deronda
's
alleged
preference
,
but
he
felt
keenly
that
in
serving
him
Daniel
had
placed
himself
at
a
disadvantage
in
Sir
Hugo
's
opinion
,
and
he
said
mournfully
,
"
If
you
had
got
the
scholarship
,
Sir
Hugo
would
have
thought
that
you
asked
to
leave
us
with
a
better
grace
.
<EOS>
You
have
spoiled
your
luck
for
my
sake
,
and
I
can
do
nothing
to
amend
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
you
can
;
you
are
to
be
a
first
-
rate
fellow
.
<EOS>
I
call
that
a
first
-
rate
investment
of
my
luck
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
confound
it
!
<EOS>
You
save
an
ugly
mongrel
from
drowning
,
and
expect
him
to
cut
a
fine
figure
.
<EOS>
The
poets
have
made
tragedies
enough
about
signing
one
's
self
over
to
wickedness
for
the
sake
of
getting
something
plummy
;
I
shall
write
a
tragedy
of
a
fellow
who
signed
himself
over
to
be
good
,
and
was
uncomfortable
ever
after
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But
Hans
lost
no
time
in
secretly
writing
the
history
of
the
affair
to
Sir
Hugo
,
making
it
plain
that
but
for
Deronda
's
generous
devotion
he
could
hardly
have
failed
to
win
the
prize
he
had
been
working
for
.
  
<EOS>
The
two
friends
went
up
to
town
together
:
Meyrick
to
rejoice
with
his
mother
and
the
girls
in
their
little
home
at
Chelsea
;
Deronda
to
carry
out
the
less
easy
task
of
opening
his
mind
to
Sir
Hugo
.
<EOS>
He
relied
a
little
on
the
baronet
's
general
tolerance
of
eccentricities
,
but
he
expected
more
opposition
than
he
met
with
.
<EOS>
He
was
received
with
even
warmer
kindness
than
usual
,
the
failure
was
passed
over
lightly
,
and
when
he
detailed
his
reasons
for
wishing
to
quit
the
university
and
go
to
study
abroad
.
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
sat
for
some
time
in
a
silence
which
was
rather
meditative
than
surprised
.
<EOS>
At
last
he
said
,
looking
at
Daniel
with
examination
,
"
So
you
do
n't
want
to
be
an
Englishman
to
the
backbone
after
all
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
want
to
be
an
Englishman
,
but
I
want
to
understand
other
points
of
view
.
<EOS>
And
I
want
to
get
rid
of
a
merely
English
attitude
in
studies
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
see
;
you
do
n't
want
to
be
turned
out
in
the
same
mould
as
every
other
youngster
.
<EOS>
And
I
have
nothing
to
say
against
your
doffing
some
of
our
national
prejudices
.
<EOS>
I
feel
the
better
myself
for
having
spent
a
good
deal
of
my
time
abroad
.
<EOS>
But
,
for
God
's
sake
,
keep
an
English
cut
,
and
do
n't
become
indifferent
to
bad
tobacco
!
<EOS>
And
,
my
dear
boy
,
it
is
good
to
be
unselfish
and
generous
;
but
do
n't
carry
that
too
far
.
<EOS>
It
will
not
do
to
give
yourself
to
be
melted
down
for
the
benefit
of
the
tallow
-
trade
;
you
must
know
where
to
find
yourself
.
<EOS>
However
,
I
shall
put
no
vote
on
your
going
.
<EOS>
Wait
until
I
can
get
off
Committee
,
and
I
'll
run
over
with
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
So
Deronda
went
according
to
his
will
.
<EOS>
But
not
before
he
had
spent
some
hours
with
Hans
Meyrick
,
and
been
introduced
to
the
mother
and
sisters
in
the
Chelsea
home
.
<EOS>
The
shy
girls
watched
and
registered
every
look
of
their
brother
's
friend
,
declared
by
Hans
to
have
been
the
salvation
of
him
,
a
fellow
like
nobody
else
,
and
,
in
fine
,
a
brick
.
<EOS>
They
so
thoroughly
accepted
Deronda
as
an
ideal
,
that
when
he
was
gone
the
youngest
set
to
work
,
under
the
criticism
of
the
two
elder
girls
,
to
paint
him
as
Prince
Camaralzaman
.
            
<EOS>
"
This
is
truth
the
poet
sings
,
  
That
a
sorrow
's
crown
of
sorrow
is
remembering
happier
things
.
"
                                  
<EOS>
TENNYSON
:
_
Locksley
Hall
_
.
   
<EOS>
On
a
fine
evening
near
the
end
of
July
,
Deronda
was
rowing
himself
on
the
Thames
.
<EOS>
It
was
already
a
year
or
more
since
he
had
come
back
to
England
,
with
the
understanding
that
his
education
was
finished
,
and
that
he
was
somehow
to
take
his
place
in
English
society
;
but
though
,
in
deference
to
Sir
Hugo
's
wish
,
and
to
fence
off
idleness
,
he
had
began
to
read
law
,
this
apparent
decision
had
been
without
other
result
than
to
deepen
the
roots
of
indecision
.
<EOS>
His
old
love
of
boating
had
revived
with
the
more
force
now
that
he
was
in
town
with
the
Mallingers
,
because
he
could
nowhere
else
get
the
same
still
seclusion
which
the
river
gave
him
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
boat
of
his
own
at
Putney
,
and
whenever
Sir
Hugo
did
not
want
him
,
it
was
his
chief
holiday
to
row
till
past
sunset
and
come
in
again
with
the
stars
.
<EOS>
Not
that
he
was
in
a
sentimental
stage
;
but
he
was
in
another
sort
of
contemplative
mood
perhaps
more
common
in
the
young
men
of
our
day
 
that
of
questioning
whether
it
were
worth
while
to
take
part
in
the
battle
of
the
world
:
<EOS>
I
mean
,
of
course
,
the
young
men
in
whom
the
unproductive

of
questioning
is
sustained
by
three
or
five
per

,
on
capital
which
somebody
else
has

for
.
<EOS>
It
puzzled
Sir
Hugo
that
one
who
made
a

contrast
with
all
that
was
sickly
and

should

hampered

which
,
since

left
an

could

no

;
especially
as
Deronda
set
himself
against
authorship
 
a
vocation
which
is
understood
to
turn

into

.
  
<EOS>
Rowing
in
his
dark

,

,

,
he

only

traces
of
the
seraphic
boy
"
trailing

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Still
,

,
"

.
<EOS>
The

,

,
had

;

that

.
<EOS>
Look

:

are
not

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

,
between

hands
 
in

the
uniform

,

,

.
<EOS>
Not

any

:

but

to
raise

can

.
  
<EOS>
Such

here

;
in

,

,

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
In

,

,

.
<EOS>
His
own
face
in

glass

like
 
one

<EOS>
In

,

,

<EOS>
Several

,

<EOS>
Deronda

,

,

<EOS>
He

all

<EOS>
the

's

in

"
Otello
,
"

"
Nessun

<EOS>
Che

Nella

"
:
[

:

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

women
are

;

<EOS>

Deronda

<EOS>

;

.

He

;

<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
But

within

,

,

,
but

"
Do

.
<EOS>
You
are

.
<EOS>
Pray
,

me
.
<EOS>
Tell

.
"
  
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
His

now
was
toward
the

,
and
she

.
<EOS>
But

,
"

"
nella

.
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
It

,

?
<EOS>
"
she

,
hesitatingly
 
"
Nessun

.
<EOS>
"
The
mere

themselves
uttered
in
her
sweet

seemed
to
give

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

,
"

,
"

often
singing
them
.
<EOS>
But
I

.
<EOS>
Pray

.
<EOS>
And
that
wet

let

.
"
  
<EOS>

"
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
it

Her

.
<EOS>
He

<EOS>

caressingly
between
both
her
own
.
<EOS>
This
gentle
welcoming
warmth
was
penetrating
the
bewildered
one
:
she
hung
back
just
enough
to

the
four

in

,
whose
good

was
being
reflected
in
hers
,
not

any

,
but
in
that

change
which
tells
us
that
anxiety

passing

.
<EOS>
For

Deronda
,

,

to
Mrs.
Meyrick
,
said

more

sweet

than
he
had
heard
before
    
"
I
am

.
<EOS>
I
am

Jewess
.
<EOS>
You
might

was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

are

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
We

,

.
<EOS>
You

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

,
who

"
You

no
more

?
<EOS>
You

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
I
should
not

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

the

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Meyrick

,

poor

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name

Mirah
Lapidoth
.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

trouble
 
<EOS>
the

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
Deronda

.

"

?

.

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You

.
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda

.
    
<EOS>
MAIDENS
CHOOSING
.
      
<EOS>
"

"
 
<EOS>
STERNE
:
<EOS>
_
Sentimental
Journey
<EOS>
_
.
   
<EOS>
To
say
that
Deronda
was
romantic
would
be
to
misrepresent
him
;
but
under
his
calm
and
somewhat
self
-
repressed
exterior
there
was
a
fervor
which
made
him
easily
find
poetry
and
romance
among
the
events
of
every
-
day
life
.
<EOS>
And
perhaps
poetry
and
romance
are
as
plentiful
as
ever
in
the
world
except
for
those
phlegmatic
natures
who
I
suspect
<EOS>
would
in
any
age
have
regarded
them
as
a
dull
form
of
erroneous
thinking
.
<EOS>
They
exist
very
easily
in
the
same
room
with
the
microscope
and
even
in
railway

:
what
banishes
them
in
the
vacuum
in
gentlemen
and
lady
passengers
.
<EOS>
How
should
all
the
apparatus
of
heaven
and
earth
,
from
the
farthest

to
the
tender

of
the
mother
who
nourished

,
make
poetry
for
a
mind
that
had
no
movements
of
awe
and
tenderness
,
no
sense
of
fellowship
which
thrills
from
the
near
to
the
distant
,
and
back
again
from
the
distant
to
the
near
?
  
<EOS>
To
Deronda
this
event
of
finding
Mirah
was
as
heart
-

as
anything
that
befell
Orestes
or
Rinaldo
.
<EOS>
He
sat
up
half
the
night
,
living
again
through
the
moments
since
he
had
first
discerned
Mirah
on
the
river
-
brink
,
with
the
fresh
and
fresh
vividness
which
belongs
to
emotive
memory
.
<EOS>
When
he
took
up
a
book
to
try
and
dull
this
urgency
of
inward
vision
,
the
printed
words
were
no
more
than
a
network
through
which
he
saw
and
heard
everything
as
clearly
as
before
 
saw
not
only
the
actual
events
of
two
hours
,
but
possibilities
of
what
had
been
and
what
might
be
which
those
events
were
enough
to
feed
with
the
warm
blood
of
passionate
hope
and
fear
.
<EOS>
Something
in
his
own
experience
caused
Mirah
's
search
after
her
mother
to
lay
hold
with
peculiar
force
on
his
imagination
.
<EOS>
The
first
prompting
of
sympathy
was
to
aid
her
in
her
search
:
if
given
persons
were
extant
in
London
there
were
ways
of
finding
them
,
as
subtle
as
scientific
experiment
,
the
right
machinery
being
set
at
work
.
<EOS>
But
here
the
mixed
feelings
which
belonged
to
Deronda
's
kindred
experience
naturally
transfused
themselves
into
his
anxiety
on
behalf
of
Mirah
.
  
<EOS>
The
desire
to
know
his
own
mother
,
or
to
know
about
her
,
was
constantly
haunted
with
dread
;
and
in

might

it
quickly
occurred

that
finding

mother
and
brother
from
whom

had
been

was

might

.
<EOS>
When
she
was
in
the
boat
she
said
that
her
mother
and
brother
were
good
;
but
the
goodness
might
have
been
chiefly
in

own

and

,
and
the
ten

since

had
been

enough

much

.
<EOS>
Spite
of
his
strong

to
side
with
the
objects
of

,
and
in
general
with
those
who
got
the
worst
of
it
,
his
interest
had
never
been

existing

,
and
the
facts
he

about

,
whether

walked

in

or

-

,
were
chiefly

a

.
<EOS>
Of
learned
and
accomplished
Jews
<EOS>
he
took
it
for
granted
that
they
had
dropped
their
religion
,
and
wished
to
be
merged
in
the
people

their
native

.
<EOS>
Scorn
flung
at
a
Jew
as
such
would
have
roused
all
his
sympathy
in
griefs
of
inheritance
;
but
<EOS>
the
indiscriminate
scorn
of
a
race
will
often
strike
a
specimen
who
has
well
earned
it
on
his
own

,
and
might
fairly
be

as
a
rascally
son
of
Adam
.
<EOS>
It
appears
that
the
Caribs
,
who
know

,
regard

as
a
practice
peculiarly
connected
with
Christian

,
and
probably

could
allege
experimental

for
this

.
<EOS>
Deronda
could
not
escape
(
who
can
?
)
<EOS>
knowing
ugly
stories
of
Jewish
characteristics
and
occupations
;
and
though
one
of
his
favorite

was
against
the
severance

past
and
present
history
,
he
was
like
others
who
shared

,
in
never

about
actual

that

retained

virtues
and

a
long

.
<EOS>
But

that
Mirah
's
longing

to
a
closer

,
very
disagreeable
images
urged
themselves
of
what

to
find

this
middle

and

.
<EOS>
To

,

the

herself
to

her

,
but
 
he
must
wait

know

:
perhaps
through
Mrs.
Meyrick
he
might

some

from
Mirah
's
own

.
<EOS>
Her
voice
,
her

,
her
looks
 
all
the
sweet

that
clothed
her
as
with
a
consecrating

made

the
more
from
giving
her
,
either
ideally
or

,
an
association
with
what
was
hateful
or

.
<EOS>
But
these
fine
words
with
which
we
fumigate
and
becloud
unpleasant
facts
are
not
the
language
in
which
we
think
.
<EOS>
Deronda
's
thinking
went
on
in
rapid
images
of
what
might
be
:
he
saw
himself
guided
by
some
official

into

;

through

,

saw

,
rough

,

,

a

girl
's

;
or

some

only
the
more
hideous
for

smarter
,
he
found
himself
under
the
breath
of
a
young
Jew
talkative
and
familiar
,
willing
to
show
his
acquaintance
with
gentlemen
's
tastes
,
and
not
fastidious
in
any
transactions
with
which
they
would
favor
him
 
and
so
on
through
the
brief
chapter
of
his
experience
in
this
kind
.
<EOS>
Excuse
him
:
<EOS>
his
mind
was
not
apt
to
run
spontaneously
into
insulting
ideas
,
or
to
practice
a
form
of
wit
which
identifies
Moses
with
the
advertisement
sheet
;
but
he
was
just
now
governed
by
dread
,
and
if
Mirah
's
parents
had
been
Christian
,
the
chief
difference
would
have
been
that
his
forebodings
would
have
been
fed
with
wider
knowledge
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
habit
of
his
mind
to
connect
dread
with
unknown
parentage
,
and
in
this
case
as
well
as
his
own
there
was
enough
to
make
the
connection
reasonable
.
  
<EOS>
But
what
was
to
be
done
with
Mirah
?
<EOS>
She
needed
shelter
and
protection
in
the
fullest
sense
,
and
all
his
chivalrous
sentiment
roused
itself
to
insist
that
the
sooner
and
the
more
fully

could
engage
for
her
the
interest

others

,
the
better
he
should

.
<EOS>
He
had
no
right
to
provide
for
her
entirely
,
though
he
might
be
able
to
do
so
;
the
very
depth

impression
she
had
produced
made

desire
that

should

to
be
entirely
independent
of
him
;
and
vague

of
the
future
which
he
tried
to
dispel
as
fantastic
left
their
influence
in
an
anxiety
stronger
than
any
motive
he
could
give
for
it
,
that
those
who
saw
his
actions
closely
should
be
acquainted
from
the
first
with
the
history
of
his
relation
to
Mirah
.
<EOS>
He
had
learned
to
hate
secrecy
about
the
grand

and

of
his
life
 
to
hate
it
the
more
because
a
strong

of
interwoven
sensibilities
hindered
him
from
breaking
such
secrecy
.
<EOS>
Deronda
had
made
a
vow
to
himself
that
 
since
the
truths
which
disgrace
mortals
are
not
all
of
their
own
making
 
<EOS>
the
truth
should
never
be
made
a
disgrace
to
another
by
his
act
.
<EOS>
He
was
not
without
terror
lest
he
should
break
this
vow
,
and
fall
into
the
apologetic
philosophy
which
explains
the
world
into
containing
nothing
better
than
one
's
own
conduct
.
  
<EOS>
At
one
moment
he
resolved
to
tell
the
whole
of
his
adventure
to
Sir
Hugo
and
Lady
Mallinger
the
next
morning
at

,
but
the
possibility
that
something
quite
new
might
reveal
itself
on
his
next
visit
to
Mrs.
Meyrick
's
checked
this

,
and
he
finally
went
to
sleep
on
the
conclusion
that
he
would
wait
until
that
visit
had
been
made
.
        
<EOS>
"
It
will
hardly
be
denied
that
even
in
this
frail
and
corrupted
world
,
    
we
sometimes
meet

who
,
in

very

and

,
as
well
    
as
in
the
whole

,
manifest
such

signature
and
stamp
of

,
as
to
make
our
judgment
of
them
a
matter

rather
    
than
the
result
of
continued
 
examination
.
"
 
<EOS>
ALEXANDER
KNOX
:
quoted
in
    
Southey
's
Life
of
Wesley
.
   
<EOS>
Mirah
said
that
she
had
slept
well
that
night
;
and
when
she
came
down
in
Mab
's
black
dress
,
her
dark
hair
curling
in
fresh
fibrils
as
it
gradually
dried
from
its
plenteous
bath
,
she
looked
like
one
who
was
beginning
to
take
comfort
after
the
long
sorrow
and
watching
which
had
paled
her
cheek
and
made
blue
semicircles
under
her

.
<EOS>
It
was
Mab
who
carried
her
breakfast
and
ushered
her
down
 
with
some
pride
in
the
effect
produced
by
a
pair
of
tiny
felt
slippers
which
she
had
rushed
out
to
buy
because
there
were
no

in

,

that
,

,

.
<EOS>
The

were

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

you

,

?
"
<EOS>

;

Budoor
 
"
two

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
Kate

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
The

;

witnesses

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

I

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

but

still
acted
from
time
to
time
.
<EOS>
Rebellious
feelings
grew
stronger
in
me
,
and
I
wished
to

away
from
this
life
;
but
I
could
not

where
to
go
,
and
I
dreaded

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
I
felt
it
would

wrong
to
leave
my
father
:
I
dreaded

,
for

thought

might
get
wicked

hateful
to

,

many

.
<EOS>
For

,

I

my

;
and
if
I
got

I
should

my

of
happy
thoughts
where
my
mother
lived
with

.
<EOS>
That
was
my
childish
notion
all

those
years
.
<EOS>
Oh
how
long
they
were
!
"
  
<EOS>
Mirah
fell
to
musing
again
.
  
<EOS>
"
Had
you
no
teaching
about
what

?
"
said

Meyrick
.
<EOS>
She

"
religion
"
 
finding

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
 
only

<EOS>
He

religion
at

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
One

,

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

mother
<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

:
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
Our

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
One

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
it

,

.

"

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

:

<EOS>

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Now

<EOS>
I

less

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

:

<EOS>

.

.

"

with

.
<EOS>
I
now
began
to
feel
a
horrible
dread
of
this
man
,
for
he
worried
me
with
his
attentions
,
his
eyes
were
always
on
me
:
I
felt
sure
that
whatever
else
there
might
be
in
his
mind
toward
me
,
below
it
all
there
was
scorn
for
the
Jewess
and
the
actress
.
<EOS>
And
when
he
came
to
me
the
next
day
in
the
theatre
and
would
put
my
shawl
around
me
,
a
terror
took
hold
of
me
;
I
saw
that
my
father
wanted
me
to
look
pleased
.
<EOS>
The
Count
was
neither
very
young
nor
very
old
;
his
hair
and
eyes
were
pale
;
he
was
tall
and
walked
heavily
,
and
his
face
was
heavy
and
grave
except
when
he
looked
at
me
.
<EOS>
He
smiled
at
me
,
and
his
smile
went
through
me
with
horror
:
<EOS>
I
could
not
tell
why
he
was
so
much
worse
to
me
than
other
men
.
<EOS>
Some
feelings
are
like
our
hearing
:
they
come
as

,
before

know

reason
.
<EOS>
My
father
talked
to
me
about
him
when

alone
,
and
praised
him
 
said
what
a
good
friend
he
had
been
.
<EOS>
I
said
nothing
,
because
I
supposed
he
had
got
my
father
out
of
prison
.
<EOS>
When
the
Count
came
again
,
my
father
left
the
room
.
<EOS>
He
asked
me
if
I
liked
being
on
the
stage
.
<EOS>
I
said
No
,
I
only
acted
in

father
.
<EOS>
He
always
spoke
French
,
and

"
petite

"

,

I
felt
insulting
.
<EOS>
I
knew

meant
to

,
and
I
had
it
firmly
in

that
a
nobleman

who
was
not

could
have
no

that
was

half

.
<EOS>
But

;
he

to
visit

his

,
where
I
might
be

of

.
<EOS>
It
was

to

,
I

anger
:
I
could
only

,
"
I

on
the

forever
,
"
<EOS>
and
I

.
<EOS>
Hurrying

room
I
saw
my
father

.
<EOS>
My

was
crushed
.
<EOS>
I
went
past

and

up
.
<EOS>
It
had
sunk
into

that
my
father
was
in

that
man

.
<EOS>
But

day

:
he

I
had
mistaken

,

:

and

.
<EOS>
So

acting
,
and

the
Count

.
<EOS>
My

changed

,
and

.
<EOS>
He

,
and

,
I
could
never

<EOS>
I

<EOS>
I

,
and
not

.
<EOS>
He

,
"
What

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You
have
had

ought

.
<EOS>
"
I
could
not

:

.
<EOS>
I
felt
for

first

should

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
My

<EOS>
his

<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
It

;

.
<EOS>
I

seen
what
despised

were
:
and

turned
against

father
,
for

saw

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
Through

.
<EOS>
I
do

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
My

chose

<EOS>
he

<EOS>
and

.
<EOS>
I

.

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
I

Some

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Then

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
When

,

.
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
At

.
<EOS>

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
People

.
<EOS>
None

.
<EOS>
I

,

<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
He

"
Stop
,

!
<EOS>
young

;

"
<EOS>
meaning

,

.
<EOS>

;

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>

very

,

?
<EOS>
for

I

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.

It

delirious

<EOS>
:

,

;

.
<EOS>
All

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
People

.
<EOS>
Many

,

;

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
How

I
live
?
<EOS>
And

that

,

the

.
<EOS>
I

,
that
I
might

.
<EOS>
The

<EOS>
I
do
n't
know
where
 
<EOS>
and

was
late

.
<EOS>
I

some

,

.
<EOS>
Sleep
must

,

.
<EOS>
The

,

,

<EOS>

oh
,

!
<EOS>
I

and

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
The

seemed

.
<EOS>
My

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

a

to
go

.
<EOS>
And

was

.
<EOS>
I
was
lost
again
,
and
I

lest
any

and

.
<EOS>
I
had
a
terror
of
the
world
.
<EOS>
None
knew
me
;
all
would
mistake
me
.
<EOS>
I
had
seen
so
many
in
my
life
who
made
themselves
glad
with
scorning
,
and
laughed
at
another
's
shame
.
<EOS>
What
could
I
do
?
<EOS>
This
life
seemed
to
be
closing
in
upon
me
with
a
wall
of
fire
 
everywhere
there
was
scorching
that
made
me
shrink
.
<EOS>
The
high
sunlight
made
me
shrink
.
<EOS>
And
I
began
to
think
that
my
despair
was
the
voice
of
God
telling
me
to
die
.
<EOS>
But
it
would
take
me
long
to
die

.
<EOS>
Then
I
thought
of
my
people
,
how

had
been
driven
from
land
to

and
been
afflicted
,
and
multitudes
had
died
of
misery
in

wandering
 
<EOS>
was
I
the
first
?
<EOS>
And

and

when
Christians
were
cruelest
,

fathers
had
sometimes

afterward
themselves
<EOS>
:
it
was
to

.
<EOS>
That

;

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

a

bear

I

bear
 
else
<EOS>
where
was

?
<EOS>

I

,
"
I

.
"
<EOS>
But

;

.
<EOS>

,

than

life

.
<EOS>
The

that

.
<EOS>
The

,
<EOS>
till

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
for

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

;

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

had

;

;

.
<EOS>
Deronda
felt

.
<EOS>
For
Mirah
was
not
childlike
from

:
her

of

.
<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
But

he

brief
with

of

how

,

might

pleased

.
<EOS>
For

,

,

,
and

.
<EOS>
And

woman
,

to

.
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
He
gave
himself
several
good
reasons
;
but
whatever
one
does
with
a
strong
unhesitating
outflow
of
will
has
a
store
of
motive
that
it
would
be
hard
to
put
into
words
.
<EOS>
Some
deeds
seem
little
more
than
interjections
which
give
vent
to
the
long
passion
of
a
life
.
  
<EOS>
So
Deronda
soon
took
his
farewell
for
the
two
months
during
which
he
expected
to
be
absent
from
London
,
and
in
a

days
he
was
on
his

with
Sir
Hugo
and
Lady
Mallinger
to
Leubronn
.
  
<EOS>
He
had
fulfilled
his
intention
of
telling
them
about
Mirah
.
<EOS>
The
baronet
was
decidedly
of
opinion
that
the
search
for
the
mother
and
brother
had
better
be
let
alone
.
<EOS>
Lady
Mallinger
was
much
interested
in
the
poor
girl
,
observing
that
there
was
a

for
the
conversion
of
the

,
and
that

was
to

hoped
Mirah
would
embrace

;
but
perceiving

,
she
concluded
that
she
had
said
something
foolish
.
<EOS>
Lady
Mallinger
felt
apologetically
about
herself
as
a
woman
who
had
produced
nothing
but
daughters
in
a
case
where
sons
were
required
,
and
hence
regarded
the
apparent
contradictions
of
the
world
as
probably
due
to
the

of
her
own

.
<EOS>
But
when
she
was
much
puzzled
,
it
was
her
habit
to
say

,
"
I
will
ask
Daniel
.
<EOS>
"
Deronda
was
altogether
a
convenience
in
the
family
;
and
Sir
Hugo
too
,
after
intending
to
do

best
for
him
,
had

to
feel
that
the
pleasantest
result
would
be
to
have
this
substitute
for
a
son
always
ready

.
  
<EOS>
This
was
the
history
of
Deronda
,
so
far
as
he
knew
it
,
up
to
the
time
of
that
visit
to
Leubronn
in
which
he
saw
Gwendolen
Harleth
at
the
gaming
-
table
.
        
<EOS>
It
is
a
common
sentence
that
Knowledge
is
power
;
but
who
hath
duly
    
Considered
or
set
forth
the
power
of
Ignorance
?
<EOS>
Knowledge
slowly
    
builds
up
what
Ignorance
in
an
hour
pulls
down
.
<EOS>
Knowledge
,
through
    
patient
and
frugal
centuries
,
enlarges
discovery
and
makes
record
of
    
it
;
Ignorance
,
wanting
its
day
's
dinner
,
lights
a
fire
with
the
    
record
,
and
gives
a
flavor
to

<EOS>
I
and
the
girls
are
going
to
work
a

Ladies

,
and
a

that

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
went
into
these
details
timidly
:
but
how
else
was

to
bring
the
fact

their
position
home
to
this
poor

who
,
alas
!
<EOS>
must
submit
at
present
,
whatever

?
<EOS>
and
she

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

Sawyer
's

,
"
Gwendolen
persisted
 
taken

(

)

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
<EOS>
But

till

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
If
I
had
known
,
I
could

the

I

:
and
for
want

,

.
<EOS>
I

nearly

,

,

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>
People

.

<EOS>
Among

"

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

"

,

"

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Ca

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.

.
<EOS>
There

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

something

!
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
What

,

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Davilow
was

,

,

.
<EOS>

;

.

,

"

.

"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
I

something
.
<EOS>
Never

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
The
dear
face
!
 
<EOS>
it
is
ten
years
older
in
these
three
weeks
.
<EOS>
Now
,
now
,
now
!
do
n't
cry
"
 
Gwendolen
,

's

,

.
"
<EOS>
But
mind
you
do
n't
contradict

or

in

.
<EOS>
I
must

.
<EOS>
I
can
not

or

.
<EOS>
My

.
<EOS>
And
I
think
"
 
here
her

took
an
edge
of
scorn
 
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
can
do
better
for
you
than

in
Sawyer
's
Cottage
.
"
  
<EOS>
In
uttering
this
last
sentence
Gwendolen
again
rose
,
and
went
to
a
desk
where
she
wrote
the
following
note
to
Klesmer
:
        
<EOS>
Miss
Harleth
presents
her
compliments
to
Herr
Klesmer
,
and
ventures
    
to
request
of
him
the
very
great
favor
that
he
will
call
upon
her
,
if
    
possible
,
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
Her
reason
for
presuming
so
far
on
his
kindness
    
is
of
a
very
serious
nature
.
<EOS>
Unfortunate
family
circumstances
have
    
obliged
her
to
take
a
course
in
which
she
can
only
turn
for
advice
to
    
the
great
knowledge
and
judgment
of
Herr
Klesmer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Pray
get
this
sent
to
Quetcham
at
once
,
mamma
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
as

.
<EOS>
"
The
man
must
be
told
to
wait
for
an
answer
.
<EOS>
Let
no
time
be
lost
.
"
  
<EOS>
For
the
moment
,
the
absorbing
purpose
was
to
get
the
letter
dispatched
;
but
when
she
had
been
assured
on
this
point
,
another
anxiety
arose
and
kept
her
in
a
state
of
uneasy
excitement
.
<EOS>
If
Klesmer
happened
not
to
be
at
Quetcham
,
what
could
she
do
next
?
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
belief
in
her
star
,
so
to
speak
,
had
had
some
bruises
.
<EOS>
Things
had
gone
against
her
.
<EOS>
A
splendid
marriage
which
presented
itself
within
reach
had
shown
a
hideous
flaw
.
<EOS>
The
chances
of
roulette
had
not
adjusted
themselves
to
her
claims
;
and
a
man
of
whom
she
knew
nothing
had
thrust
himself
between
her
and
her
intentions
.
<EOS>
The
conduct
of
those
uninteresting
people
who
managed
the
business
of
the
world
had
been
culpable
just
in
the
points
most
injurious
to
her
in
particular
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
Harleth
,
with
all
her
beauty
and
conscious
force
,
felt
the
close
threats
of
humiliation
:
for
the
first
time
the
conditions
of
this
world
seemed
to
her
like
a
hurrying
roaring
crowd
in
which
she
had
got
astray
,
no
more
cared
for
and
protected
than
a
myriad
of
other
girls
,
in
spite
of
its
being
a
peculiar
hardship
to
her
.
<EOS>
If
Klesmer
were
not
at
Quetcham
 
that
would
be
all
of
a
piece
with
the
rest
:
the
unwelcome
negative
urged
itself
as
a
probability
,
and
set
her
brain
working
at
desperate
alternatives
which
might
deliver
her
from
Sawyer
's
Cottage
or
the
ultimate
necessity
of
"
taking
a
situation
,
"
a
phrase
that
summed
up
for
her
the
disagreeables
most
wounding
to
her
pride
,
most
irksome
to
her
tastes
;
at
least
so
far
as
her
experience
enabled
her
to
imagine
disagreeables
.
  
<EOS>
Still
Klesmer
might
be
there
,
and
Gwendolen
thought
of
the
result
in
that
case
with
a
hopefulness
which
even
cast
a
satisfactory
light
over
her
peculiar
troubles
,
as
what
might

,
wind
-
like
rush
backward
and
forward
on
the
piano
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Bult
felt
this
buffoonery
rather
offensive
and
Polish
,
but
 
Miss
Arrowpoint
being
there
 
did
not
like
to
move
away
.
  
<EOS>
"
Herr
Klesmer
has
cosmopolitan
ideas
,
"
said
Miss
Arrowpoint
,
trying
to
make
the
best
of
the
situation
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
looks
forward
to
a
fusion
of
races
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
With
all
my
heart
,
"
said
Mr.
Bult
,
willing
to
be

.
<EOS>
"
I
was
sure
he
had
too
much
talent
to
be
a
mere
musician
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
sir
,
you
are
under
some
mistake
there
,
"
said
Klesmer
,
firing
up
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
No
man
has
too
much
talent
to
be
a
musician
.
<EOS>
Most
men
have
too
little
.
<EOS>
A
creative
artist
is
no
more
a
mere
musician
than
a
great
statesman
is
a
mere
politician
.
<EOS>
We
are
not

,

,
who

look

.
<EOS>
We
help
to
rule

and

as

as
any
other
public
men
.
<EOS>
We
count
ourselves
on
level

with
legislators
.
<EOS>
And
a
man
who
speaks
effectively
through
music
is
compelled
to
something
more
difficult
than
parliamentary
eloquence
.
"
  
<EOS>
With

Klesmer

.
  
<EOS>
Miss

colored
,
and

Bult

,

,
"
Your

does

small

of

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Herr
Klesmer

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
He
will

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,

"

,
none

because

shown

.
  
<EOS>
Catherine
,

airs
,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>

into

,

<EOS>

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

the

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Catherine
's

that

:
<EOS>
still
less

her

.
<EOS>

on
    
"
<EOS>
This

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

had

:
there

:

.
<EOS>

,

had

to

Klesmer
.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
's
state
of
mind
was
pitiable
.
<EOS>
Imagine
Jean
Jacques
,
after
his
essay
on
the

,

of

they

;
or

Just
,
after
fervidly

all

of

eminence
,

,
which
warranted

dullest

in

.
<EOS>
Something

same

of
"
Tasso
,
"
when
what
she
had

dead
Leonora
was
enacted
by
her
own
Catherine
.
<EOS>
It
is
hard
for
us
to
live
up
to

own

,
and
keep
pace
with
our
winged
words
,
while
we
are

and
are

to
heavy

.
<EOS>
Besides
,
it
has
long
been
understood
that
the
proprieties
of

are
not

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
naturally
wished
for
the
best
of
everything
.
<EOS>
She
not
only

to

herself
at

than

with

;

.
<EOS>
While

was

:

son
-

law

what

.
<EOS>
And

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

;
"

<EOS>

marry
a
gentleman
,
"
said
the
father
,
exerting
himself
.
  
<EOS>
"
And
a
man
connected
with
the
institutions
of
this
country
,
"
said
the
mother
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
woman
in
your
position
has
serious
duties
.
<EOS>
Where
duty
and
inclination
clash
,
she
must
follow
duty
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
deny
that
,
"
said
Catherine
,
getting
colder
in
proportion
to
her
mother
's
heat
.
<EOS>
"
But
one
may
say
very
true
things
and
apply
them
falsely
.
<EOS>
People
can
easily
take
the
sacred
word
duty
as
a
name
for
what
they
desire
any
one
else
to
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
parent
's
desire
makes
no
duty
for
you
,
then
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
within
reason
.
<EOS>
But
before
I
give
up
the
happiness
of
my
life
 
"
  
"
Catherine
,
Catherine
,
it
will
not
be
your
happiness
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
in
her
most
raven
-
like
tones
.
  
<EOS>
"
Well
,
what
seems
to
me
my
happiness
 
before
I
give
it
up
,
I
must
see
some
better
reason
than
the
wish
that
I
should
marry
a
nobleman
,
or
a
man
who
votes
with
a
party
that
he
may
be
turned
into
a
nobleman
.
<EOS>
I
feel
at
liberty
to
marry
the
man
I
love
and
think
worthy
,
unless
some
higher
duty
forbids
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
so
it
does
,
<EOS>
Catherine
,
though
you
are
blinded
and
can
not
see
it
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
woman
's
duty
not
to
lower
herself
.
<EOS>
You
are
lowering
yourself
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
will
you
tell
your
daughter
what
is
her
duty
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
must
see
,
Catherine
,
that
Klesmer
is
not
the
man
for
you
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
.
<EOS>
"
He
wo
n't
do
at
the
head
of
estates
.
<EOS>
He
has
a
deuced
foreign
look
 
is
an
unpractical
man
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
really
ca
n't
see
what
that
has
to
do
with
it
,
papa
.
<EOS>
The
land
of
England
has
often
passed
into
the
hands
of
foreigners
 
Dutch
soldiers
,
sons
of
foreign
women
of
bad
character
:
 
if
our
land
were
sold
to
-
morrow
it
would
very
likely
pass
into
the
hands
of
some
foreign
merchant
on
'
Change
.
<EOS>
It
is
in
everybody
's
mouth
that
successful
swindlers
may
buy
up
half
the
land
in
the
country
.
<EOS>
How
can
I
stem
that
tide
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
will
never
do
to
argue
about
marriage
,
Cath
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
.
<EOS>
"
It
's
no
use
getting
up
the
subject
like
a
parliamentary
question
.
<EOS>
We
must
do
as
other
people
do
.
<EOS>
We
must
think
of
the
nation
and
the
public
good
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
see
any
public
good
concerned
here
,
papa
,
"
said
Catherine
.
<EOS>
"
Why
is
it
to
be
expected
of
any
heiress
that
she
should
carry
the
property
gained
in
trade
into
the
hands
of
a
certain
class
?
<EOS>
That
seems
to
be
a
ridiculous
mishmash
of
superannuated
customs
and
false
ambition
.
<EOS>
I
should
call
it
a
public
evil
.
<EOS>
People
had
better
make
a
new
sort
of
public
good
by
changing
their
ambitions
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
mere
sophistry
,
Catherine
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
.
<EOS>
"
Because
you
do
n't
wish
to
marry
a
nobleman
,
you
are
not
obliged
to
marry
a
mountebank
or

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
understand
the
application
of
such
words
,
mamma
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
I
dare
say
not
,
"
rejoined
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
with
significant
scorn
.
<EOS>
"
You
have
got
to
a
pitch
at
which
we
are
not
likely
to
understand
each
other
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
ca
n't
be
done
,
Cath
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
wishing
to
substitute
a
better
-

for

's

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
A
man
like
Klesmer
ca
n't
marry
such
a
property
as
yours
.
<EOS>
It
ca
n't
be
done
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
certainly
will
not
be
done
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Where
is
the
man
?
<EOS>
Let
him
be
fetched
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
fetch
him
to
be
insulted
,
"
said
Catherine
.
<EOS>
"
Nothing
will
be
achieved
by

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose
you
would
wish
him
to
know
that
in
marrying
you
he
will
not
marry
your
fortune
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
.
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
;
if
it
were
so
,
I
should
wish
him
to
know
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
had
better
fetch
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
Catherine
only
went
into
the
music
-
room
and
said
,
"
Come
.
"
<EOS>
She
felt
no
need
to
prepare
Klesmer
.
  
<EOS>
"
Herr
Klesmer
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
with
a
rather
contemptuous

,
"
it
is
unnecessary
to
repeat
what
has
passed
between
us
and
our
daughter
.
<EOS>
Mr.
Arrowpoint
will
tell

our
resolution
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Your
marrying
is
out
of
the
question
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
rather
too
heavily
weighted
with
his

,
and
standing
in
an

unrelieved
by
a
cigar
.
<EOS>
"
It
is
a
wild
scheme
altogether
.
<EOS>
A
man
has
been
called
out
for
less
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
have
taken
a
base
advantage
of
our
confidence
,
"
burst
in
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
unable
to
carry
out
her
purpose
and
leave
the
burden
of
speech
to
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
Klesmer
made
a
low
bow
in
silent
irony
.
  
<EOS>
"
The
pretension
is
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
You
had
better
give
it
up
and
leave
the
house
at
once
,
"
continued
Mr.
Arrowpoint
.
<EOS>
He
wished
to
do
without
mentioning
the
money
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
give
up
nothing
without
reference
to
your
daughter
's
wish
,
"
said
Klesmer
.
<EOS>
"
My
engagement
is
to
her
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
useless
to
discuss
the
question
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
.
<EOS>
"
We
shall
never
consent
to
the
marriage
.
<EOS>
If
Catherine
disobeys
us
we
shall
disinherit
her
.
<EOS>
You
will
not
marry
her
fortune
.
<EOS>
It
is
right
you
should
know

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
her
fortune
has
been
the
only

I
have
had
to
regret
about
her
.
<EOS>
But
I
must
ask

if
she
will
not

the

greater
than
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
no

to

,
"
said
Catherine
,
"
except
that
I
am
sorry
to
hurt
my
father
and
mother
.
<EOS>
I
have
always
felt
my
fortune
to
be
a
wretched
fatality
of
my

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
mean
to
defy
us
,

?
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
to
marry
Herr
Klesmer
,
"
said
Catherine
,
firmly
.
  
<EOS>
"
He
had
better
not
count
on
our
relenting
,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
,
whose
manners
suffered
from
that
impunity
in
insult
which
has
been
reckoned
among
the
privileges
of
women
.
  
<EOS>
"
Madam
,
"
said
Klesmer
,
"
certain
reasons
forbid
me
to
retort
.
<EOS>
But
understand
that
I
consider
it
out
of
the
power
either
of
you
,
or
of
your
fortune
,
to
confer
on
me
anything
that
I
value
.
<EOS>
My
rank
as
an
artist
is
of
my
own
winning
,
and
I
would
not
exchange
it
for
any
other
.
<EOS>
I
am
able
to
maintain
your
daughter
,
and
I
ask
for
no
change
in
my
life
but
her

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
leave
the
house
,

,
"
said
Mrs.
Arrowpoint
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
go
at
once
,
"
said
Klesmer
,
bowing
and

room
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
there
be
no
misunderstanding
,
mamma
,
"
said
Catherine
;
"
I
consider
myself
engaged
to
Herr
Klesmer
,
and
I
intend
to
marry
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
mother
turned
her
head
away
and
waved
her
hand
in
sign
of
dismissal
.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
very
fine
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
when
Catherine
was
gone
;
"
but
what
the
deuce
are
we
to
do
with
the
property
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
is
Harry
Brendall
.
<EOS>
He
can
take
the
name
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Harry
Brendall
will
get
through
it
all
in
no
time
,
"
said
Mr.
Arrowpoint
,
relighting
his
cigar
.
  
<EOS>
And
thus
,
with
nothing
settled
<EOS>
but
the
determination
of
the
lovers
,
Klesmer
had
left
Quetcham
.
        
<EOS>
Among
the
heirs
of
Art
,
as
is
the
division
of
the
promised
land
,
each
    
has
to
win
his
portion
by
hard
fighting
:
the
bestowal
is
after
the
    
manner
of
prophecy
,
and
is
a
title
without
possession
.
<EOS>
To
carry
the
    
map
of
an
ungotten
estate
in
your
pocket
is
a
poor
sort
of
copyhold
.
    
<EOS>
And
in
fancy
to
cast
his
shoe
over
Eden
is
little
warrant
that
a
man
    
shall
ever
set
the
sole
of
his
foot
on
an
acre
of
his
own
there
.
      
<EOS>
The
most
obstinate
beliefs
that
mortals
entertain
about
themselves
are
    
such
as
they
have
no
evidence
for
beyond
a
constant
,
spontaneous
    
pulsing
of
their
self
-
satisfaction
 
as
it
were
a
hidden
seed
of
    
madness
,
a
confidence
that
they
can
move
the
world
without
precise
    
notion
of
standing
-
place
or
lever
.
   
<EOS>
"
Pray
go
to
church
,
mamma
,
"
said
Gwendolen
the
next
morning
.
<EOS>
"
I
prefer
seeing
Herr
Klesmer
alone
.
"
(
He
had
written
in
reply
to
her
note
that
he
would
be
with
her
at
eleven
.
)
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
hardly
correct
,
I
think
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
anxiously
.
  
<EOS>
"
Our
affairs
are
too
serious
for
us
to
think
of
such
nonsensical
rules
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
contemptuously
.
<EOS>
"
They
are
insulting
as
well
as
ridiculous
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
would
not
mind
Isabel
sitting
with
you
?
<EOS>
She
would
be
reading
in
a
corner
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
she
could
not
:
she
would
bite
her
nails
and
stare
.
<EOS>
It
would
be
too
irritating
.
<EOS>
Trust
my
judgment
,
mamma
,
I
must
be
alone
,
Take
them
all
to
church
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
had
her
way
,
of
course
;
only
that
Miss
Merry
and
two
of
the
girls
stayed
at
home
,
to
give
the
house
a
look
of
habitation
by
sitting
at
the
dining
-
room
windows
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
a
delicious
Sunday
morning
.
<EOS>
The
melancholy
waning
sunshine
of
autumn
rested
on
the
half
-
strown
grass
and
came
mildly
through
the
windows
in
slanting
bands
of
brightness
over
the
old
furniture
,
and
the
glass
panel
that
reflected
the
furniture
;
over
the
tapestried
chairs
with
their
faded
flower
-
wreaths
,
the
dark
enigmatic
pictures
,
the
superannuated
organ
at
which
Gwendolen
had
pleased
herself
with
acting
Saint
Cecelia
on
her
first
joyous
arrival
,
the
crowd
of
pallid
,
dusty
knicknacks
seen
through
the
open
doors
of
the
antechamber
where
she
had
achieved
the
wearing
of
her
Greek
dress
as
Hermione
.
<EOS>
This
last
memory
was
just
now
very
busy
in
her
;
for
had
not
Klesmer
then
been
struck
with
admiration
of
her
pose
and
expression
?
<EOS>
Whatever
he
had
said
,
whatever
she
imagined
him
to
have
thought
,
was
at
this
moment
pointed
with
keenest
interest
for
her
:
perhaps
she
had
never
before
in
her
life
felt
so
inwardly
dependent
,
so
consciously
in
need
of
another
person
's
opinion
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
new
fluttering
of
spirit
within
her
,
a
new
element
of
deliberation
in
her
self
-
estimate
which
had
hitherto
been
a
blissful
gift
of
intuition
.
<EOS>
Still
it
was
the
recurrent
burden
of
her
inward
soliloquy
that
Klesmer
had
seen
but
little
of
her
,
and
any
unfavorable
conclusion
of
his
must
have
too
narrow
a
foundation
.
<EOS>
She
really
felt
clever
enough
for
anything
.
  
<EOS>
To
fill
up
the
time
she
collected
her
volumes
and
pieces
of
music
,
and
laying
them
on
the
top
of
the
piano
,
set
herself
to
classify
them
.
<EOS>
Then
catching
the
reflection
of
her
movements
in
the
glass
panel
,
she
was
diverted
to
the
contemplation
of
the
image
there
and
walked
toward
it
.
<EOS>
Dressed
in
black
,
without
a
single
ornament
,
and
with
the
warm
whiteness
of
her
skin
set
off
between
her
light
-
brown
coronet
of
hair
and
her
square
-
cut
bodice
,
she
might
have
tempted
an
artist
to
try
again
the
Roman
trick
of
a
statue
in
black
,
white
,
and
tawny
marble
.
<EOS>
Seeing
her
image
slowly
advancing
,
she
thought
"
I
_
am
_
beautiful
"
 
not
exultingly
,
but
with
grave
decision
.
<EOS>
Being
beautiful
was
after
all
the
condition
on
which
she
most
needed
external
testimony
.
<EOS>
If
any
one
objected
to
the
turn
of
her
nose
or
the
form
of
her
neck
and
chin
,
she
had
not
the
sense
that
she
could
presently
show
her
power
of
attainment
in
these
branches
of
feminine
perfection
.
  
<EOS>
There
was
not
much
time
to
fill
up
in
this
way
before
the
sound
of
wheels
,
the
loud
ring
,
and
<EOS>
the
opening
doors
assured
her
that
she
was
not

Miss
Arrowpoint
,
which
will
more
than
double
such
right
as
I
have
to
be
trusted
by
you
as
a
friend
.
<EOS>
Your
friendship
will
have
greatly
risen
in
value
for
_
her
_
by
your
having
adopted
that
generous
labor
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
face
had
begun
to
burn
.
<EOS>
That
Klesmer
was
about
to
marry
Miss
Arrowpoint
<EOS>
caused
her
no
surprise
,
and
at
another
moment
she
would
have
amused
herself
in
quickly
imagining
the
scenes
that
must
have
occurred
at

.
<EOS>
But

engrossed
her
feeling
,
what
filled

now
,
was
the

of
her
own
immediate
future
that
Klesmer
's
words
seemed
to
have
unfolded
.
<EOS>
The
suggestion
of
Miss
Arrowpoint
as
a

was
only
another
detail
added
to
its
repulsiveness
:
Klesmer
's
proposal
to
help
her
seemed
an
additional
irritation
after
the
humiliating
judgment
he
had
passed
on
her
capabilities
.
<EOS>
His
words
had
really
bitten
into
her
self
-
confidence
and
turned
it
into
the
pain
of
a
bleeding

;
and
the

of
presenting

before

was
now

the

that
they
also
might
be
harsh
;
they
also
would
not
recognize
the
talent
she
was
conscious
of
.
<EOS>
But
she
controlled
herself
,
and
rose
from
her
seat
before
she
made
any
answer
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
natural
that
she
should
pause
.
<EOS>
She
went
to
the
piano
and
looked
absently
at
leaves
of
music
,
pinching
up
the
corners
.
<EOS>
At
last
she
turned
toward
Klesmer
and
said
,
with
almost
her
usual
air

,
which
in
this

had
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
Herr
Klesmer
.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
But
I
ca
n't

.
<EOS>
If

,

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

.
"
  
<EOS>
Klesmer

,
"
She
will
never
let
me
know
.
"
<EOS>
But

most

"

.
<EOS>

which

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When

,
Gwendolen
's
better

,
conscious

which
the

Klesmer
must

,
made

egoistic

.
<EOS>
Looking

with

,

and

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
Then
,

,

touched
her

lightly
with
his

,
and
in
another

more

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
had
never

so

.
<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
Her

;

.
<EOS>
All

,

,

displayed
,

open

<EOS>
the

seemed
no

packed
-

.
<EOS>
For

on

,

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
She
did

about
<EOS>
;

were
too

;

into
the
shadiest

and
pressed
her

.
<EOS>
Every

that

had
said
seemed
to
have

,
as
most

are
which

.
<EOS>
Only

,

of
self
-

rested
on

as

:

but
the

a

approved
Juliet

:

,

,

.
<EOS>
Why
not
?
<EOS>
At

,
at

,
among

,
she
had
been

;
and

in

where

,
from

art
,
is

,

only

like
 
<EOS>
otherwise

would
probably
give
forth
abler

,
and

than
any
the

is
at

obliged

.
<EOS>
The

;

<EOS>
"
Too
old

you

hard

<EOS>
bread

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
How

?

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
She

?
<EOS>

,

"

"

"

<EOS>
She

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

:
  
<EOS>
And

"
                              
<EOS>
WORDSWORTH
.
   
<EOS>
Gwendolen

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
How
_

_

you

,

.
<EOS>

all

.
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
  
"

<EOS>

"
  
"

<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,

wider

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

,

,

?
<EOS>
Thus

,

.
<EOS>
He

have
been
the
security
of
the
wife
's
gratitude
,
for
Lush
had
always
been
Mrs.
Glasher
's
friend
;
and
that
the
future
Mrs.
Grandcourt
should
not
be
socially
received
could
not
affect
his
private
comfort
.
<EOS>
He
would
not
have
minded
,
either
,
that
there
should
be
no
marriage
in
question
at
all
;
but
he
felt
himself
justified
in
doing
his
utmost
to
hinder
a
marriage
with
a
girl
who
was
likely
to
bring
nothing
but
trouble
to
her
husband
 
not
to
speak
of
annoyance
if
not
ultimate
injury
to
her
husband
's
old
companion
,
whose
future
Mr.
Lush
earnestly
wished
to
make
as
easy
as
possible
,
considering
that
he
had
well
deserved
such
compensation
for
leading
a
dog
's
life
,
though
that
of
a
dog
who
enjoyed
many
tastes
undisturbed
,
and
who
profited
by
a
large
establishment
.
<EOS>
He
wished
for
himself
what
he
felt
to
be
good
,
and
was
not
conscious
of
wishing
harm
to
any
one
else
;
unless
perhaps
it
were
just
now
a
little
harm
to
the
inconvenient
and
impertinent
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
But
the
easiest
-
humored
of
luxury
and
music
,
the
toad
-
eater
the
least
liable
to
nausea
,
must
be
expected
to
have
his
susceptibilities
.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Lush
was
accustomed
to
be
treated
by
the
world
in
general
as
an
apt
,
agreeable
fellow
:
he
had
not

up

to
be

by
more

one

.
  
<EOS>
With
this
imperfect

of
a
war

,
Lush
was

Grandcourt
's

,
doing

.
<EOS>
The
first

Grandcourt
was
much

with
the

,
and

he
ordered
a

to

on

and
let

's

.
<EOS>
This
marked

purpose
set

on
considering
over
again
whether
he
should
incur
the
ticklish

of
speaking
first
,
while

was

that
no

;
and

rose
the
next
morning
<EOS>
almost

that

.
<EOS>
But

did

,

,
no

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

"

?
"

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

Grandcourt

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

"
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
Here

"

"

"

:
"

,

He

"

"
  
<EOS>
No

,

.
<EOS>
Why
,

,

,

The

,
and

<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
"
Let
Hutchins
go

,

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

was

Miss
Harleth
,
Offendene
.
<EOS>
When

;

.
<EOS>

full

backward

which

_

_
.
<EOS>

scarcely

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
Perhaps

full

"

.
<EOS>

_

<EOS>

"

"

,

.

?

"

.

:

<EOS>

.

seemed

:

.

,

.

her

prospects
;
her
vision
was
filled
by
her
own
release
from
the
Momperts
,
and
her
mother
's
release
from
Sawyer
's
Cottage
.
<EOS>
With
a

of
the

,
she
said
    
"
Will
you
not
see
mamma
?
<EOS>
I
will
fetch
her
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

wait
a

,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
in
his

,
having
his

,
and

,
while

near

and
looked
at
her
 
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
Have
you
anything
else

,
"
said

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
 
I
know

things
said
to
you
is
a
great

,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
rather

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not
when

are
things
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Will

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
it
will
,

-

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

-

,

,

to
-

.
<EOS>
Think

to
-

.
<EOS>
In
a
fortnight
 
or

weeks
 
as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
think

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
notice
when
people
are
married
the
husband
is
not

with
his
wife
as
when
they
are
engaged
.
<EOS>
But
perhaps
I
shall
like

better
,

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
laughed
charmingly
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
shall
have
whatever
you
like
,
"
said
Grandcourt
.
  
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
And
nothing
that
I
do
n't
like
?
 
<EOS>
please
say
that
;
because
I
think
I
dislike
what
I
do

like
more
than
I
like
what
I
like
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
finding
herself
in
the
woman
's
paradise
,
where
all
her
nonsense
is
adorable
.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
paused
;
these
were
subtilties
in
which
he
had
much
experience
of

.
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
know
 
this
is
such
a

of

,

up
that

n't

.
<EOS>
I
ca

.
<EOS>

,

ca

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

:

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Come

.
"
  
<EOS>
They

,

,

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

?
"

.
<EOS>
"
If
you

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
But

must

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Take
my

to

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
Their

were
very

,

,
and
he

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

"

.
<EOS>

_

.

<EOS>
Gwendolen

.
<EOS>
All

:
Grandcourt
's

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Really

.
  
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
My

,
"

.
  
<EOS>

,
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
    
<EOS>
GWENDOLEN

.
      
<EOS>
"
Il

<EOS>
homme
<EOS>

.
 
<EOS>
LA
ROCHEFOUCAULD
.
"
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

on

.
"
  
<EOS>
The

,

<EOS>

,
"

.
<EOS>
In

she

about
Rex
 
<EOS>
how

her

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
Miss
Merry
and

,

,

,

,

,

"
Sir

Grandison
.
<EOS>
"
The

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Ryelands

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

;
"
But
<EOS>
Ryelands
I

.
<EOS>
The

of

.
<EOS>
The

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
Still
,

was

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.

"
The

,
"

"

.
<EOS>
There

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
To

<EOS>
I

style
 
with

,

.
<EOS>
Let

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
And

,

"

.
<EOS>
She
