.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
thought

,

Mompert

Mumbo
-

.
<EOS>
She
was
very
silent
through

,
and
that

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
rarity
in
her
strong

:
and

still
greater
rarity

her
to
be

that

not

.
<EOS>
But
her
state
of
mind
was
altogether
new
:
she
who
had
been
used
to
feel
sure
of
herself
,
and
ready

,
had
just

decisive
step
which
she
had
beforehand
thought
that
she
would
not
take
 
nay
,
<EOS>
perhaps
,
was
bound
not
to
take
.
<EOS>
She
could
not
go
backward
now
;
she
liked
a
great
deal
of
what
lay
before
her
;
and
there
was
nothing
for
her
to
like
if
she
went
back
.
<EOS>
But
her
resolution
was
dogged
by

shadow
of
that
previous
resolve
which
had
at
first

as
the

.
<EOS>
While

,
"
looking
on
darkness
which
the
blind
do
see
,
"
she
was
appalled
by
the
idea
that
she
was
going

do

had
once
started

.
<EOS>
It
was
new

her
that
a

of

in

should
rouse
her
terror
;
she
had

no
compunction
that
atoning
caresses
and
presents
could
not
lay
to
rest
.
<EOS>
But
here
had
come
a
moment
when
something
like
a
new
consciousness
was
awaked
.
<EOS>
She
seemed
on
the
edge
of
adopting
deliberately
,
as
a
notion
for
all
the
rest
of
her
life
,
what
she
had
rashly
said
in
her
bitterness
,
when
her
discovery
had
driven
her
away
to
Leubronn
:
 
that
it
did
not
signify
what
she
did
;
she
had
only
to
amuse
herself
as
best
she
could
.
<EOS>
That
lawlessness
,
that
casting
away
of
all
care
for
justification
,
suddenly
frightened
her
:
it
came
to
her
with
the
shadowy
array
of
possible
calamity
behind
it
 
calamity
which
had
ceased
to
be
a
mere
name
for
her
;
and
all
the
infiltrated
influences
of
disregarded
religious
teaching
,
as
well
as
the
deeper
impressions
of
something
awful
and
inexorable
enveloping
her
,
seemed
to
concentrate
themselves
in
the
vague
conception
of
avenging
power
.
<EOS>
The
brilliant
position
she
had
longed
for
,
the
imagined
freedom
she
would
create
for
herself
in
marriage
,
the
deliverance
from
the
dull
insignificance
of
her
girlhood
 
all
immediately
before
her
;
and
yet
they
had
come
to
her
hunger
like
food
with
the
taint
of
sacrilege
upon
it
,
which
she
must
snatch
with
terror
.
<EOS>
In
the
darkness
and
loneliness
of
her
little
bed
,
her
more
resistant
self
could
not
act
against
the
first
onslaught
of
dread
after
her
irrevocable
decision
.
<EOS>
That
unhappy
-
faced
woman
and
her
children
 
Grandcourt
and
his
relations
with
her
 
kept
repeating
themselves
in
her
imagination
like
the
clinging
memory
of
a
disgrace
,
and
gradually
obliterated
all
other
thought
,
leaving
only
the
consciousness
that
she
had
taken
those
scenes
into
her
life
.
<EOS>
Her
long
wakefulness
seemed
a
delirium
;
a
faint
,
faint
light
penetrated
beside
the
window
-
curtain
;
the
chillness
increased
.
<EOS>
She
could
bear
it
no
longer
,
and
cried
"
Mamma
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
dear
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
immediately
,
in
a
wakeful
voice
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
me
come
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
soon
went
to
sleep
on
her
mother
's
shoulder
,
and
slept
on
till
late
,
when
,
dreaming
of
a
lit
-
up
ball
-
room
,
she
opened
her
eyes
on
her
mother
standing
by
the
bedside
with
a
small
packet
in
her
hand
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
am
sorry
to
wake
you
,
darling
,
but
I
thought
it
better
to
give
you
this
at
once
.
<EOS>
The
groom
has
brought
Criterion
;
he
has
come
on
another
horse
,
and
says
he
is
to
stay
here
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
sat
up
in
bed
and
opened
the
packet
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
delicate
enameled
casket
,
and
inside
was
a
splendid
diamond
ring
with
a
letter
which
contained
a
folded
bit
of
colored
paper
and
these
words
:
        
<EOS>
Pray
wear
this
ring
when
I
come
at
twelve
in
sign
of
our
betrothal
.
<EOS>
I
    
enclose
a
check
drawn
in
the
name
of
Mr.
Gascoigne
,
for
immediate
    
expenses
.
<EOS>
Of
course
Mrs.
Davilow
will
remain
at
Offendene
,
at
least
    
for
some
time
.
<EOS>
I
hope
,
when
I
come
,
you
will
have
granted
me
an
early
    
day
,
when
you
may
begin
to
command
me
at
a
shorter
distance
.
      
<EOS>
Yours
devotedly
,
      
H.
M.
GRANDCOURT
.
  
<EOS>
The
check
was
for
five
hundred
pounds
,
and
Gwendolen
turned
it
toward
her
mother
,
with
the
letter
.
  
<EOS>
"
How
very
kind
and
delicate
!
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
with
much
feeling
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
But
I
really
should
like
better
not
to
be
dependent
on
a
son
-
in
-
law
.
<EOS>
I
and
the
girls
could
get
along
very
well
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mamma
,
if
you
say
that
again
,
I
will
not
marry
him
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
angrily
.
  
<EOS>
"
My
dear
child
,
I
trust
you
are
not
going
to
marry
only
for
my
sake
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
depreciatingly
.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
tossed
her
head
on
the
pillow
away
from
her
mother
,
and
let
the
ring
lie
.
<EOS>
She
was
irritated
at
this
attempt
to
take
away
a
motive
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
deeper
cause
of
her
irritation
was
the
consciousness
that
she
was
not
going
to
marry
solely
for
her
mamma
's
sake
 
that
she
was
drawn
toward
the
marriage
in
ways
<EOS>
against
which
stronger
reasons
than
her
mother
's
renunciation
were
yet
not
strong
enough
to
hinder
her
.
<EOS>
She
had
waked
up
to
the
signs
that
she
was
irrevocably
engaged
,
and
all
the
ugly
visions
,
the
alarms
,
the
arguments
of
the
night
,
must
be
met
by
daylight
,
in
which
probably
they
would
show
themselves
weak
.
<EOS>
"
What
I
long
for
is
your
happiness
,
dear
,
"
continued
Mrs.
Davilow
,
pleadingly
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
say
anything
to
vex
you
.
<EOS>
Will
you
not
put
on
the
ring
?
"
  
<EOS>
For
a
few
moments
Gwendolen
did
not
answer
,
but
her
thoughts
were
active
.
<EOS>
At
last
she
raised
herself
with
a
determination
to
do
as
she
would
do
if
she
had
started
on
horseback
,
and
go
on
with
spirit
,
whatever
ideas
might
be
running
in
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought
the
lover
always
put
on
the

ring
himself
,
"
she
said
laughingly
,
slipping
the
ring

,
and

with

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
why
he
has
sent
it
,
"
she

,
nodding

.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
He
would
rather
make
me
put
it
on
than
ask
me
to
let
him
do

.
<EOS>
Aha
!
<EOS>
he
is
very
proud
.
<EOS>
But
so
am
I.
<EOS>
We
shall
match
each
other
.
<EOS>
I
should
hate
a
man
who
went
down
on
his
knees
,
and
came
fawning
on
me
.
<EOS>
He
really
is
not
disgusting
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is
very
moderate
praise
,
Gwen
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
it
is
not
,
for
a
man
,
"
said
Gwendolen
gaily
.
<EOS>
"
But
now
I
must
get
up
and
dress
.
<EOS>
Will
you
come
and
do
my
hair
,
mamma
,
dear
,
"
she
went

,
drawing

mamma
's

to

with
her
own

,
"
and
not

so
naughty
any

as
to

?
<EOS>
You
must
bear
to

,
even
if

do
n't

.
<EOS>
And
Mr.
Grandcourt
behaves

,

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Certainly
he
does
,
"
said
Mrs.
Davilow
,
encouraged
,
and
persuaded
that
after
all
Gwendolen
was
fond
of
her
betrothed
.
<EOS>
She
herself
thought
him
a
man
whose
attentions
were
likely
to
tell
on
a
girl
's
feeling
.
<EOS>
Suitors
must
often
be
judged
as
words
are
,
by
the
standing
and
the
figure
they
make
in
polite
society
:
it
is
difficult
to
know
much
else
of
them
.
<EOS>
And
all
the
mother
's
anxiety
turned
not
on
Grandcourt
's
character
,
but
on
Gwendolen
's
mood
in
accepting
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
mood
was
necessarily
passing
through
a
new
phase
this
morning
.
<EOS>
Even
in
the
hour
of
making
her
toilet
,
she
had
drawn
on
all
the
knowledge
she
had
for
grounds
to
justify
her
marriage
.
<EOS>
And
what
she
most
dwelt
on
was
the
determination
,
that
when
she
was
Grandcourt
's
wife
,
she
would
urge
him
to
the
most

toward
Mrs.
Glasher
's
children
.
  
<EOS>
"
Of
what
use
would
it
be
to
her
that
I
should
not

?
<EOS>
He
could
have
married
her
if
he

;
but
he
did
_
<EOS>
not
_
like
.
<EOS>
Perhaps

is
to

.
<EOS>
There
must
be
a
great

about

that
I

nothing

.
<EOS>
And
he
must
have
been
good
to
her
in
many
ways
,
else
she
would
not

wanted
to
marry
him
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
that
last
argument
at
once
began
to
appear

.
<EOS>
Mrs.
Glasher
naturally
wished
to
exclude
other
children
who
would
stand
between
Grandcourt
and

own
:
and
Gwendolen
's

of

prompted
another
way

claims
.
  
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
we
shall
have
no
children
.
<EOS>
I
hope
we
shall
not
.
<EOS>
And
he
might
leave
the
estate
to
the
pretty
little
boy
.
<EOS>
My
uncle
said
that
Mr.
Grandcourt
could
do
as
he

with
the
estates
.
<EOS>
Only
when
Sir
Hugo
Mallinger
dies
there
will
be
enough
for
two
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
made
Mrs.
Glasher
appear
quite
unreasonable
in
demanding
that
her
boy
should
be
sole
heir
;
and
the
double
property
was
a
security
that
Grandcourt
's
marriage
would
do
her
no

,
when
the
wife
was
Gwendolen
Harleth
with
all
her
proud
resolution
not
to
be
fairly
accused
.
<EOS>
This
maiden
had
been
accustomed
to
think
herself
blameless
;
other
persons
only
were
faulty
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
striking
,
that
in
the
hold
which
this

of
her
doing
no

to
Mrs.
Glasher
had
taken

,
her

to

idea
of
Grandcourt
's
past
had
sunk
into

.
<EOS>
The
terror
she
had
felt
in
the
night
-

at
overstepping
the
border
of
wickedness
by
doing
what
she

at
first

to

,
had
dulled

about

.
<EOS>
She
was
thinking

him
,
whatever
he
might

,
as
a
man
over
whom
she
was
going
to

;
and
her
loving
him
having
never
been
a
question
with
her
,
any
agreeableness
he
had
was
so
much
gain
.
<EOS>
Poor
Gwendolen
had
no
awe
of
unmanageable
forces
in
the
state
of
matrimony
,
but
regarded
it
as
altogether
a
matter
of
management
,

she
would
know
how
to
act
.
<EOS>
In

Grandcourt
's
past
she
encouraged
new

whether
he
were
likely
to
have
differed
much
from
other

;
and
she
devised
little

for
learning
what
was
expected
of
men
in

.
  
<EOS>
But
whatever
else
might
be
true
in
the
world
,
her
hair
was
dressed
suitably
for
riding
,
and
she
went
down
in
her
riding
-
habit
,
to
avoid
delay
before
getting
on
horseback
.
<EOS>
She
wanted
to
have
her
blood
stirred
once
more
with
the
intoxication
of
youth
,
and
to
recover
the
daring
with
which
she
had
been
used
to
think
of
her
course
in
life
.
<EOS>
Already
a
load
was
lifted
off
her
;
for
in
daylight
and
activity
it
was
less
oppressive
to
have

about
her
choice
,
than
to
feel
that
she
had
no

but
to
endure

and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Go
back
and
make

,
mamma
,
"
she

,
turning

-

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Put
your
point
-
lace
over

.
<EOS>
I
must
have
you
look
like

duchess
.
<EOS>
You
must
not
take
things
humbly
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
When
Grandcourt
raised
her
left
hand
gently
and

ring
,
she

,
"
It
was
very
good

you
to
think

and

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will

there

I
forget
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
keeping
the
hand
softly

own
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
do
anything
you
wish
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
I
am
very
unreasonable
in
my

,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
smiling
.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
expect
that
.
<EOS>
Women
always
are
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
I
will
not
be
unreasonable
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
taking
away
her
hand
and
tossing
her

.
<EOS>
"
I
will
not
be
told
that
I
am
what
women
always
are
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
did
not
say
that
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
looking
at
her
with
his
usual
gravity
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
what
no
other
woman
is
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
And
what
is
that
,
pray
?
"
said
Gwendolen
,
moving
to
a
distance
with
a
little

.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
made
his
pause
before
he
answered
.
<EOS>
"
You
are
the
woman
I
love
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
what
nice
speeches
!
"
said
Gwendolen
,
laughing
.
<EOS>
The
sense
of
that
love
which
he
must
once
have
given
to
another
woman
under
strange
circumstances
was
getting
familiar
.
  
<EOS>
"
Give
me
a
nice
speech
in

.
<EOS>
Say

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Not

.
<EOS>
Not
till

.
<EOS>
I

so

that
,
I
can

else
.
<EOS>
I
wish
the
hunting
had
begun
.
<EOS>
Sunday
the
twentieth
,
twenty
-
seventh
,
Monday
,
Tuesday
.
<EOS>
"
Gwendolen
was
counting
on
her
fingers
with
the
prettiest
nod
while
she
looked
at
Grandcourt
,
and
at
last
swept
one

over
the
other
while

,
"
It
will
begin
in
ten

!
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let

married

,

,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
"
and
we
shall
not

bored

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
do
women
always
say
in

?
"
said
Gwendolen
,
mischievously
.
  
<EOS>
"
They
agree
to
it
,
"
said

<EOS>
"

political

<EOS>

;

,

from

.
<EOS>
That

;

.
  
<EOS>
But
Grandcourt
's
hair
,

had
not
much
of

,
was
of
a
fine
,
sunny

,
and
his

.
<EOS>
We
mortals
have

,

knows

biting

.

for
    
the
neighborhood
,
and
there
will
be
the
notion
of
the
money
sticking
    
by
him
without
being
urged
.
<EOS>
I
would
bet
on
your
ultimate
success
.
<EOS>
As
I
    
am
not
to
be
exiled
to
Siberia
,
but
am
to
be
within
call
,
it
is
    
possible
that
,
by
and
by
,
I
may
be
of
more
service
to
you
.
<EOS>
But
at
    
present
I
can
think
of
no
medium
so
good
as
Mr.
Deronda
.
<EOS>
Nothing
puts
    
Grandcourt
in
worse
humor
than
having
the
lawyers
thrust
their
paper
    
under
his
nose
uninvited
.
      
<EOS>
Trusting
that
your
visit
to
Leubronn
has
put
you
in
excellent
    
condition
 
for
the
winter
,
I
remain
,
my
dear
Sir
Hugo
,
      
Yours
very
faithfully
,
      
THOMAS
CRANMER
LUSH
.
  
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
,
having
received
this
letter
at
breakfast
,
handed
it
to
Deronda
,
who
,
though
he
had
chambers
in
town
,
was
somehow
hardly
ever
in
them
,
Sir
Hugo
not
being
contented
without
him
.
<EOS>
The
chatty
baronet
would
have
liked
a
young
companion
even
if
there
had
been
no
peculiar
reasons
for
attachment
between
them
:
one
with
a
fine
harmonious
unspoiled
face
fitted
to
keep
up
a
cheerful
view
of
posterity
and
inheritance
generally
,
notwithstanding
particular
disappointments
;
and
his
affection
for
Deronda
was
not
diminished
by
the
deep
-
lying
though
not
obtrusive
difference
in
their
notions
and
tastes
.
<EOS>
Perhaps
it
was
all
the
stronger
;
acting
as
the
same
sort
of
difference
does
between
a
man
and
a
woman
in
giving
a
piquancy
to
the
attachment
which
subsists
in
spite
of
it
.
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
did
not
think
unapprovingly
of
himself
;
but
he
looked
at
men
and
society
from
a
liberal
-
menagerie
point
of
view
,
and
he
had
a
certain
pride
in
Deronda
's
differing
from
him
,
which
,
if
it
had
found
voice
,
might
have
said
 
"
You
see
this
fine
young
fellow
 
not
such
as
you
see
every

,
is
he
?
 
<EOS>
he
belongs
to
me
in
a
sort

.
<EOS>
I
brought
him
up
from
a
child
;
but
you
would
not
ticket

,
he
has
notions

own
,
and
he
's
as
far
as
the
poles
asunder
from
what
I
was
at
his
age
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This

of

was

the
mental
balance
in
Deronda
,
who
was

by
an
affectionateness
such
as
we
are
apt

,

,

certain

of

,
and

,
held

.
  
<EOS>
When

,

,
inwardly

under
Lush
's
mode
of
attributing

to

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

,
Dan
?
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

Deronda
,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
<EOS>
If

.

"

"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
,
in

the

visit
,
felt
less
disinclination
than
when

.
<EOS>
The
story
of
that
girl
's

did
interest
him
:
what
he
had
heard
through
Lush
of
her
having
run

from
the
suit
of
the
man
she
was
now

,
had

;
and
it

probably

transition
from
that
fevered

into

which
had
urged

where
she
must
in
some

.
<EOS>
All
this
implied
a
nature
liable
to
difficulty
and
struggle
 
elements
of
life
which
had
a
predominant
attraction
for
his
sympathy
,
due
perhaps
to
his
early
pain
in
dwelling
on
the
conjectured
story
of
his
own
existence
.
<EOS>
Persons
attracted
him
,
as
Hans
Meyrick
had
done
,
in
proportion
to
the
possibility
of
his
defending

,

,
telling
upon

;
and
he
had
to
resist
an
inclination
,
easily
accounted
for
,
to
withdraw

from
the
fortunate
.
<EOS>
But
in
the

which
had
led

to
repurchase
Gwendolen
's

for
her
,
and
which
was
at

in

,

something

something

of
her

.
<EOS>
He
was
very
open
to
that
sort

charm
,
and
mingled

with
the
consciously

of

own

;
yet
any
one
able
to
trace

might
have

that
he
would
be
more
likely
than
many
less

to
love

woman
without

her

.
<EOS>
Sprinkle
food
before
a
delicate
-
eared
bird
:
there
is
nothing
he
would
more
willingly
take
,
yet
he
keeps
aloof
,
because
of
his
sensibility
to
checks
which
to
you
are

.
<EOS>
And
one
man
differs
from
another
,

we
all
differ
from

Bosjesman
,
in
a

to
checks
,
that
come
from

of
needs
,

.
<EOS>
It
seemed

that

of
reticence
in
Deronda
that
his
imagination
was
much
occupied
with
two
women
,
to

.
<EOS>
Hans

had

for

;
and

's

about

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
wrote

,

.
<EOS>
That

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt

's

court

,

.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt

not

which

.
      
<EOS>
"
Surely

,
     
him

I

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,
     
with

.
<EOS>
"
                                      
<EOS>
WALT
WHITMAN
.
   
<EOS>
"

,
"

,
"

?
 
<EOS>
to

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Things

.
<EOS>
And
to
-
morrow
is

.
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
sitting
sideways
on
a
sofa
in
the
drawing
-

at
Offendene
,
one

and

on

back
,
and
the

hand
thrust
between
his
crossed
knees
 
in
the
attitude
of
a
man
who
is
much
interested
in
watching
the
person
next
to
him
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
who
had
always
disliked
needlework
,
had
taken
to
it
with
apparent
zeal
since
her
engagement
,
and
now
held
a
piece
of
white
embroidery
which
,
on
examination
,
would
have
shown
many
false
stitches
.
<EOS>
During
the
last
eight
or
nine
days
their
hours
had
been
chiefly
spent
on
horseback
,
but
some
margin
had
always
been
left
for
this
more
difficult
sort
of
companionship
,
which
,
however
,
Gwendolen
had
not
found
disagreeable
.
<EOS>
She
was
very
well
satisfied
with
Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
His
answers
to
her
lively
questions
about
what
he
had
seen
and
done
in
his
life
,
bore
drawling
very
well
.
<EOS>
From
the
first
she
had
noticed
that
he
knew
what
to
say
;
and
she
was
constantly
feeling
not
only
that
he
had
nothing
of
the
fool
in
his
composition
,
but
that
by
some
subtle
means
he
communicated
to
her
the
impression
that
all
the
folly
lay
with
other
people
,
who
did
what
he
did
not
care
to
do
.
<EOS>
A
man
who
seems
to
have
been
able
to
command
the
best
,
has
a
sovereign

of
depreciation
.
<EOS>
Then
Grandcourt
's
behavior
as
a
lover
had
hardly
at
all
passed
the
limit
of
an
amorous

which
was
inobtrusive
as
a
wafted
odor

,
and
spent

effects
in

.
<EOS>
One

,

had
kissed
not
her

her

a

;
and
Gwendolen
,

,
had
started

which
made

,
"
I
beg
your
pardon
 
<EOS>
did
I
annoy
you
?
"
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

nothing
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,

,
"
only

to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

,
but
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Her

,

.
  
<EOS>
To

;

,

(
of

<EOS>
Gwendolen

.
<EOS>
She

"

?
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
  
"

<EOS>
it

a

<EOS>
but

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Grandcourt
noticed

"

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
She

her

the

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
He

<EOS>
"

"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

<EOS>
Her

.
  
<EOS>
"
How

"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
_

_

"
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>
She

:

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
_

_

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Gwendolen

.
<EOS>
She
was

,
that

<EOS>
that

.
<EOS>
She
had

,
and

a

that
she

.
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
All

,

.
<EOS>
With

.
<EOS>
There

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Not

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
Clearly

"

<EOS>
It

that

:
an

<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
Her

<EOS>
a

.
<EOS>
His

that

threatens
to

as

's

was

.
<EOS>
(
Who

?
)
<EOS>
His

,

,
was
to
Grandcourt

,

in

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
,

,

Deronda
thought

much

:
 
a

.
<EOS>
However

on

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
held

;
Deronda

Caliban
,

could

;

;

;

-

;
and
Deronda

that

to

-

.
  
<EOS>
While
this
polite
pea
-

was

,
Gwendolen
trifled
with
her
jelly
,
and
looked
at
every

in
turn
that
she
might

at

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

he

,

?
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
Why

to

"

was
no

.
<EOS>
Where

,

.
<EOS>
They

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
She

;

"

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

"

<EOS>
No

,
  
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Imagine

<EOS>

:
<EOS>
a

some

Outside

,

,

<EOS>
Mrs.

's

,

.
<EOS>
Now

;

.
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

;

<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Grandcourt

.
<EOS>
He

:

.

Yet

.

His

,

.
<EOS>
At

would

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

which

had

in
Mrs.
Glasher
was
just

.
<EOS>
At
first
she
was
comparatively
careless
about

.
<EOS>
It
was
enough
that

had

with

who
had

her
 
young
,

,

,
and

,

and

.
<EOS>
She
was

,

,

,

by
five

of

;

was

that

.
<EOS>
An

was

;

no

:

,

,

,

"
mamma
"

.
<EOS>
But

had

her

and

;
and
that
Grandcourt
should

had

.
<EOS>
The

position
which
she
had
not

about
for

was
now

through

,
whom

.
<EOS>
She
had
no

except

.
<EOS>
If
Grandcourt
married
her
,
the
children
would
be
none
the

off
for

passed
:
they

see

mother
in

,
and

would
be
at

with

:
her

could
be

's

.
<EOS>
It

this

which

to

's

;

had
long

that

,

of
her

including

in

.
<EOS>
For

she
was

to
endure
anything
quietly

;

to

Grandcourt
's
flickering

negatively
,

molesting

with

.
<EOS>
In
her
,
as

else

wanted
anything

,

,

to
harden

,
had
created
a
reasonable
dread
:
 
a
slow

,
of
which
no

had
been
given
in
the
bearing
of
a

lover
with
a
fine
line
of

and
the
softest

.
<EOS>
But
reticence
had
necessarily
cost
something
to
this
impassioned
woman
,
and
she
was
the

for
it
.
<EOS>
There
is
no
quailing
 
even
that
forced
on
the
helpless
and
injured
 
which
has
not
an
ugly
obverse
:
the
withheld
sting
was
gathering

.
<EOS>
She
was
absolutely
dependent
on
Grandcourt
;
for
though

had
been

for

,

had

;
and

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
said

would

;
and

was

future

often

that

<EOS>

<EOS>
Lydia
.

"
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Even

,

<EOS>
Both

.
<EOS>
Yet

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"
  
"

<EOS>
"

"

.

"

"

"
Poor

!
"

<EOS>
"

"
                              
SHAKESPEARE
.
   
<EOS>

;

bless
you
;
we
shall
see
you
again
before
long
,
"
and
then
returned
to
Mrs.
Davilow
,
saying
half
cheerfully
,
half
solemnly
    
<EOS>
"
Let
us
be
thankful
,
Fanny
.
<EOS>
She
is
in
a
position
well

to
her
,
and
beyond

I

have
dared

.
<EOS>
And
few
women

chosen
more
entirely
for

.
<EOS>
You
should
feel
yourself
a
happy

.
"
         
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
      
<EOS>
*
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
railway
journey
of
some
fifty
miles
before
the
new
husband
and
wife
reached
the
station
near
Ryelands
.
<EOS>
The
sky
had
veiled
itself
since
the
morning
,
and
it
was
hardly
more
than
twilight
when
they
entered
the
park
-
gates
,
but
<EOS>
still
Gwendolen
,
looking
out

the

along
,
could

the
grand

and
the

of
the
scene
 
<EOS>
the

bordered

:
then

;

,

,

<EOS>
Gwendolen
had

during

,

,

any

in

;
and
Grandcourt
had
been
rather

,
while
she
turned

gentle

of
her

into

,
with

as

.
<EOS>
She
was
really

somewhat

;
and
now

the
park
her

.
<EOS>
Was

,

about

her

of
being
"
<EOS>
somebody
"
 
walking

own

of

own

of
an
out
-
of
-
sight

,
where
her
own
painted
Spring
was

,
and
her
own
fore
-
shortened
Zephyrs
were

over

;
while
her
own

,

in

but

,
were
as

,
and
revered

of

to

:
 
being
in
short

heroine
of
an
admired

of

?
<EOS>
Was

alone

of
this

which

?
<EOS>
or

some
dim

,
the
insistent

of
suppressed

,

?
<EOS>
Hers
was
one

of

.
  
<EOS>
She

,

,
"

!
"
<EOS>

:

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

print
,

.
      
<EOS>
These

,

Lydia
    
Glasher
<EOS>
,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
God

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
His

:

.
<EOS>
It

<EOS>
You

<EOS>

<EOS>
Truly

,

.

In

<EOS>
In

<EOS>
Deronda

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
What

?
 
<EOS>
only

before

.
<EOS>
Few

;

<EOS>
This

,

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Few

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
We

;

the

.
<EOS>
Martyrdom

,

,

He

knowledge

the

<EOS>
To

what

;

?
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>

,

?
  
<EOS>
Something
like

was
the
common

-
current
in

's

while

law

.
<EOS>
Meanwhile

.
<EOS>
Not

,

have

,
with

of
bruising

.
  
<EOS>
I
have

that

he

which

;

,

sense

remote

playfully
    
"
Whichever

take

,

;

,

must
end

difference
,
just

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
To
be
sure
.
<EOS>
We

in
zig

,
"

Meyrick
.
<EOS>
"
I
think

is
very
weak

to

up
by

.
<EOS>
Still

's

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

;

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
And

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
As

she

fervent
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

<EOS>
"
  
"

<EOS>
Mirah
's

<EOS>
,

<EOS>

<EOS>
However
!
 
<EOS>
Thank

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
divined
something

in

<EOS>
His

<EOS>
He

that

;

.
<EOS>
There

,

,

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

acting

.
<EOS>
How

's

.
<EOS>
Mirah
's

;

.
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Our

,

-

,

<EOS>
"
This

.

<EOS>
"

,
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Having

Deronda

Han
's

.
<EOS>

,

,

.
<EOS>
To

,

;

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>

(
whether

)

.
  
<EOS>
As

's

,

-

.
<EOS>
His

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I

.
"
  
<EOS>
What

all
do
without

,

?
<EOS>
The
admirable

of
the

,

is

,
always
supply

with
a

before
which

.
        
<EOS>
"
No
man
,
"
says
a
Rabbi
,
by

instance
,
"
may
turn
the
    
bones
of
his
father
and
mother
into

"
 
sure
that
his
hearers
    
felt
the
checks
against
that

.
<EOS>
The
market
for
spoons
    
has
never
expanded
enough
for
any

to
say
,
"
Why
not
?
"
and

that
human
progress

.
<EOS>
The

check
to

is
a

,

will

none
who
do
not
    
hold
that
sentiments
are
the
better

of
the
world
's
wealth
.
   
<EOS>
Deronda
meanwhile
took
to
a
less
fashionable
form
of
exercise
than
riding
in
Rotten
Row
.
<EOS>
He
went
often
rambling
in
those
parts
of
London
which
are
most

by
common
Jews
.
<EOS>
He
walked
to
the
synagogues
at
times
of
service
,
he
looked
into
shops
,
he
observed
faces
:
 
<EOS>
a
process
not
very
promising
of
particular
discovery
.
<EOS>
Why
did
he
not
address
himself
to
an
influential
Rabbi

,

finding

mother
named

,

,

?
<EOS>
He
thought
of
doing
so
 
after
Christmas
.
<EOS>
The
fact
was
,
notwithstanding
all
his
sense
of
poetry
in
common
things
,
Deronda
,
where
a

interest
was
aroused
,
could
not
,
more
than
the
rest

us
,
continuously
escape

from
the
pressure
of
that
hard
unaccommodating
Actual
,
which
has
never
consulted
our
taste
and
is
entirely
unselect
.
<EOS>
Enthusiasm
,
we
know
,
dwells
at
ease
among
ideas
,
tolerates

breathed
in
the
middle

,
and
sees
no

,
expecting
to
see
behind
the
counter
a
grimy
personage
showing
that
_
nonchalance
_
about
sales
which
seems
to
belong
universally
to
the
second
-
hand
book
-
business
.
<EOS>
In
most
other
trades
you
find
generous
men
who
are
anxious
to
sell
you
their
wares
for
your
own
welfare
;
but
even
a
Jew
will
not
urge
Simson
's
Euclid
on
you
with
an
affectionate
assurance
that
you
will
have
pleasure
in
reading
it
,
and
that
he
wishes
he
had
twenty
more
of
the
article
,
so
much
is
it
in
request
.
<EOS>
One
is
led
to
fear
that
a
secondhand
bookseller
may
belong
to
that
unhappy
class
of
men
who
have
no
belief
in
the
good
of
what
they
get
their
living
by
,
yet
keep
conscience
enough
to
be
morose
rather
than
unctuous
in
their
vocation
.
  
<EOS>
But
instead
of
the
ordinary
tradesman
,
he
saw
,
on
the
dark
background
of
books
in
the
long
narrow
shop
,
a
figure
that
was
somewhat
startling
in
its
unusualness
.
<EOS>
A
man
in
threadbare
clothing
,
whose
age
was
difficult
to
guess
 
from
the
dead
yellowish
flatness
of
the
flesh
,
something
like
an
old
ivory
carving
 
was
seated
on
a
stool
against
some

that
projected
beyond
the
short
counter
,
doing
nothing

than
reading

's
_
Times
_
;
but
when

let
the
paper
rest
on

at
the
incoming
customer
,
the
thought
glanced
through
Deronda
that
precisely
such
a
physiognomy
as
that
might
possibly
have
been
seen

,

.
<EOS>
It
was
a
fine
typical
Jewish
face
,
wrought
into
intensity
of
expression
apparently
by
a
strenuous
eager
experience
in
which
all
the
satisfaction
had
been
indirect

far
off
,
and
perhaps
by
some
bodily

also
,
which
involved
that
absence
of
ease
in
the
present
.
<EOS>
The
features
were
clear
-
cut
,
not
large
;
the
brow
not
high
but
broad
,
and
fully
defined
by
the
crisp
black
hair
.
<EOS>
It
might
never
have
been
a
particularly
handsome
face
,
but
it
must
always
have
been
forcible
;
and
now
with
its
dark
,

-

,

shop
,

upon

in
some

,
which

;
while
the

on
an

seemed
eager

to

.
<EOS>
The

probably

;

;
"

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

"

,

Ram

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
The

Mother
!
"

<EOS>

:
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

Cohen
,

,
with

.
<EOS>
Deronda

,

<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
All
.
<EOS>

If

.

.

But

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

;

.

_
<EOS>

<EOS>
When
Deronda
arrived
at
five

,
the
shop
was
closed
and
the
door
was
opened
for
him
by
the
Christian

.
<EOS>
When
she
showed
him
into
the
room
behind
the
shop
he
was
surprised
at
the
prettiness
of
the
scene
.
<EOS>
The
house
was
old
,
and
rather
extensive
at
the
back
:
probably
the
large
room
he
how
entered
was
gloomy
by
daylight
,
but
now
it
was
agreeably
lit
by
a
fine
old
brass
lamp
with
seven
oil
-
lights
hanging
above
the
snow
-
white
cloth
spread
on
the
central

,
The
ceiling
and
walls
were
smoky
,
and
all
the
surroundings
were
dark
enough
to
throw
into
relief
the
human
figures
,
which
had
a
Venetian
glow
of
coloring
.
<EOS>
The
grandmother
was
arrayed
in
yellowish
brown
with
a
large

chain
in
lieu
of
the
necklace
,
and
by
this
light
her
yellow
face
with
its
darkly
-

and

of
gray
hair
looked
as
handsome
as
was
necessary
for
picturesque
effect
.
<EOS>
Young
Mrs.
Cohen
was
clad
in
red
and
black
,
with
a
string
of
large
artificial
pearls
wound
round
and
round
her
neck
:
the
baby
lay
asleep
in
the

under
a

;
Adelaide
Rebekah
was
in
braided
amber
,
and
Jacob
Alexander
was
in
black
velveteen
with
scarlet
stockings
.
<EOS>
As
the
four
pairs
of
black
eyes
all
glistened
a
welcome
at
Deronda
,
he
was
almost
ashamed
of
the
supercilious
dislike
these
happy
-
looking
creatures
had
raised
in
him
by
daylight
.
<EOS>
Nothing
could
be
more
cordial
than
the
greeting
he
received
,
and
both
mother
and
grandmother
seemed
to
gather
more
dignity
from
being
seen
on
the
private
hearth
,
showing
hospitality
.
<EOS>
He
looked
round
with
some
wonder
at
the
old
furniture
:
the
oaken
bureau
and
high
side
-
table
must
surely
be
mere
matters
of
chance
and
economy
,
and
not
due
to
the
family
taste
.
<EOS>
A
large
dish
of
blue
and
yellow
ware
was
set
up
on
the
side
-
table
,
and
flanking
it
were
two
old
silver
vessels
;
in
front
of
them
a
large
volume
in
darkened
vellum
with
a
deep
-
ribbed
back
.
<EOS>
In
the
corner
at
the
farther
end
was
an
open
door
into
an
inner
room
,
where
there
was
also
a
light
.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
took
in
these
details
by
parenthetic
glances
while
he
met
Jacob
's
pressing
solicitude
about
the
knife
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken
the
pains
to
buy
one
with
the
requisites
of
the
hook
and
white
handle
,
and
produced
it
on
demand
,
saying
,
    
"
Is
that
the
sort
of
thing
you
want
,
Jacob
?
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
subjected
to
a
severe
scrutiny
,
the
hook
and
blades
were
opened
,
and
the
article
of
barter
with
the
cork
-
screw
was
drawn
forth
for
comparison
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
like
a
hook
better
than
a
cork
-
screw
?
"
said

"

him
to
give
his
greeting
before
the
summons
to
dinner
.
  
<EOS>
He
sat
not
far
from
opposite
to
her
at
table
,
and
could
sometimes

what
she
said
in
answer
to
Sir
Hugo
,
who
was
at
his
liveliest
in
conversation
with
her
;
but
though

looked

her
with
the

,
she
gave

doing

for
some

.
<EOS>
At
last

Hugo
,
who
might

that

,
said
,
"
Deronda
,
you
will

Mrs.

about
your
favorite
Klesmer
.
"
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's

had
been
lowered
,
and
Deronda
,
already
looking
at
her
,
thought

and
return

and

,
her
own

being
one
of
the

.
<EOS>
It

but

,
and
Sir
Hugo
continued
without
pause
    
<EOS>
"
The
Arrowpoints
have
condoned
the

,
and
he
is

with

Quetcham
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
suppose

for
the

his
wife
,
else
<EOS>
I
dare
say
he
would
not

minded
keeping

a
distance
,
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
It
's

,
"

Pentreath
,
an
easy

;
"
<EOS>
I
'm

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

'

,

,
after

,
"

Hugo
.
"
<EOS>

_

_

everybody

,

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

was

's
men
,
you
know
 
<EOS>
a
doctor
's

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

_

"

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
But

,
"

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>
"
Do

"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

"

"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"

Amen
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Klesmer

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
His

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,
having
a

against
Klesmer
in

.
<EOS>
Deronda
was
wondering
what

:

,

.
<EOS>
But

?
  
<EOS>
Sir

,

,

,
"
Is

a

?
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
There

,

.
<EOS>
Else

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"
  
<EOS>
"

"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
The

was
in

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen

,

.

's

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
<EOS>

?
"

,

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Grandcourt

<EOS>

<EOS>

?

"
<EOS>
Not

"

,

<EOS>
One

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

Offendene
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said
Sir
Hugo
,
and

let

.
  
<EOS>
What
amiable
baronet
can
escape
the
effect
of
a
strong
desire
for
a
particular

?
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
would
have

,

,

Diplow
;

's

this

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
much

's

,

,

to
Lady

,

for

had
married

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
had
not

this

,
having
given

elsewhere
,
but

he
had
of

's

deepened

had
something

.
  
<EOS>
Later
,

the

-

,

,

's

,

.
<EOS>
Afterward
,
Mrs.
Raymond
took

;
and
on

observed
that
Gwendolen
had
left
her

,
and
had

this

,
as

fully
,
but

,

a
fine

head

in

which
hung

.
<EOS>
He
longed
to
go
to
her
and

.
<EOS>
Why
should
he
not
obey
such
an
impulse
,
as
he
would

?
<EOS>
Yet
he
hesitated
some

,
observing
the

of
her
back
,
but
not

.
  
<EOS>
If
you
have
any
reason
for
not
indulging

wish
to
speak
to
a
fair
woman
,
it
is

bad
plan
to
look
long

her
back
:
the
wish
to
see
what
it
screens
becomes
the
stronger
.
<EOS>
There
may
be
a
very

on
the

.
<EOS>
Deronda
ended
by
going
to
the
end

the
small

,
at
right
angles
to
Gwendolen
's
position
,
but

she
had
turned

no

,
but
such

,
so
utterly
different
from
the
chill

of
her
recognition
at
table
,
that
his
speech
was
checked
.
<EOS>
For

an
appreciative
space
of
time
to
both
,
though
the

of
others
could
not
have
measured

,

at

other
 
she
seeming
to
take
the
deep
rest
of
confession
,
<EOS>
he
with
an

depth
of
sympathy
that
neutralized
all

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will
you
not
join
in
the
music
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
by
way
of
meeting
the

.
  
<EOS>
That
her

of
confession
had
been
involuntary
was

by
that
just
perceptible

and

,
"
I
join

by

.
<EOS>
I
am

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Are
you
not

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
given
a
great
deal

to

.
<EOS>
But
I
have
not

to
make

.
<EOS>
I
shall

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

are

,

private
,
for
your

.
<EOS>
I
make
it
a
virtue
to
be

with
my
middlingness
,
"
said
Deronda
,
smiling
;
"
it
is
always
pardonable
,
so
that
one
does
not
ask
others
to
take
it
for
superiority
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
can
not
imitate
you
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
recovering
her
tone
of
artificial
vivacity
.
<EOS>
"
To
be
middling
with
me
is
another
phrase
for
being
dull
.
<EOS>
And
the
worst
fault
I
have
to
find
with
the
world
is
,
that
it
is
dull
.
<EOS>
Do
you
know
,
I
am
going
to
justify
gambling
in
spite
of
you
.
<EOS>
It
is
a
refuge
from
dullness
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
admit
the
justification
,
"
said
Deronda
.
<EOS>
"
I
think
what
we
call
the
dullness
of
things
is
a
disease
in
ourselves
.
<EOS>
Else
how
can
any
one
find
an
intense
interest
in
life
?
<EOS>
And
many
do
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
I
see
!
<EOS>
The
fault
I
find
in
the
world
is
my
own
fault
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
smiling
at
him
.
<EOS>
Then
after
a
moment
,
looking
up
at
the
ivory
again
,
she
said
,
"
Do
_
you
_
never
find
fault
with
the
world
or
with
others
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
.
<EOS>
When
I
am
in
a
grumbling
mood
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
And
hate
people
?
<EOS>
Confess
you
hate
them
when
they
stand
in
your
way
 
when
their
gain
is
your
loss
?
<EOS>
That
is
your
own
phrase
,
you
know
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
We
are
often
standing
in
each
other
's
way
when
we
ca
n't
help
it
.
<EOS>
I
think
it
is
stupid
to
hate
people
on
that
ground
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But
if
they
injure
you
and
could
have
helped
it
?
"
said
Gwendolen
with
a
hard
intensity
unaccountable
in
incidental
talk
like
this
.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
wondered
at
her
choice
of
subjects
.
<EOS>
A
painful
impression
arrested
his
answer
a
moment
,
but
at
last
he
said
,
with
a
graver
,
deeper
intonation
,
"
Why
,
then
,
after
all
,
I
prefer
my
place
to
theirs
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
There
I
believe
you
are
right
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
with
a
sudden
little
laugh
,
and
turned
to
join
the
group
at
the
piano
.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
looked
around
for
Grandcourt
,
wondering
whether
he
followed
his
bride
's
movements
with
any
attention
;
but
it
was
rather
undiscerning
to
him
to
suppose
that
he
could
find
out
the
fact
.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
had
a
delusive
mood
of
observing
whatever
had
an
interest
for
him
,
which
could
be
surpassed
by
no
sleepy
-
eyed
animal
on
the
watch
for
prey
.
<EOS>
At
that
moment
he
was
plunged
in
the
depth
of
an
easy
chair
,
being
talked
to
by
Mr.
Vandernoodt
,
who
apparently
thought
the
acquaintance
of
such
a
bridegroom
worth
cultivating
;
and
an
incautious
person
might
have
supposed
it
safe
to
telegraph
secrets
in
front
of
him
,
the
common
prejudice
being
that
your
quick
observer
is
one
whose
eyes
have
quick
movements
.
<EOS>
Not
at
all
.
<EOS>
If
you
want
a
respectable
witness
who
will
see
nothing
inconvenient
,
choose
a
vivacious
gentleman
,
very
much
on
the
alert
,
with
two
eyes
wide
open
,
a
glass
in
one
of
them
,
and
an
entire
impartiality
as
to
the
purpose
of
looking
.
<EOS>
If
Grandcourt
cared
to
keep
any
one
under
his
power
he
saw
them
out
of
the
corners
of
his
long
narrow
eyes
,
and
if
they
went
behind
him
he
had
a
constructive
process
by
which
he
knew
what
they
were
doing
there
.
<EOS>
He
knew
perfectly
well
where
his
wife
was
,
and
how
she
was
behaving
.
<EOS>
Was
he
going
to
be
a
jealous
husband
?
<EOS>
Deronda
imagined
that
to
be
likely
;
but
his
imagination
was
as
much
astray
about
Grandcourt
as
it
would
have
been
about
an
unexplored
continent
where
all
the
species
were
peculiar
.
<EOS>
He
did
not
conceive
that
he
himself
was
a
likely
subject
of
jealousy
,
or
that
he
should
give
any
pretext
for
it
;
but
the
suspicion
that
a
wife
is
not
happy
naturally
leads
one
to
speculate
on
the
husband
's
private
deportment
;
and
Deronda
found
himself
after
one
o'clock
in
the
morning
in
the
rather
ludicrous
position
of
sitting
up
severely
holding
a
Hebrew
grammar
in
his
hands
(
for
somehow
,
in
deference
to
Mordecai
,
he
had
begun
to
study
Hebrew
)
,
with
the
consciousness
that
he
had
been
in
that
attitude
nearly
an
hour
,
and
had
thought
of
nothing
but
Gwendolen
and
her
husband
.
<EOS>
To
be
an
unusual
young
man
means
for
the
most
part
to
get
a
difficult
mastery
over
the
usual
,
which
is
often
like
the
sprite
of
ill
-
luck
you
pack
up
your
goods
to
escape
from
,
and
see
grinning
at
you
from
the
top
of
your
luggage
van
.
<EOS>
The
peculiarities
of
Deronda
's
nature
had
been
acutely
touched
by
the
brief
incident
and
words
which
made
the
history
of
his
intercourse
with
Gwendolen
;
and
this
evening
's
slight
addition
had
given
them
an
importunate
recurrence
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
vanity
 
<EOS>
it
was
ready
sympathy
that
had
made
him
alive
to
a
certain
appealingness
in
her
behavior
toward
him
;
and
the
difficulty
with
which
she
had
seemed
to
raise
her

to
bow
to
him
,
in
the
first
instance
,
was
to
be
interpreted
now
by
that
unmistakable
look
of
involuntary
confidence
which
she
had
afterward
turned
on
him
under
the
consciousness
of
his
approach
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
use
of
it
all
?
"
thought
Deronda
,
as
he
threw
down
his
grammar
,
and
began
to
undress
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
do
anything
to
help
her
 
nobody
can
,
if
she
has
found
out
her
mistake
already
.
<EOS>
And
it
seems
to
me
that
she
has
a
dreary
lack
of
the
ideas
that
might
help
her
.
<EOS>
Strange
and
piteous
to
human
flesh
like
that
might
be
,
wrapped
round
with
fine
raiment
,
her
ears
pierced
for
gems
,
her
head
held
loftily
,
her
mouth
all
smiling

,
the
poor
soul
within
her
sitting
in
sick
distaste
of
all
things
!
<EOS>
But
what
do
I
know
of
her
?
<EOS>
There
may
be
a
demon
in
her
to
match
the
worst
husband
,
for
what
I
can
tell
.
<EOS>
She
was
clearly
an
ill
-
educated
,
worldly
girl
:
perhaps
she
is
a
coquette
.
"
  
<EOS>
This
last
reflection
,
not
much
believed
in
,
was
a
self
-
administered
dose
of
caution
,
prompted
partly
by
Sir
Hugo
's
much
-
contemned
joking
on
the
subject
of
flirtation
.
<EOS>
Deronda
resolved
not
to
volunteer
any
_
tete
-
à
-
tete
_
with
Gwendolen
during
the
days
of
her
stay
at
the
Abbey
;
and
he
was
capable
of
keeping
a
resolve
in
spite
of
much
inclination
to
the
contrary
.
  
<EOS>
But
a
man
can
not
resolve
about
a
woman
's
actions
,
least
of
all
about
those
of
a
woman
like
Gwendolen
,
in
whose
nature
there
was
a
combination
of
proud
reserve
with
rashness
,
of
perilously
poised
terror
with
defiance
,
which
might
alternately
flatter
and
disappoint
control
.
<EOS>
Few
words
could
less
represent
her
than
"
coquette
.
"
<EOS>
She
had
native
love
of
homage
,
and
belief
in
her
own
power
;
but
no
cold
artifice
for
the
sake
of
enslaving
.
<EOS>
And
the
poor
thing
's
belief
in
her
power
,
with
her
other
dreams
before
marriage
,
had
often
to
be
thrust
aside
now
like
the
toys
of
a
sick
child
,
which
it
looks
at
with
dull
eyes
,
and
has
no
heart
to
play
with
,
however
it
may
try
.
  
<EOS>
The
next
day
at
lunch
Sir
Hugo
said
to
her
,
"
The
thaw
has
gone
on
like
magic
,
and
it
's
so
pleasant
out
of
doors
just
now
 
<EOS>
shall
we
go
and
see
the
stables
and
the
other
odd
bits
about
the
place
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
Yes
,
pray
,
"
said
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
"
You
will
like
to
see
the
stables
,
Henleigh
?
"
<EOS>
she
added
,
looking
at
her
husband
.
  
<EOS>
"
Uncommonly
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
with
an
indifference
which
seemed
to
give
irony
to
the
word
,
as
he
returned
her
look
.
<EOS>
It
was
the
first
time
Deronda
had
seen
them
speak
to
each
other
since
their
arrival
,
and
he
thought
their
exchange
of
looks
as
cold
or
official
as
if
it
had
been
a
ceremony
to
keep
up
a
charter
.
<EOS>
Still
,
the
English
fondness
for
reserve
will
account
for
much
negation
;
and
Grandcourt
's
manners
with
an
extra
veil
of
reserve
over
them
might
be
expected
to
present
the
extreme
type
of
the
national
taste
.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
else
is
inclined
to
make
the
tour
of
the
house
and
premises
?
"
said
Sir
Hugo
.
<EOS>
"
The
ladies
must
muffle
themselves
;
there
is
only
just
about
time
to
do
it
well
before
sunset
.
<EOS>
You
will
go
,
Dan
,
wo
n't
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
yes
,
"
said
Deronda
,
carelessly
,
knowing
that
Sir
Hugo
would
think
any
excuse
disobliging
.
  
<EOS>
"
All
meet
in
the
library
,
then
,
when
they
are
ready
 
say
in
half
an
hour
,
"
said
the
baronet
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
made
herself
ready
with
wonderful
quickness
,
and
in
ten
minutes
came
down
into
the
library
in
her
sables
,
plume
,
and
little
thick
boots
.
<EOS>
As
soon
as
she
entered
the
room
she
was
aware
that
some
one
else
was
there
:
it
was
precisely
what
she
had
hoped
for
.
<EOS>
Deronda
was
standing
with
his
back
toward
her
at
the
far
end
of
the
room
,
and
was
looking
over
a
newspaper
.
<EOS>
How
could
little
thick
boots
make
any
noise
on
an
Axminster
carpet
?
<EOS>
And
to
cough
would
have
seemed
an
intended
signaling
which
her
pride
could
not
condescend
to
;
also
,
she
felt
bashful
about
walking
up
to
him
and
letting
him
know
that
she
was
there
,
though
it
was
her
hunger
to
speak
to
him
which
had
set
her
imagination
on
constructing
this
chance
of
finding
him
,
and
had
made
her
hurry
down
,
as
birds
hover
near
the
water
which
they
dare
not
drink
.
<EOS>
Always
uneasily
dubious
about
his
opinion
of
her
,
she
felt
a
peculiar
anxiety
to
-
day
,
lest
he
might
think
of
her
with
contempt
,
as
one
triumphantly
conscious
of
being
Grandcourt
's
wife
,
the
future
lady
of
this
domain
.
<EOS>
It
was
her
habitual
effort
now
to
magnify
the
satisfactions
of
her
pride
,
on
which
she
nourished
her
strength
;
but
somehow
Deronda
's
being
there
disturbed
them
all
.
<EOS>
There
was
not
the
faintest
touch
of
coquetry
in
the
attitude
of
her
mind
toward
him
:
he
was
unique
to
her
among
men
,
because
he
had
impressed
her
as
being
not
her
admirer
but
her
superior
:
in
some
mysterious
way
he
was
becoming
a
part
of
her
conscience
,
as
one
woman
whose
nature
is
an
object
of
reverential
belief
may
become
a
new
conscience
to
a
man
.
  
<EOS>
And
now
he
would
not
look
round
and
find
out
that
she
was
there
!
<EOS>
The
paper
crackled
in
his
hand
,
his
head
rose
and
sank
,
exploring
those
stupid
columns
,
and
he
was
evidently
stroking
his
beard
;
as
if
this
world
were
a
very
easy
affair
to
her
.
<EOS>
Of
course
all
the
rest
of
the
company
would
soon
be
down
,
and
the
opportunity
of
her
saying
something
to
efface
her
flippancy
of
the
evening
before
,
would
be
quite
gone
.
<EOS>
She
felt
sick
with
irritation
 
<EOS>
so
fast
do
young
creatures
like
her
absorb
misery
through
invisible
suckers
of
their
own
fancies
 
and
her
face
had
gathered
that
peculiar
expression
which
comes
with
a
mortification
to
which
tears
are
forbidden
.
  
<EOS>
At
last
he
threw
down
the
paper
and
turned
round
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
you
are
there
already
,
"
he
said
,
coming
forward
a
step
or
two
:
"
I
must
go
and
put
on
my
coat
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
turned
aside
and
walked
out
of
the
room
.
<EOS>
This
was
behaving
quite
badly
.
<EOS>
Mere
politeness
would
have
made
him
stay
to
exchange
some
words
before
leaving
her
alone
.
<EOS>
It
was
true
that
Grandcourt
came
in
with
Sir
Hugo
immediately
after
,
so
that
the
words
must
have
been
too
few
to
be
worth
anything
.
<EOS>
As
it
was
,
they
saw
him
walking
from
the
library
door
.
  
<EOS>
"
A
 
you
look
rather
ill
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
going
straight
up
to
her
,
standing
in
front
of
her
,
and
looking
into
her
eyes
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Do
you
feel
equal
to
the
walk
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
shall
like
it
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
without
the
slightest
movement
except
this
of
the
lips
.
  
<EOS>
"
We
could
put
off
going
over
the
house
,
you
know
,
and
only
go
out
of
doors
,
"
said
Sir
Hugo
,
kindly
,
while
Grandcourt
turned
aside
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
dear
no
!
<EOS>
"
said
Gwendolen
,
speaking
with
determination
;
"
let
us
put
off
nothing
.
<EOS>
I
want
a
long
walk
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
rest
of
the
walking
party
 
two
ladies
and
two
gentlemen
besides
Deronda
 
had
now
assembled
;
and
Gwendolen
rallying
,
went
with
due
cheerfulness
by
the
side
of
Sir
Hugo
,
paying
apparently
an
equal

to
the
commentaries
Deronda
was
called
upon
to
give
on
the
various

,
to
Sir
Hugo
's
reasons
for
not
attempting
to
remedy
the
mixture
of
the
undisguised
modern
with
the
antique
 
which
in

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
and

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
Oh
,

!
"
<EOS>

:

,

:

,

.
<EOS>

is

:

-

.
<EOS>
Deronda

;

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do

to

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
said

,

.
<EOS>
He
had

,

;

,

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

,

,

"

"

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
The
poor

had
passed

of

in
marriage
 
of

present

to
what

.
<EOS>
For

to

,
and
fills

.
<EOS>
Her

,

,
had
told
on
Grandcourt
during

,
and
formed

such

<EOS>

<EOS>
but

.
  
<EOS>
What

and
her
wearing

.
<EOS>
One

,

<EOS>

:

.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt

<EOS>
"
Am

?
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
That

Of

?
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

nothing

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>
Deronda

,

.
  
<EOS>
"

when

would
demand
her
utmost
splendor
.
<EOS>
Determined
to
wear
the
memorial
necklace
<EOS>
somehow
,
she
wound
it
thrice
<EOS>
round
her
wrist
and
made
a
bracelet
of
it
 
having
gone
to
her
room
to
put
it
on
just
before
the
time
of
entering
the
ball
-
room
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
always
a
beautiful
scene
,
this
dance
on
New
Year
's
Eve
,
which
had
been
kept
up
by
the
family
tradition
as
nearly
in
the
old
fashion
as
inexorable
change
would
allow
.
<EOS>
Red
carpet
was
laid
down
for
the
occasion
:
hot
-
house
plants
and
evergreens
were
arranged
in

at
the

and
in

;
and
the
old

stretching
back
through

,
even

the
pre

period
,
made
a

of

.
<EOS>
Some

gentry
,
major
and
minor
,
were
invited
;
and
it
was
certainly
an
occasion
when
a
prospective
master
and
mistress
of
Abbott
's
and
King
's
Topping
might
see
their
future

in
an

,
as
a
picturesque
provincial
supremacy
with
a
rent
-

personified
by
the
most
prosperous
-

.
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
expected
Grandcourt
to
feel
flattered
by
being
asked
to
the
Abbey
at
a
time
which
included
this
festival
in

of
the
family

;
but
he

that
his
own

might
impress

with
the
probable

time

and
with
the

preferring

to
a
minor

that
must

.
<EOS>
All
present
,
down
to
the
least
important
farmer
's
daughter
,
knew

they
were
to
see
"
young
Grandcourt
,
"
Sir
Hugo
's
nephew
,
the
presumptive

and

,
now

;
any

between

,

,

.
<EOS>
The
bride
opening
the
ball
with
Sir
Hugo
was
necessarily
the
cynosure
of
all

;
and
less

a
year
before
,
if
some

have

Gwendolen
her
actual
position
,
she
would
have
imagined

moving
in

with

,
conscious
that
she
held
in
her

a
life
full
of
favorable
chances
which
her
cleverness
and
spirit
would
enable
her
to
make
the
best
of
.
<EOS>
And
now
she
was
wondering
that
she
could
get
so
little

the

to

had

,
away

of
her

with
its

of

and

.
<EOS>
She
would
have
been
glad
to
be
even

,
and
to

everything
but
the
flattery
of
the
moment
;
but
she
was
like
one

,

insist
like

.
  
<EOS>
Wondering
in

at
her

,
and

an

that
would
deaden

aches
,
she
was
passing
through
files
of
admiring
beholders
in
the
country
-

with

was
traditional
to
open

ball
,
and
was
being
generally

her
own

as
an
enviable

.
<EOS>
It
was
remarked
that
she
carried

with
a
wonderful
air
,
considering
that
she
had
been
nobody
in
particular
,
and
without
a

to
her

.
<EOS>
If

had
been
a

's

,

,
she
could

.
<EOS>
Poor
Gwendolen
!
<EOS>
It
would
by
-
and
-

to

.
  
<EOS>
The

were

.
<EOS>
Lady
Pentreath
had
said
,
"
I
shall
stand

,

.
<EOS>
Mr.

,

.
<EOS>
Nobody

.
<EOS>
I

contrast
.
"
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
She
was
one

,

to

.
<EOS>
What

seemed

in

,
had

which
defied

,
and
was
set
off
by
a

;
her

-

was
well

with
black

,
her

and

comfortably

,
showing
none

which

think

.
<EOS>
She

enough
,
her

with

.
<EOS>
Her

's
young

of

against

of

had

something

fine

against

.
<EOS>
Perhaps
the
tenants
hardly
appreciated
this
pair
.
<EOS>
Lady
Pentreath
was
nothing
more
than
a
straight
,
active
old
lady
:
Mr.
Deronda
was
a
familiar
figure
regarded

;
but
if
he
had
been

,
it
would
have
been
regretted
that
his
face
was
not

English
as
Sir
Hugo
's
.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
's

when
he
came

with
Lady
Mallinger
was
not

:
still

in

.
<EOS>
It
would
have

if
one
who
had
the

to
inherit
two
old
family

had
had

,

,

;
but
that
fine

,

of

,
was

.
<EOS>
It
was

that
Mr.
Grandcourt
could
never

what
he
was
 
a

;
and
that
,

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

,

going

with

of

as

,

,

,

's

.
<EOS>
But

from

,

her
full

.
<EOS>
All

held
it
a

not

a
fine
boy
,
or
even
several
 
which

expected
,
to

when

.
  
<EOS>
The

included
only

,

fourth
being

as

:

,

,
while

was
less

,

.
<EOS>
Later

the

Gwendolen
was
in

,
and
Grandcourt
was

.
<EOS>
They

:
she

,
and
he
against

;

,

.
<EOS>
Having

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt

;

.
<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
had
been

_
ennui
_

,
and

:

not

.
<EOS>
She

,

.
<EOS>
But

had

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
;
I

not

.
<EOS>
Are

?
"
<EOS>
she

,

"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"
said

,
"

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
But

,

?
"
  
<EOS>
It

but

that

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
was
wrapped
in
the
lightest
,

of

,

.
<EOS>
While

,

,
and

,

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
saw

,

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

?
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
That
?
"

,

,

,

;
"

I

.
<EOS>
I

,

someone

.
"
  
<EOS>
With

,

,
and
on

said
,

<EOS>
"
It

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
should

.
<EOS>
Will

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
He

,

,
"
No
,
Deronda
will

,
"
slowly

,

.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
face
for
a
moment
showed
a
fleeting

:
she
resented
this
show
of
indifference
toward
her
.
<EOS>
Deronda
felt
annoyed
,
chiefly
for
her

;
and
with

,
that
it
would

her
most
to
behave

,
he
said
,
"
Will

take

and
go
,
while
only

there
?
"
<EOS>
He
thought
that
he
understood
well
her
action
in
drawing

to

:
she
wished
him
to
infer
that
she
had

to
rebuke
 
<EOS>
her
speech

had
from

that

and
that
she

no

.
<EOS>
Her
evident
confidence
in
his
interpretation
of
her
appealed
to

as

.
  
<EOS>
When

were

together
,
Gwendolen
felt
as
if
the

which
had
just

had

another

from
between

,
and
she

.
<EOS>
She

,
being

of
silent

,
until

were
in

the

.
<EOS>
A
sort

bower
had
been
made

,
turning

into

.
<EOS>
Quitting
his

,
she
folded
her
hands
in
her
burnous
,
and
pressed
her

against

glass
.
<EOS>
He
moved
slightly
away
,
and
held
the
lapels
of
his
coat
with
his
thumbs
under
the
collar
as
his
manner
was
:
he
had
a
wonderful
power
of
standing
perfectly
still
,
and
in
that
position
reminded
one
sometimes
of
Dante
's
_
spiriti

con

_
.
<EOS>
(
Doubtless
some
of
these
danced
in
their

,
doubted
of
their
own
vocation
,
and
found
their
own
times
too
modern
.
)
<EOS>
He
abstained
from
remarking
on
the
scene
before
them
,
fearing
that
any
indifferent
words
might
jar
on
her
:
already
the
calm
light
and
shadow
,
the
ancient
steadfast
forms
,
and
aloofness
enough
from
those
inward
troubles
which
he
felt
sure
were
agitating
her
.
<EOS>
And
he
judged
aright
:
she
would
have
been
impatient
of
polite

.
<EOS>
The
incidents
of
the
last
minute
or
two
had
receded
behind
former
thoughts
which
she
had
imagined
herself
uttering
to
Deronda
,
which
now
urged
themselves
to
her
lips
.
<EOS>
In
a
subdued
voice
,
she
said
    
"
Suppose
I
had
gambled
again
,
and
lost
the
necklace
again
,
what
should
you
have
thought
of
me
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Worse
than
I
do
now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
are
mistaken
about
me
.
<EOS>
You
wanted
me
not
to
do
that
 
not
to
make
my
gain
out
of
another
's
loss
in
that
way
 
<EOS>
and
I
have
done
a
great
deal
worse
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
imagine
temptations
,
"
said
Deronda
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
I
am
able
to
understand
what
you
mean
.
<EOS>
At
least
I
understand
self
-

.
<EOS>
"
In

was

at

's
precipitancy
of
confidence

,
in

.
  
<EOS>
"
What

do

were

me
 
<EOS>
feeling
that

were
wrong
and

,
and
dreading

to

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
It

that
she
was

speak

.
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
but
many
,
"
said
Deronda
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
What
?
"

,

,

from

.
  
<EOS>
He
looked
full

in

,

what

.
<EOS>
He
felt
that

not

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean

many

may

to
bear

sorrow
.
<EOS>
Multitudes
have
to
bear
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
She
turned
her

to
the
window
again
,
and
said

,
"
You
must

what

;
else
why
did

doing

I

not
minding
?
<EOS>
If
I

gambling
I
might
have
won

,

I
might
have
got
not

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Why
should

I
do
as
I

,

not

?
<EOS>
Other

do
.
"
<EOS>
Poor
Gwendolen
's
speech
expressed
nothing

clearly
except
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do
n't
believe
you
would
ever
get
not
to
mind
,
"
said
Deronda
,
with
deep

.
<EOS>
"
If

were

that
baseness
and

made

,
what

would

ca
n't

?
<EOS>
Idiots

some

;
but
you
ca

an

.
<EOS>
Some
may

;
but

?
<EOS>
I
believe
you
could
never

life
 
<EOS>
all
reckless

are
injurious
,
pestilential
 
without
feeling

.
<EOS>
"
Deronda
's
unconscious

had

on
:
he
was

he

used

.
  
<EOS>
"
Then

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Many

.
<EOS>
Look

.
<EOS>
See

,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
Try

is
best

something

.
"
  
<EOS>
For

.
<EOS>
Then

,

"
You

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He

firmly
 
"
You
will

being
selfish

!
"
  
<EOS>
She

that

.

<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
When

,
"
Sit

.
<EOS>
"
She
,

burnous

,

.
<EOS>
Turning

,

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
If

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

,
her

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

.
<EOS>
Keep

.
"
<EOS>
Grandcourt

,

.
<EOS>
"

I

.
<EOS>
Only

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

,

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
And

to

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
You

.
<EOS>
Behave

.
<EOS>
That

<EOS>
"

Grandcourt
rose
,

.
<EOS>
She
was

.
<EOS>
There

no

that

fling

.
<EOS>
What

would
least

the
making

and
being

.
<EOS>
It

to

that
Deronda
too
had
only
been
a
monitor
 
the
strongest
of
all

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
was
contemptuous
,
not

;
contemptuously
certain
of
all

.
<EOS>
Why
could

?
<EOS>
She

.
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>

,
that
could

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

of
his

kept

.
  
<EOS>
"
Shall
I
ring
?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
he

,

.
<EOS>
She

her

,
and

to

-

.
  
<EOS>
Certain

were

within

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
wrong
you
have
done

will
be
your
own

.
"
<EOS>
As

closed

,

,

provoked
an

:
"
Why
did

?
<EOS>
"
It

in

,

.
<EOS>
But
she
immediately
pressed
her

against

,
and
checked

.
  
<EOS>
The
next
day
,

,

,

;

,

,
which
was
now

.
<EOS>
Not
toward
Deronda
himself
 
she
was
singularly
free
from
alarm
lest
he
should
think
her
openness
wanting
in
dignity
<EOS>
:
it
was

power

that

as

;

,

.
<EOS>
But

came
,
and

never

dropped

,
and

without

.
<EOS>
She

were
to

.
<EOS>
It

too

that

in

's

,

.
<EOS>
Grandcourt

,

-

;

;

,

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

,

.
<EOS>
She

,

;

,

;

<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>

The

of

,

ajar
.
<EOS>
She
pushed

,

looked

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

(

,

Hugo

)
.
<EOS>
An

,

,

as

have

.
<EOS>
It

to

in
 
too

;

she

in

,

,

,

,
pushed

,

to

for

,

,
"
Mr.
Deronda
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was
certainly

.
<EOS>
He
rose
hastily
,
turned
round
,
and
pushed

chair
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
Am

?
"
said

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
thought

were
far

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
turned

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you

to
go

?
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
want
to

something
,
and
I
ca
n't
stay

,
"
said

,
speaking

perhaps

"

duty
 
if

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
Many

He

<EOS>
To

A

<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
Mordecai

.
<EOS>
Thus

Being

<EOS>
The

's

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

's

<EOS>

<EOS>

,

;

<EOS>

;

,

.
<EOS>
The

;

"

.
  
<EOS>
Of

,

,

's

.
<EOS>

,

?
<EOS>
The

's

must
be
near
 
the

's

the
best
heritage
of
his
people
.
<EOS>
An
insane
exaggeration
of
his
own
value
,
even

had
been
as
true

of

,
many

,
"
<EOS>
If

,
"

the

.
<EOS>
But

desires
to

.
<EOS>

"

will

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
  
<EOS>
Withering

;
  
The

<EOS>

,

In

<EOS>
There

<EOS>
Shatter

"

"

.
"

But

;

.
<EOS>
Deronda

to

.

,

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
In
the
January
weeks
,
he
felt
an
increasing
agitation
of
that
subdued
hidden
quality
which
hinders
nervous
people
from
any
steady
occupation
on
the
eve
of
an
anticipated
change
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
go
on
with
his
printing
of
Hebrew
on
little
Jacob
's
mind
;
or
with
his
attendance
at
a
weekly
club
,
which
was
another
effort
of
the
same
forlorn
hope
:
something
else
was
coming
.
<EOS>
The
one
thing
he
longed
for
was
to
get
as
far
as
the
river
,
which
he
could
do
but
seldom
and
with
difficulty
.
<EOS>
He
yearned
with
a
poet
's
yearning
for
the
wide
sky
,
the
far
-
reaching
vista
of
bridges
,
the
tender
and
fluctuating
lights
on
the
water
which
seems
to
breathe
with
a
life
that
can
shiver
and
mourn
,
be
comforted
and
rejoice
.
      
<EOS>
"
Vor
den
Wissenden
sich
stellen
  
<EOS>
Sicher
ist
's
in
alien
Fällen
!
  
<EOS>
Wenn
du
lange
dich
gequälet
  
<EOS>
Weiss
er
gleich
wo
dir

fehlet
;
  
<EOS>
Auch
auf
Beifall
darfst
du
hoffen
,
  
<EOS>
Denn
er
weiss
wo
du
's
getroffen
,
"
             
<EOS>
GOETHE
:
<EOS>
_
West
-
östlicker
Divan
_
.
   
<EOS>
Momentous
things
happened
to
Deronda
the
very

of
that
visit
to
the

Chelsea
,
when

the

about
Mirah
's

.
<EOS>
But

there
,

chief
sequence
connected
with
it
<EOS>
occurred
two
days
afterward
.
<EOS>
About
four
o'clock
wheels
paused
before
the
door
,
and
there
came
one
of
those

with

ring
which
serve
to
magnify
the
sense
of
social
existence
in
a

where
the
most

are
usually

of

.
<EOS>
All
the
girls
were
at

,
and

were

Kate
's
drawing
,
as
well

a
great
length
of
embroidery
which
had

of

satin

a

_

_

,

.
<EOS>
It

room
picturesquely

,

Meyrick
bending

,
Mab

,

.
<EOS>
Mirah
,

,

.
<EOS>

,
"
The

-

,
"

"

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
Dear

!
"

;
"

?
<EOS>

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Hans

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

,

"

.
<EOS>
"

!
"
  
<EOS>
The

were
all

a

respected

tall

Julius

_
.
  
<EOS>
Even

could
hardly
have
made
the
"

mother
"
awkward
,

her

she
was

,
and

;

.
<EOS>
But

,
the

,

,
Mab

,
seemed
a

,

as

.
<EOS>
Klesmer
's
personality
,
especially
his
way
of
glancing
round
him
,
immediately
suggested
vast
areas
and
a
multitudinous
audience
,
and
probably

made
the
usual
scenery
of
his
consciousness
,
for
we
all
of
us
carry
on
our
thinking
in
some

where
there
is
a
presence
of
other
souls
,
and
those
who
take
in
a
larger
sweep
than
their
neighbors
are
apt
to
seem
mightily

and
affected
.
<EOS>
Klesmer
was
vain
,
but
not
more
so
than
many
contemporaries
of
heavy
aspect
,
whose
vanity
leaps
out
and

like

a

-
stick
;
as
to
his
carriage
and

,
these
were

the

his

;
and
the
rankest

he
could
have
shown
would
have
been
to

and

.
<EOS>
While
his
grandiose
air
was
making
Mab
feel
herself
a
ridiculous

to
match
the
cottage
piano
,
he
was
taking
in

details

a

.
<EOS>
He
remembered
a
home
no

on

;
and
in
the
figurative
Bohemia

he

large

with

.
<EOS>
He

Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
Being

,

.
<EOS>

here
 
Miss

.
"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
Mab

.
<EOS>
Mrs.

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Klesmer

.
<EOS>
And

adorable
:
"
as

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

we

meet
again
.
<EOS>
But

?
"

<EOS>
"

"

"

"
  
<EOS>

REVELATIONS
      
<EOS>
"

ARISTOTLE
:
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
Poetics
_
.
   
<EOS>
Imagine
the
conflict
in
a
mind
like
<EOS>
Deronda
's
given
not
only
to
feel
strongly
but

question
actively
,
on
the

after

.
<EOS>
To
a

of
much

susceptibilities
the
adventure
might
have
seemed
enough
out
of
the
common

to
divide

;
but

had
stirred

so

,
that
with
the
usual
reaction
of
his
intellect
he
began
to
examine
the
grounds
of
his
emotion
,
and
consider
how
far
he
must
resist
its
guidance
.
<EOS>
The
consciousness
that
he
was
half
dominated
by
Mordecai
's

,
and
still
more

his

,
roused
his

.
<EOS>
It
was
his
characteristic
bias
to
shrink
from
the
moral
stupidity
of
valuing
<EOS>
lightly
what
had
come
close
to
him
,
and
of
missing
blindly
in
his
own
life
of
to
-
day
the
crisis
which
he
recognized
as
momentous
and
sacred
in
the
historic

of
men
.
<EOS>
If

had
read

this

as

in

,

,
Asia
Minor
,
Palestine
,

,

,

to

for

,
whose

an

through

.
<EOS>
Why
should

be
ashamed
of
his
own
agitated
feeling
merely

dressed
for

,

,
and
lived
among

who
might

any
conscience
in
the
matter
,
as
the
solemn

of
taking

?
 
<EOS>
that
bugbear
of
circles
in
which
the
lack
of
grave
emotion
passes
for
wit
.
<EOS>
From
such
cowardice
before
modish

and

,
Deronda
shrank
.
<EOS>
But
he
also
shrank
from
having

determined
by
mere

,
without

of

;
or
from

a

for

to
hurry

along
a
dimly
-

.
  
<EOS>
What
,
after
all
,
had
really

?
<EOS>
He
knew
quite
accurately
the
answer
Sir
Hugo
would

given
:
"
A
consumptive
Jew
,
possessed
by
a

which
obstacles
and
hastening
death
intensified
,
had
fixed

as

,
the

of
wedded

and

:
despair
of

own

,
irrepressible

in
the

.
<EOS>
The
instance
was
perhaps
odd
,
exceptional
in
its
form
,
but

was
not
rare
.
<EOS>
Fanaticism
was
not
so
common
as

,
but
taken
in
all
its
aspects
it
was
abundant
enough
.
<EOS>
While
Mordecai
was

for

,
another
man
was
convinced
that

had
the

,

,

.
<EOS>
Scattered

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

<EOS>
In

.
<EOS>
And

's

that

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
's
ear

;
nay

<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
We

"

.
<EOS>
Even

,

.
  
<EOS>
This

Mordecai
,

.
<EOS>
This

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Our

:

)
.
<EOS>
And

's

included
sensibilities
beyond
the
common
,
enlarged
by
his
early

of
thinking
himself
imaginatively
into

.
  
<EOS>
What
was

claim
this

?
 
<EOS>
"
You
must

my
beliefs
 
be

<EOS>
hope

see

I

to
 
behold

!
"
<EOS>
To

would

;

,

,

had

of

.
<EOS>
The
claim
hung
,
too
,
on
a
supposition
which
might
be
 
nay
,
probably
was
 
in
discordance
with
the

:
the
supposition
that
he
,
Deronda
,
was
of
Jewish
blood
.
<EOS>
Was

ever
a
more

appeal
?
  
<EOS>
But

the
age

had
associated
the
deepest
experience
of
his

with
what
was

,
namely
,
that
Sir
Hugo
was
his
father
<EOS>
:
that

a

had
been

within
him
;
by
its
light
he
had
been
accustomed
to
subdue

and
to

.
<EOS>
He
had
been
well
used
to

in

might

;
and

some

.
<EOS>
To

,
which
was

and

,
was

of

.
  
<EOS>
And
now
,

wish

belief
in
his

,

:

's

's

?
<EOS>

,

was

that

needed

that
,

,

from

's

lay

own
thought
like

some

yearned

but

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

was

would

industrious
so
far
as
a
poor
creature
can
be
,
and
takes
as
much

in
the
boy
as
anybody
could
.
<EOS>
But
this
last
day
or
two

's
been
moving
about
like
a
sleep

,
or
else

as

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
the
disease
,
poor

,
"
said
the
grandmother
,
tenderly
.
<EOS>
"
I
doubt

he
can
stand

against

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
<EOS>
;
I
think
its
only
something
he
's

in

.
"

Cohen

.
<EOS>
"
He
's

continually
,
and

it
takes

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

"

,

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
It

,

.
<EOS>
There

do
business

.
<EOS>
I

'

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh

"

.
  
<EOS>
"
He

,
"

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

,

<EOS>
"

,

<EOS>
I

<EOS>

.
"
<EOS>

<EOS>

"

himself

!
<EOS>
do

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Skillful

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

:

.
<EOS>
Mordecai
was

,

.
<EOS>
He

"

.
<EOS>
Are

?
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

,

,

!
<EOS>
"
sending

's

,

.
<EOS>

"

"

"

,

.

"
He

,

"

.

.

"
  
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

"
My

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

!
<EOS>

;

.
<EOS>
There

wo

.
"
<EOS>
Here

's

,
but

judicious

,
for

gave

about

,
"
Old

,

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
thought
,
"
I

never
know
anything
decisive
about

people
until

ask
Cohen
pointblank
whether
he
lost
a
sister
named
Mirah
when

was
six

old
.
<EOS>
"
The
decisive
moment
did
not
yet
seem
easy
for
him
to
face
.
<EOS>
Still
his
first
sense
of
repulsion
at
the

.
<EOS>
However

,

in

of
the
consumptive

,
whose

impressed

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
The

,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
And
I
for

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

,

as

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

,
"

,
"
by

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
 
yes
,

.
<EOS>
But

,
for

of

has

,
and
this

is

.
<EOS>
I
am
as

man
bound
and

long
years
:
<EOS>
behold
him

to
speech
of

:
<EOS>
he

,

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"
said
Deronda
,
feeling

's

of

like

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Cover
your
mouth
with

.
<EOS>
We

to
the
_
Hand

_
,

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

.
<EOS>
For

of
the
club
I

,
and

might

any

until

,
when

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

.
<EOS>
But
I

.
<EOS>
In
new

the
outer

presses

and
narrows

inward

.
<EOS>
And
the
people
there
are

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
do

,
"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
What

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

"
The

.
<EOS>
"
They
are
few
 
like
the
cedars
of
Lebanon
 
poor
men
given
to
thought
.
<EOS>
But
none
so
poor
as
I
am
:
and
sometimes

higher

rank
have

.
<EOS>
We
are
allowed
to
introduce
a

,
who
is

.
<EOS>
Each

or
some
other

,

.
<EOS>
Most

.
<EOS>
I
have
gone
when
I
could
,
for
there
are
other
men
of
my
race
who
come
,
and
sometimes
I
have
broken

.
<EOS>
I
have
pleased
myself
with
a
faint

between
these
poor

and

Masters
who
handed

race
 
the
great

,
who

,

the

,

Israel
alive
as

.
<EOS>
The
heart
pleases
itself

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall
be

,

.
<EOS>
It

I

like

,
"
said
Deronda
,
not
without

in
the
prospect
of
an
interval
before

went
through

of

next

.
  
<EOS>
In
three

they
had
opened
the
glazed
door
with
the
red

,
and
were
in
the
little
parlor
,
hardly
much
more
than
fifteen

square
,
where

shone
through

what

.
<EOS>
Half
-
a
-
dozen

of

,

and

,

,

with

in

,
were

intelligence
to
a
man

-

,
with

,
short

,

,
who
,

,

,
was
just

from
Shelley
(
the
comparison
of
the
avalanche
in
his
"
Prometheus
Unbound
"
)
    
<EOS>
"
As
thought
by
thought
is
piled
,
till
some
great
truth
  
Is
loosened
,
and
the
nations
echo
round
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
entrance
of
the
new
-
comers
broke
the
fixity
of
attention
,
and
called
for
re
-
arrangement
of
seats
in
the
too
narrow
semicircle
round
the
fire
-
place
and
the
table
holding
the
glasses
,
spare
pipes
and

.
<EOS>
This
was
the
soberest
of
clubs
;
but
sobriety
is
no
reason
why
smoking
and
"
taking
something
"
should
be
less
imperiously
needed
as
a

of
getting
a
decent
status
in
company
and

.
<EOS>
Mordecai
was
received
with
welcoming
voices
which
had
a
slight
cadence
of
compassion
in
them
,
but
naturally
all
glances
passed
immediately
to
his

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
have
brought
a
friend
who
is
interested

,
"
said
Mordecai
.
<EOS>
"
He
has
traveled
and

.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Is
the

anonymous
?
<EOS>
Is
he

Great
"
Unknown
?
"
<EOS>
"
said
the

-
chested
quoter
of
Shelley
,
with

.
  
<EOS>
"
My
name
is
Daniel
Deronda
.
<EOS>
I
am
unknown
,
but
not

any

great
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

breaking

stranger
's

as

was

,

"
Hear
,

,
"
and
<EOS>
the
broad

said
    
"
You
recommend

name
,

,

are

.
<EOS>
Here
,

,
come

against

,
"
he
added
,
evidently
wishing
to
give
the
coziest

to
the
one
who
most
needed

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
was
well
satisfied
to
get
a
seat
on
the
opposite
side
,
where
his
general
survey
of
the
party
easily
included
Mordecai
,
who
remained
an
eminently
striking
object
in
this
group
of
sharply
-
characterized
figures
,
more
than
one
of
whom
,
even
to
Daniel
's
little
exercised
discrimination
,
seemed
probably
of
Jewish
descent
.
  
<EOS>
In
fact
pure
English
blood
(
if
leech
or
lancet
can
furnish
us
with
the
precise
product
)
did
not
declare
itself
predominantly
in
the
party
at
present

.
<EOS>
Miller
,
the
broad
man
,
an
exceptional
second
-
hand
bookseller
who
knew
the

no
clearer
to
him
than
the
light
of
the
sun
to
our

in

,

.
<EOS>
What
wonder
that
multitudes
of

are

,
narrow
,

?
<EOS>
What
wonder
?
"
  
<EOS>
Here

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
What
wonder
?
<EOS>
The

unto

,
that

;

<EOS>

no

<EOS>

elation
about
themselves
reflected
in
other
minds
;
and
Gwendolen
,
with
her
youth
and
inward

,
may

for
dwelling
on
signs
of
special
interest
in
her
shown
by
the
one

who
had
impressed

with
the
feeling
of
submission
,
and
for
mistaking
the
color
and

of
those
signs
in
the

Deronda
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
,
what
would
he
tell

that
she

do
?
"
<EOS>
He
said
,
I

<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

<EOS>

was
a
great
singer
,
and
I
acted
as
well
as
I
sang
.
<EOS>
All
the
rest
were
poor
beside
me
.
<EOS>
Men
followed
me
from
one
country
to
another
.
<EOS>
I
was
living
a
myriad
lives
in
one
.
<EOS>
I
did
not
want
a
child
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
There
was
a
passionate
self
-
defence
in
her
tone
.
<EOS>
She
had
cast
all
precedent
out
of
her
mind
.
<EOS>
Precedent
had
no
excuse
for
her
<EOS>
and
she
could
only

in
the
intensest

she

for
her

.
<EOS>
She
seemed
to
fling

last
words
against
some
possible
reproach
in
the

of
her
son
,
who
had
to
stand

them
 
clutching
his
coat

as

were

above

by

,
and

his
blood
in

of
a

which
gave

to

.
<EOS>
What
else

to

?
<EOS>
She

with

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
did

.
<EOS>
I
was

your
father
 
forced
,
I
mean
,
by
my
father
's

;
and

,

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
<EOS>
I

to

.
<EOS>
I

a

to

my

from
a

that
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She

,

that

closed

is
like

.
<EOS>
Deronda
continued

,
and

"
<EOS>
And

I

I

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
<EOS>
Deronda

.
<EOS>
"
My

a

,

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

,
"

,

<EOS>
"
I

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

against

.
<EOS>
This

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

.

"
  
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
He

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>
A

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
I

if

.

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
He

for
her
whose

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Why

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
 
the

!
"

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
Every

<EOS>

<EOS>

_
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
If

dead
 
<EOS>

but
<EOS>
little

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.

<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

,

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

:

.
<EOS>
But
why
have
you
now
sent
for
me
to
tell
me
that
I
am
a
Jew
?
"
said
Deronda
,
with
an
intensity
of
opposition
in
feeling
that
was
almost
bitter
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
her
words
had
called
out
a
latent
obstinacy
of
race
in
him
.
  
<EOS>
"
Why
?
 
<EOS>
ah
,
why
?
<EOS>
"
said
the
Princess
,
rising
quickly
and
walking
to
the
other
side
of
the
room
,
where
she
turned
round
and
slowly
approached
him
,
as
he
,
too
,
stood
up
.
<EOS>
Then
she
began
to
speak
again
in
a
more
veiled
voice
.
<EOS>
"
I
ca
n't
explain
;
I
can
only
say
what
is
.
<EOS>
I
do
n't
love
my
father
's
religion
now
any
more
than
I
did
then
.
<EOS>
Before
I
married
the
second

I
was
baptized
;
I
made

like
the
people
I
lived

.
<EOS>
I
had
a
right
to
do

;
I
was
not

,

to
go
with

own

.
<EOS>
I
have
not
repented
;
I
will
not
say
that
I
have
repented
.
<EOS>
But
yet
"
 
here
she
had
come
near
to
her
son
,
and
paused
;
then
again

a
little
and

,
as

;
but

,

anything
<EOS>
but
the
awe
that
subdued

.
<EOS>
"
It
is
illness
,
I
do

doubt
that
it
has
been
gathering
illness
 
<EOS>
my
mind
has
gone
back
:
more
than
a
year

began
.
<EOS>
You
see
my
gray

,
my
worn

:
it
has
all
come
fast
.
<EOS>
Sometimes

am
in
an
agony
of
pain
 
<EOS>
I
dare
<EOS>
say
I
shall
be
to
-

.
<EOS>
Then

,

,
and
I
ca

:
my

.
<EOS>
My

<EOS>
my
girlhood
 
<EOS>
the

the

my
father
's

there

.
<EOS>
Then

:
what

know
of

or

?
<EOS>
and
what
my
father

"
right
"
may

a

that
is

of
me
 
that
is

me
now
.
<EOS>
Well
,
I
will

him
.
<EOS>
I
can
not
go

without

.
<EOS>
I
have
hidden
what
was
his
.
<EOS>
I
thought

would

.
<EOS>
I
have
not
burned
it
.
<EOS>
I
thank
God
<EOS>
I
have
not
burned
it
!
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
threw
herself
on
her
cushions
again
,
visibly

.
<EOS>
Deronda
,
moved
too
strongly
by
her
suffering
for
other
impulses
to
act
within
him
,
drew
near
her
,
and
said
,
entreatingly
    
"
Will
you
not
spare
yourself
this
evening
?
<EOS>
Let

leave
the
rest
till
to
-
morrow
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
said
decisively
.
<EOS>
"
I
will
confess
it
all
,
now
that
I
have
come
up
to
it
.
<EOS>
Often

I
am
at

it
all

away
;
my
whole
self
comes
quite
back
;
but
I
know

will
sink

again
,
and
the
other
will
come
 
<EOS>
the
poor
,

,
forsaken
remains
of
self
,
that
can

nothing
.
<EOS>
It
was
my
nature
to
resist
,
and

,
"
I

to

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Well
,
I
say
so
still
when

in

.
<EOS>
You
have

,

do

.
<EOS>
But

,

itself

;
and

,

.
<EOS>
And

have
made

worse

,
"

,

;
"
but
I
shall

.
<EOS>
And

,
"

"

?
<EOS>
Joseph
Kalonymos
reproached

:
he

,
who

.
<EOS>
I

had
!
"
<EOS>
she

,
with

.
<EOS>
It
was
as
if

were
breaking
into

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Who
is
Joseph
Kalonymos
?
"
said
Deronda
,
with
a
darting

of
that
Jew
who
touched
his
arm
in
the
Frankfort

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
!
<EOS>
some
vengeance
sent
him
back
from
the
East
,
that
he
might
see

and
come
to
reproach

.
<EOS>
He
was
my
father
's
friend
.
<EOS>
He
knew
of
your
birth
:
he
knew
of
my
husband
's
death
,
and
once
,
twenty
years
ago
,
after
he
had
been
away
in
the
Levant
,
he
came
to
see
me
and
inquire
about
you
.
<EOS>
I
told
him
that
you
were
dead
:
I
meant
you
to
be
dead
to
all
the
world
of
my
childhood
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
said
that
your
were
living
,
he
would
have
interfered
with
my

:
he
would
have
taken
on
him
to
represent
my
father
,
and
have

recall

had
done
.
<EOS>
What
could
I
do
but
say
you
were
dead
?
<EOS>
The
act
was
done
.
<EOS>
If
I
had
told
him
of
it
there
would
have
been
trouble
and
scandal
 
and
all
to
conquer
me
,
who
would
not
have
been
conquered
.
<EOS>
I
was
strong
then
,
and
I
would
have
had
my
will
,
though
there
might
have
been
a

against

.
<EOS>
I
took
the
way
to
have
it
without
any

.
<EOS>
I
felt
then
that
I
was
not
really
deceiving
:
it
would
have
come
to
the
same
in
the
end
;
or
if

,

something

.
<EOS>
He

and

that
I
would
give
up

him
the
chest
that
my
father
had
charged

to

to

.
<EOS>
I

was
in

chest
 
things
that
had

in

since
I
had
had
any

things
that
were
thrust
on
my

that
I
might
feel
them
like
a

my
life
 
<EOS>
my

that
was
growing
like
a
tree
.
<EOS>
Once
,

my
husband
died
,
I
was

.
<EOS>
But
it
was
difficult
to
burn
;
and

a

.
<EOS>
I
have
committed
no
shameful
act
 
except
what
Jews

.
<EOS>
I
had
kept
the

,
and
I

to
Joseph
Kalonymos
.
<EOS>
He
went

mournful
,
and

,
"

,
and

another

,

chest
to

.
<EOS>
"
I

.
<EOS>
I
meant

to
marry
again
 
no

than
I
meant
to
be
the

that
I

now
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
ceased

,
and

.
<EOS>
Her
thought
was
traveling
through
the
years
,
and
when

began
to

her
voice
had
lost

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
But

this
Kalonymos
saw

.
<EOS>
He

you

,
and

.
<EOS>
There

nobody
else

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then

?
"

,
with

this

.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,

,
"
said

mother
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
Jews
have
always
been
changing

.
<EOS>
My
father
's
family
had
kept

name
of
Charisi
:
my

was
a
Charisi
.
<EOS>
When

,

Alcharisi
.
<EOS>
But

who

,
and

,

Hugo

,
"
Let

,
"
I

.
<EOS>
But
Joseph
Kalonymos
had
heard
my
father
speak
of
the
Deronda
branch
,
and
the
name
confirmed
his
suspicion
.
<EOS>
He
began
to
suspect
what
had
been
done
.
<EOS>
It
was
as
if
everything
had
been
whispered

air
.
<EOS>
He
found
out
where
I
was
.
<EOS>
He
took
a
journey
into
Russia
to
see
me
;
he
found
me
weak
and

.
<EOS>
He
had
come
back
again
,
with
his
white
hair
,
and
with
rage
in
his
soul
against
me
.
<EOS>
He
said
I
was
going
down
to
the
grave
clad
in
falsehood
and
robbery
 
falsehood
to
my
father
and
robbery
of
my
own
child
.
<EOS>
He
accused
me
of
having
kept

of
your
birth
from
you
,
and
having
brought
you
up
as

you

been
the
son

an
English

.
<EOS>
Well
,
it
was
true
;
and
twenty
years
before
I
would
have
maintained
that
I
had
a
right
to
do
it
.
<EOS>
But
I
can
maintain
nothing
now
.
<EOS>
No
faith
is
strong
within
me
.
<EOS>
My
father
may
have
God
on
his
side
.
<EOS>
This
man
's
words
were
like
lion
's
teeth
upon
me
.
<EOS>
My
father
's
threats
eat
into

with
my
pain
.
<EOS>
If
I
tell
everything
 
if
I
deliver
up
everything
 
what
else
can
be
demanded
of
me
?
<EOS>
I
can
not
make
myself
love
the
people
I
have
never
loved
 
<EOS>
is
it
not
enough
that
I
lost
the
life
I
did
love
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
had
leaned
forward
a
little
in
her
low
-

,
that
seemed
like
a
smothered

:
her

and

were
stretched

,
as
if

in

,
Deronda
's
soul
was
absorbed
in
the
anguish
of
compassion
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
mind
now
that
he
had
been
repulsed
before
.
<EOS>
His
pity
made
a
flood
of
forgiveness
within
him
.
<EOS>
His
single
impulse
was
to
kneel
by
her
and
take
her
hand
gently
,
between
his
palms
,
while
he
said
in
that
exquisite
voice
of
soothing
which
expresses
oneness
with
the
sufferer
    
"
Mother
,
take
comfort
!
"
  
<EOS>
She
did
not
seem
inclined
to
repulse
him
now
,
but
looked
down
at
him
and
let
him
take
both
her
hands
to
fold
between
his
.
<EOS>
Gradually
tears
gathered
,
but
she
pressed
her
handkerchief
against
her

and
then
leaned
her
cheek
against
his
brow
,
as
if
she
wished
that
they
should
not
look

other
.
  
<EOS>
"
Is
it
not
possible
that
I
could
be
near
you
often
and
comfort
you
?
"
said
Deronda
.
<EOS>
He
was
under
that
stress
of
pity
that
propels
us
on
sacrifices
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
not
possible
,
"
she
answered
,
lifting
up
her
head
again
and
withdrawing
her
hand
as
if
she
wished
him
to
move
away
.
<EOS>
"
I
have
a
husband
and
five
children
.
<EOS>
None
of
them
know
of
your
existence
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
felt
painfully
silenced
.
<EOS>
He
rose
and
stood
at
a
little
distance
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
wonder
why
I
married
,
"
she
went
on
presently
,
under
the
influence
of
a
newly
-
recurring
thought
.
<EOS>
"
I
meant
never
to
marry
again
.
<EOS>
I
meant
to
be
free
and
to
live
for
my
art
.
<EOS>
I
had
parted
with
you
.
<EOS>
I
had
no
bonds
.
<EOS>
For
nine
years
I
was
a
queen
.
<EOS>
I
enjoyed
the
life
I
had
longed
for
.
<EOS>
But
something
befell
me
.
<EOS>
It
was
like
a
fit
of
forgetfulness
.
<EOS>
I
began
to
sing
out
of
tune
.
<EOS>
They
told
me
of
it
.
<EOS>
Another
woman
was
thrusting
herself
in
my
place
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
endure
the
prospect
of
failure
and
decline
.
<EOS>
It
was
horrible
to
me
.
"
<EOS>
She
started
up
again
,
with
a
shudder
,
and
lifted

hands
like
one
who
dreads
missiles
.
<EOS>
"
It
drove
me
to
marry
.
<EOS>
I
made
believe
that
I
preferred
being
the
wife
of
a
Russian
noble
to
being
the
greatest
lyric
actress
of
Europe
;
I
made
believe
 
<EOS>
I
acted
that
part
.
<EOS>
It
was
because
I
felt
my
greatness
sinking
away
from
me
,
as
I
feel
my
life
sinking
now
.
<EOS>
I
would
not
wait
till
men
said
,
"
She
had
better
go
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
She
sank
into
her
seat
again
,
and
looked
at
the
evening
sky
as
she
went
on
:
"
I
repented
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
resolve
taken
in
desperation
.
<EOS>
That
singing
out
of
tune
was
only
like
a
fit
of
illness
;
it
went
away
.
<EOS>
I
repented
;
but
it
was
too
late
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
go
back
.
<EOS>
All

hindered
,
me
 
all

.
"
  
<EOS>

.
"

"

.
<EOS>

?
<EOS>

"

<EOS>
LA
ROCHEFOUCAULD
.
   
<EOS>

<EOS>
MY
DEAR
DERONDA
,
 
<EOS>

is

"
time

.
"
<EOS>

account

which

.

.

.

<EOS>
And

<EOS>

<EOS>

My

(

)

,
