"
My
desolation
does
begin
to
make
  
A
better
life
.
"
        
<EOS>
SHAKESPEARE
:
_
Antony
and
Cleopatra
.
<EOS>
_
   
<EOS>
Before
Deronda
was
summoned
to
a
second
interview
with
his
mother
,
a
day
had
passed
in
which
she
had
only
sent
him
a
message
to
say
that
she
was
not
yet
well
enough
to
receive
him
again
;
but
on
the
third
morning
he
had
a
note
saying
,
"
I
leave
to
-
day
.
<EOS>
Come
and
see
me
at
once
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
was
shown
into
the
same
room
as
before
;
but
it
was
much
darkened
with
blinds
and
curtains
.
<EOS>
The
Princess
was
not
there
,
but
she
presently
entered
,
dressed
in
a
loose
wrap
of
some
soft
silk
,
in
color
a
dusky
orange
,
her
head
again
with
black
lace
floating
about
it
,
her
arms
showing
themselves
bare
from
under
her
wide
sleeves
.
<EOS>
Her
face
seemed
even
more
impressive
in
the
sombre
light
,
<EOS>
the
eyes
larger
,
the
lines
more
vigorous
.
<EOS>
You
might
have
imagined
her
a
sorceress
who
would
stretch
forth
her
wonderful
hand
and
arm
to
mix
youth
-
potions
for
others
,
but
scorned
to
mix
them
for
herself
,
having
had
enough
of
youth
.
  
<EOS>
She
put
her
arms
on
her
son
's
shoulders
at
once
,
and
kissed
him
on
both
cheeks
,
then
seated
herself
among
her
cushions
with
an
air
of
assured
firmness
and
dignity
unlike
her
fitfulness
in
their
first
interview
,
and
told
Deronda
to
sit
down
by
her
.
<EOS>
He
obeyed
,
saying
,
"
You
are
quite
relieved
now
,
I
trust
?
"
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
I
am
at
ease
again
.
<EOS>
Is
there
anything
more
that
you
would
like
to
ask
me
?
"
<EOS>
she
said
,
with
the
matter
of
a
queen
rather
than
of
a
mother
.
  
<EOS>
"
Can
I
find
the
house
in
Genoa
where
you
used
to
live
with
my
grandfather
?
"
said
Deronda
.
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"
she
answered
,
with
a
deprecating
movement
of
her
arm
,
"
it
is
pulled
down
 
not
to
be
found
.
<EOS>
But
about
our
family
,
and
where
my
father
lived
at
various
times
 
you
will
find
all
that
among
the
papers
in
the
chest
,
better
than
I
can
tell
you
.
<EOS>
My
father
,
I
told
you
,
was
a
physician
.
<EOS>
My
mother
was
a
Morteira
.
<EOS>
I
used
to
hear
all
those
things
without
listening
.
<EOS>
You
will
find
them
all
.
<EOS>
I
was
born
amongst
them
without
my
will
.
<EOS>
I
banished
them
as
soon
as
I
could
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
tried
to
hide
his
pained
feeling
,
and
said
,
"
Anything
else
that
I
should
desire
to
know
from
you
could
only
be
what
it
is
some
satisfaction
to
your
own
feeling
to
tell
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
think
I
have
told
you
everything
that
could
be
demanded
of
me
,
"
said
the
Princess
,
looking
coldly
meditative
.
<EOS>
It
seemed
as
if
she
had
exhausted
her
emotion
in
their
former
interview
.
<EOS>
The
fact
was
,
she
had
said
to

,
"
I
have
done
it
all
.
<EOS>
I
have
confessed
all
.
<EOS>
I
will
not
go
through
it
again
.
<EOS>
I
will
save
myself
from
agitation
.
"
<EOS>
And
she
was
acting
out
that
scheme
.
  
<EOS>
But
to
Deronda
's
nature
the
moment
was
cruel
;
it
made
the
filial
yearning
of
his
life
a
disappointed

to
a
shrine
where
there
were
no
longer
the
symbols
of

.
<EOS>
It
seemed
that
all
the
woman
lacking
in
her
was
present
in
him
,
as
he
said
,
with
some

"
Then
are
we
to
part
<EOS>
and
I
never
be
anything
to

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
is
better

,
"
said
the
Princess
,
in
a
softer
,
mellower
voice
.
<EOS>
"
There
could
be
nothing
but
hard
duty
for
you
,
even
if

were

for
you
to
take

my

.
<EOS>
You
would
not
love
me
.
<EOS>
Do

,
"
she
said
,

,

.
<EOS>
"
I
know
what
is
the
truth
.
<EOS>
You
do
n't
like
what
I
did
.
<EOS>
You
are
angry
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
think
I
robbed
you
of
something
.
<EOS>
You
are
on
your
grandfather
's
side
,
and
you
will
always
have
a
condemnation
of
me
in
your
heart
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
felt
himself
under
a
ban
of
silence
.
<EOS>
He
rose
from
his
seat
by
her
,
preferring
to
stand
,
if
he
had
to
obey
that
imperious
prohibition
of
any
tenderness
.
<EOS>
But
his
mother
now
looked
up
at
him
with
a
new
admiration
in
her
glance
,
saying
    
"
You
are
wrong
to
be
angry
with
me
.
<EOS>
You
are
the
better
for
what
I
did
.
"
<EOS>
After
pausing
a
little
,
she
added
,
abruptly
,
"
And
now
tell
me
what
you
shall
do
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Do
you
mean
now
,
immediately
,
"
said
Deronda
;
"
or
as
to
the
course

my
future

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
mean
in
the
future
.
<EOS>
What
difference
will
it
make
to
you
that
I
have
told

about
your
birth
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
A
very
great
difference
,
"
said
Deronda
,
emphatically
.
<EOS>
"
I
can
hardly
think

anything
that
would

greater
difference
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
shall
you
do

?
"
said
the
Princess
,
with
more

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Make
yourself
just
like
your
grandfather
 
be
what
he
wished
you
 
turn

into

Jew

?
"
  
<EOS>
"
That
is

.
<EOS>
The
effect

my

.
<EOS>
The
Christian

in

my

was
reared
can
never

,
"
said
Deronda
,

.
<EOS>
"
But
I
consider
it
my
duty
 
<EOS>
it
is
the
impulse
of
my
feeling
 
to

,
as
far

,
with
my
hereditary

,

if

see
any

that
I
can
give
my
soul
and
hand
to
<EOS>
I
shall
choose
to
do
it
.
"
  
<EOS>
His
mother
had
her
eyes
fixed
on
him
with
a
wondering
speculation
,
examining
his
face
as
if
she
thought
that
by
close

she
could
read
a
difficult
language
there
.
<EOS>
He
bore
her

very
firmly
,
sustained
by
a
resolute
opposition
,
which
was
the
expression
of
his
fullest
self
.
<EOS>
She
bent
toward
him
a
little
,
and
said
,
with
a
decisive
emphasis
    
<EOS>
"
You
are
in
love
with
a
Jewess
.
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
colored
and
said
,
"
My
reasons
would
be
independent
of
any
such
fact
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
I
know
better
.
<EOS>
I
have

what
men
are
,
"
said

Princess
,

.
<EOS>
"
Tell

.
<EOS>
She
is
a
Jewess
who

but

.
<EOS>
There
_
are
_
<EOS>
a
few
such
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
had
that

to
answer
which
we
all
have
known
in

to
those
who
are
too

to

.
<EOS>
But

,
the
point
immediately
in
question
was
one

a

either

.
<EOS>
He

,

"
You
love
her
as

father

,
and
she

.
"
  
<EOS>
Those
words
touched

's
filial

,
and
some

in

was
taken

mother

.
<EOS>
She

:
"
But
I

leading

the

.
<EOS>
And
now

grandfather
is

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Mother
,
"

,

"
do

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
Deronda

:

"

.

"
Not

,

<EOS>
,
"

"
I

,

"

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Her

.
<EOS>
Deronda
,

,

,

"
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
I

may
 
which

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

you

as

"
 
<EOS>
there

"

.

<EOS>
His

<EOS>
After

,
"

"

.
<EOS>

.

.
<EOS>

your

?

.
<EOS>
My

SHELLEY
.
   
<EOS>
Madonna
Pia
,
whose
husband
,
feeling
himself
injured
by
her
,
took
her
to
his
castle
amid
the
swampy
flats
of
the
Maremma
and
got
rid
of
her
there
,
makes
a
pathetic
figure
in
Dante
's
Purgatory
,
among
the
sinners
who
repented
at
the
last
and
desire
to
be
remembered
compassionately
by
their
fellow
-
countrymen
.
<EOS>
We
know
little
about
the
grounds
of
mutual
discontent
between
the
Siennese
couple
,
but
we
may
infer
with
some
confidence
that
the
husband
had
never
been
a
very
delightful
companion
,
and
that
on
the
flats
of
the
Maremma
his
disagreeable
manners
had
a
background
which
threw
them
out
remarkably
;
whence
in
his
desire
to
punish
his
wife
to
the
unmost
,
<EOS>
the
nature
of
things
was
so
far
against
him
that
in
relieving
himself
of
her
<EOS>
he
could
not
avoid
making
the
relief
mutual
.
<EOS>
And
thus
,
without
any
hardness
to
the
poor
Tuscan
lady
,
who
had
her
deliverance
long
ago
,
one
may
feel
warranted
in
thinking
of
her
with
a
less
sympathetic
interest
than
of
the
better
known
Gwendolen
who
,
instead
of
being
delivered
from
her
errors
on
earth
and
cleansed
from
their
effect
in
purgatory
,
is
at
the
very
height
of
her
entanglement
in
those
fatal
meshes
which
are
woven
within
more
closely
than
without
,
and
often
make
the
inward
torture
disproportionate
to
what
is
discernable
as
outward
cause
.
  
<EOS>
In
taking
his
wife
with
him
on
a
yachting
expedition
,
Grandcourt
had
no
intention
to
get
rid
of
her
;
on
the
contrary
,
he
wanted
to
feel
more
securely
that
she
was
his
to
do
as
he
liked
with
,
and
to
make
her
feel
it
also
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
was
himself
very
fond
of
yachting
:
<EOS>
its
dreamy
do
-
nothing
absolutism
,
unmolested
by
social
demands
,
suited
his
disposition
,
and
he
did
not
in
the
least
regard
it
as
an
equivalent
for
the
dreariness
of
the
Maremma
.
<EOS>
He
had
his
reasons
for
carrying
Gwendolen
out
of
reach
,
but
they
were
not
reasons
that
can
seem
black
in
the
mere
statement
.
<EOS>
He
suspected
a
growing
spirit
of
opposition
in
her
,
and
his
feeling
about
the
sentimental
inclination
she
betrayed
for
Deronda
was
what
in
another
man
he
would
have
called
jealousy
.
<EOS>
In
himself
it
seemed
merely
a
resolution
to
put
an
end
to
such
foolery
as
must
have
been
going
on
in
that
prearranged
visit
of
Deronda
's
which
he
had
divined
and
interrupted
.
  
<EOS>
And
Grandcourt
might
have
pleaded
that
he
was
perfectly
justified
in
taking
care
that
his
wife
should
fulfill
the
obligations
she
had
accepted
.
<EOS>
Her
marriage
was
a
contract
where
all
the
ostensible
advantages
were
on
her
side
,
and
it
was
only
of
those
advantages
that
her
husband
should
use
his
power
to
hinder

from
any

or

.
<EOS>
He
knew

well
that
she
had
not
married
him
 
had
not
overcome

*

make

passionately
present
to
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
And
so

was
.
<EOS>
In

's

met

,
each

and

<EOS>

<EOS>
It

sometimes

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

"

"

"

.
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
Why

?
 
<EOS>
since

<EOS>

be
out
of
temper
.
<EOS>
You
make
things
uncommonly
pleasant
for
me
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Why
do
you
want
to
make
them
unpleasant
for
_
me
_
?
"
said
Gwendolen
,
getting
helpless
again
,
and
feeling
the
hot
tears
rise
.
  
<EOS>
"
Now
,
will
you
be
good
enough
to
say
what
it
is
you
have
to
complain
of
?
"
said
Grandcourt
,
looking
into
her
eyes
,
and
using
his
most
inward
voice
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Is
it
that
I
stay
indoors
when
you
stay
?
"
  
<EOS>
She
could
give
no
answer
.
<EOS>
The
sort
of
truth
that
made
any
excuse
for
her
anger
could
not
be
uttered
.
<EOS>
In
the
conflict
of
despair
and
humiliation
she
began
to
sob
,
and
the
tears
rolled
down
her
cheeks
 
<EOS>
a
form
of
agitation
which
she
had
never
shown
before
in
her
husband
's
presence
.
  
<EOS>
"
I
hope
this
is
useful
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
after
a
moment
or
two
.
<EOS>
"
All
I
can
say
is
,
it
's
most
confoundedly
unpleasant
.
<EOS>
What
the
devil
women
can
see
in
this
kind
of
thing
,
I
do
n't
know
.
<EOS>
_
You
_
see
something
to
be
got
by
it
,
of
course
.
<EOS>
All
I
can
see
is
,
that
we
shall
be
shut

here
when
we
might
have
been
having
a
pleasant
sail
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
go
,
then
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
impetuously
.
<EOS>
"
Perhaps
we
shall
be
drowned
.
<EOS>
"
She
began
to
sob
again
.
  
<EOS>
This
extraordinary
behavior
,
which
had
evidently
some
relation
to
Deronda
,
gave
more
definiteness
to
Grandcourt
's
conclusions
.
<EOS>
He
drew
his
chair
quite
close
in
front
of
her
,
and
said
,
in
a
low
tone
,
"
Just
be
quiet
and
listen
,
will
you
?
"
  
<EOS>
There
seemed
to
be
a
magical
effect
in
this
close
vicinity
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
shrank
and
ceased
to
sob
.
<EOS>
She
kept
her
eyelids
down
and
clasped
her
hands
tightly
.
  
<EOS>
"
Let
us
understand
each
other
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
in
the
same
tone
.
<EOS>
"
I
know
very
well
what
this
nonsense
means
.
<EOS>
But
if
you
suppose
I
am
going
to
let
you
make
a

of

,
just
dismiss
that

your

.
<EOS>
What
are
you
looking

,
if
you
ca
n't

as
my
wife
?
<EOS>
There

disgrace
for
you
,

,

I

;
and
as

,

's

he

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
It
's
all
false
!
"
<EOS>
said
Gwendolen
,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
You
do
n't
in
the
least
imagine
what
is
in
my
mind
.
<EOS>
I
have
seen
enough
of
the
disgrace
that
comes
in
that
way
.
<EOS>
And
you
had
better
leave
me
at
liberty
to
speak

one
I

.
<EOS>
It
will
be
better
for
you
.
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
will
allow
me
to
judge
of
that
,
"
said
Grandcourt
,
rising
and
moving
to
a
little
distance
toward
the
window
,
but
standing
there
playing
with
his
whiskers
as
if
he
were

something
.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
words
had
so
clear
and
tremendous
<EOS>
a
meaning
for
herself
that
she
thought
they
must
have
expressed
it
to
Grandcourt
,
and
had
no
sooner
uttered
them
than
she
dreaded
their
effect
.
<EOS>
But
his
soul
was
garrisoned
against
presentiments
and
fears
:
he
had
the
courage
and
confidence
that
belong
to
domination
,
and
he
was
at
that
moment
feeling
perfectly
satisfied
that
he
held
his
wife
with
bit
and
bridle
.
<EOS>
By
the
time
they
had
been
married
a
year
she
would
cease
to
be
restive
.
<EOS>
He
continued
standing
with
his
air
of
indifference
,
till
she
felt
her
habitual
stifling
consciousness
of
having
an
immovable

in
her

,
like
the

of
beholding
a
single
form
that

to

though

wide
country
lies
open
.
  
<EOS>
"
What
decision
have
you
come
to
?
"
<EOS>
he
said
,
presently
looking
at

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
What
orders
shall
I
give
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
let
us
go
,
"
said
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
The
walls
had
begun
to
be
an
imprisonment
,
and
while
there
was
breath
in
this
man
he
would
have
the
mastery
over
her
.
<EOS>
His
words
had
the
power
of
thumb
-
screws
and
the
cold
touch
of
the
rock
.
<EOS>
To
resist
was
to
act
like
a
stupid
animal
unable
to
measure
results
.
  
<EOS>
So
the
boat
was
ordered
.
<EOS>
She
even
went
down
to
the
quay
again
with
him
to
see
it
before
midday
.
<EOS>
Grandcourt
had
recovered
perfect
quietude
of
temper
,
and
had
a

in
the
attention
given
by
the
nautical
groups
to
the
_
milord
_
,
owner
of
the
handsome
yacht
which
had
just
put
in
for
repairs
,
and
who
being
an

was
naturally
so
at

on
the
sea
that
he
could
manage

with

same

that
he
could
manage
a
horse
.
<EOS>
The
sort
of
exultation
he
had
discerned
in
Gwendolen
this
morning
<EOS>
she
now
thought
that
she
discerned
in
him
;
and
it
was
true
that
he
had
set
his

on
this

,
and
carried

his

as
something
that
people
might
not
expect
him
to
do
,
with
the
gratified
impulse
of
a
strong
will
which
had
nothing
better
to
exert
itself
upon
.
<EOS>
He
had
remarkable
physical
courage
,
and
was
proud
of
it
 
or
rather
he
had
a
great
contempt
for
the
coarser
,
bulkier
men
who
generally
had
less
.
<EOS>
Moreover
,
he
was
ruling
that
Gwendolen
should
go
with
him
.
  
<EOS>
And
when
they
came
down
again
at
five
o'clock
,
equipped
for
their
boating
,
the
scene
was
as
good
as
a
theatrical
representation
for
all
beholders
.
<EOS>
This
handsome
,
fair
-
skinned
English
couple
,
manifesting
the
usual
eccentricity
of
their
nation
,
both
of
them
proud
,
pale
,
and
calm
,
without
a
smile
on
their
faces
,
moving
like
creatures
who
were
fulfilling
a
supernatural
destiny
 
<EOS>
it
was
a
thing
to
go
out
and
see
,
a
thing
to
paint
.
<EOS>
The
husband
's
chest
,
back
,
and
arms
,
showed
very
well
in
his
close
-
fitting
dress
,
and
the
wife
was
declared
to
be
a
statue
.
  
<EOS>
Some
suggestions
were
proffered
concerning
a
possible
change
in
the
breeze
,
and
the
necessary
care
in
putting
about
,
but
Grandcourt
's
manner
made
the
speakers
understand
that
they
were
too
officious
,
and
that
he
knew
better
than
they
.
  
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
keeping
her
impassable
air
,
as
they
moved
away
from
the
strand
,
felt
her
imagination
obstinately
at
work
.
<EOS>
She
was
not
afraid
of
any
outward
dangers
 
<EOS>
she
was
afraid
of
her
own
wishes
which
were
taking
shapes
possible
and
impossible
,
like
a
cloud
of
demon
-
faces
.
<EOS>
She
was
afraid
of
her
own
hatred
,
which
under
the
cold
iron
touch
that
had
compelled
her
to
-
day
had
gathered
a
fierce
intensity
.
<EOS>
As
she
sat
guiding
the
tiller
under
her
husband
's
eyes
,
doing
just
what
he
told
her
,
the
strife
within
her
seemed
like
her
own
effort
to
escape
from

.
<EOS>
She
clung
to
the
thought
of
Deronda
:
she
persuaded
herself
that
he
would
not
go
away
while
she
was
there
 
<EOS>
he
knew
that
she
needed
help
.
<EOS>
The
sense
that
he
was
there
would
save
her
from
acting
out
the
evil
within
.
<EOS>
And
yet
quick
,
quick
,
came
images
,
plans
of
evil
that
would
come
again
and
seize
her
in
the
night
,
like

preparing
the
deed
that
they
would
straightway

.
  
<EOS>
They
were
taken
out
of
the
port
and
carried
eastward
by
a
gentle
breeze
.
<EOS>
Some
clouds
tempered
the
sunlight
,
and
the
hour
was
always
deepening
toward
the
supreme
beauty
of
evening
.
<EOS>
Sails
larger
and
smaller
changed
their
aspect
like
sensitive
things
,
and
made
a
cheerful
companionship
,
alternately
near
and
far
.
<EOS>
The
grand
city
shone
more
vaguely
,
the
mountains
looked
out
above
it
,
and
there
was
stillness
as
in
an
island
sanctuary
.
<EOS>
Yet
suddenly
Gwendolen
let
her
hands
fall
,
and
said
in
a

tone
,
"
God
help
me
!
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
is
the
matter
?
"
said
Grandcourt
,
not
distinguishing
the
words
.
  
<EOS>
"
Oh
,
nothing
,
"
said
Gwendolen
,
rousing
herself
from
her
momentary
forgetfulness
and
resuming
the
ropes
.
  
<EOS>
"
Do
n't
you
find
this
pleasant
?
"
said
Grandcourt
.
  
<EOS>
"
Very
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You
admit
now
we
could
n't
have
done
anything
better
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
 
I
see
nothing
better
.
<EOS>
I
think
we
shall
go
on
always
,
like
the
Flying
Dutchman
,
"
said
Gwendolen
wildly
.
  
<EOS>
Grandcourt
gave
her
one
of
his
narrow

glances
,
and
then
said
,
"
If
you
like
,
we
can
go
to
Spezia

the

,

let

take

there
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
;
I
shall
like
nothing
better
than
this
.
<EOS>
"
  
"
Very
well
:
we
'll
do

-

.
<EOS>
But
we
must
be
turning
in
soon
.
<EOS>
I
shall
put
about
.
"
            
<EOS>
"
Ritorna
a
tua
scienza
  
<EOS>
Che
vuoi
,
quanto
<EOS>
la
cosa
<EOS>
e
più
perfetta
  
<EOS>
Più
senta
if
bene
,
e
cosi
la
doglienza
.
"
                                           
<EOS>
DANTE
.
   
<EOS>
When
Deronda
met
Gwendolen
and
Grandcourt
on
the
staircase
,
his
mind
was
seriously
preoccupied
.
<EOS>
He
had
just
been
summoned
to
the
second
interview
with
his
mother
.
  
<EOS>
In
two
hours
after
his
parting
from
her
he
knew
that
the
Princess
Halm
-
Eberstein
had
left
the
hotel
,
and
so
far
as
the
purpose
of
his
journey
to
Genoa
was
concerned
,
he
might
himself
have
set
off
on
his
way
to
Mainz
,
to
deliver
the
letter
from
Joseph
Kalonymos
,
and
get
possession
of
the
family
chest
.
<EOS>
But
mixed
mental
conditions
,
which
did
not
resolve
themselves
into
definite
reasons
,
hindered
him
from
departure
.
<EOS>
Long
after
the
farewell
he
was
kept
passive
by
a
weight
of
retrospective
feeling
.
<EOS>
He
lived
again
,
with
the
new
keenness
of
emotive
memory
,
through
the
exciting
scenes
which
seemed
past
only
in
the
sense
of
preparation
for
their
actual
presence
in
his
soul
.
<EOS>
He
allowed
himself
in
his
solitude
to
sob
,
with
perhaps
more
than
a
woman
's
acuteness
of
compassion
,
over
that
woman
's
life
so
near
to
his
,
and
yet
so
remote
.
<EOS>
He
beheld
the
world
changed
for
him
by
the
certitude
of
ties
that
altered
the
poise
of
hopes
and
fears
,
and
gave
him
a
new
sense
of
fellowship
,
as
if
under
cover
of
the
night
he
had
joined
the
wrong
band
of
wanderers
,
and
found
with
the
rise
of
morning
that
the
tents
of
his
kindred
were
grouped
far
off
.
<EOS>
He
had
a
quivering
imaginative
sense
of
close
relation
to
the
grandfather
who
had
been
animated
by
strong
impulses
and
beloved
thoughts
,
which
were
now
perhaps
being
roused
from
their
slumber
within
himself
.
<EOS>
And
through
all
this
passionate
meditation
Mordecai
and
Mirah
were
always
present
,
as
beings
who
clasped
hands
with
him
in
sympathetic
silence
.
  
<EOS>
Of
such
quick
,
responsive
fibre
was
Deronda
made
,
under
that
mantle
of
self
-
controlled
reserve
into
which
early
experience
had
thrown
so
much
of
his
young
strength
.
  
<EOS>
When
the
persistent
ringing
of
a
bell
as
a
signal
reminded
him
of
the
hour
he
thought
of
looking
into
_
Bradshaw
_
,
and
making
the
brief
necessary
preparations
for
starting
by
the
next
train
 
thought
of
it
,
but
made
no
movement
in
consequence
.
<EOS>
Wishes
went
to
Mainz
and
what
he
was
to
get
possession
of
there
 
to
London
and
the
beings
there
who
made
the
strongest
attachments
of
his
life
;
but
there
were
other
wishes
that
clung
in
these
moments
to
Genoa
,
and
they
kept
him
where
he
was
by
that
force
which
urges
us
to
linger
over
an
interview
that
carries
a
presentiment
of
final
farewell
or
of
overshadowing
sorrow
.
<EOS>
Deronda
did
not
formally
say
,
"
I
will
stay
over
to
-
night
,
because
it
is
Friday
,
and
I
should
like
to
go
to
the
evening
service
at
the
synagogue
where
they
must
all
have
gone
;
and
besides
,
I
may
see
the
Grandcourts
again
.
"
<EOS>
But
simply
,
instead
of
packing
and
ringing
for
his
bill
,
he
sat
doing
nothing
at
all
,
while
his
mind
went
to
the
synagogue
and
saw
faces
there
probably
little
different
from
those
of
his
grandfather
's
time
,
and
heard
the
Spanish
-
Hebrew
liturgy
which
had
lasted
through
the
seasons
of
wandering
generations
like
a
plant
with
wandering
seed
,
that
gives
the
far
-
off
lands
a
kinship
to
the
exile
's
home
 
<EOS>
while
,
also
,
his
mind
went
toward
Gwendolen
,
with
anxious
remembrance
of
what
had
been
,
and
with
a
half
-
admitted
impression
that
it
would
be
hardness
in
him
willingly
to
go
away
at
once
without
making
some
effort
,
in
spite
of
Grandcourt
's
probable
dislike
,
to
manifest
the
continuance
of
his
sympathy
with
her
since
their
abrupt
parting
.
  
<EOS>
In
this
state
of
mind
he
deferred
departure
,
ate
his
dinner
without
sense
of
flavor
,
rose
from
it
quickly
to
find
the
synagogue
,
and
in
passing
the
porter
<EOS>
asked
if
Mr.
and
Mrs.
Grandcourt
were
still
in
the
hotel
,
and
what
was
the
number
of
their
apartment
.
<EOS>
The
porter
gave
him
the
number
,
but
added
that
they
were
gone
out
boating
.
<EOS>
That
information
had
somehow
power
enough
over
Deronda
to
divide
his
thoughts
with
the
memories
<EOS>
wakened
among
the
sparse
_
talithim
_
and
keen
dark
faces
of
worshippers
whose
way
of
taking
awful
prayers
and
invocations
with
the
easy
familiarity
which
might
be
called
Hebrew
dyed
Italian
,
made
him
reflect
that
his
grandfather
,
according
to
the
Princess
's
hints
of
his
character
,
must
have
been
almost
as
exceptional
a
Jew
as
Mordecai
.
<EOS>
But
were
not
men
of
ardent
zeal
and
far
-
reaching
hope
everywhere
exceptional
?
<EOS>
the
men
who
had
the
visions
which
,
as
Mordecai
said
,
were
the
creators
and
feeders
of
the
world
 
moulding
and
feeding
the
more
passive
life
which
without
them
would
dwindle
and
shrivel
into
the
narrow
tenacity
of
insects
,
unshaken
by
thoughts
beyond
the
reach
of
their
antennae
.
<EOS>
Something
of
a
mournful
impatience
perhaps
added
itself
to
the
solicitude
about
Gwendolen
(
a
solicitude
that
had
room
to
grow
in
his
present
release
from
immediate

)
as
an
incitement
to
hasten
from
the
synagogue
and
choose
to
take
his
evening

toward
the
quay
,
always
a
favorite

with
him
,
and
just
now
attractive
with
the
possibility
that
he
might
be
in
time
to
see
the
Grandcourts
come
in
from
their

.
<EOS>
In
this
case
,
he
resolved
that
he
would
advance
to
greet
them
deliberately
,
and
ignore
any
grounds
that
the
husband
might
have
for
wishing
him
elsewhere
.
  
<EOS>
The
sun
had
set
behind
a
bank
of
cloud
,
and
only
a
faint
yellow
light
was
giving
its
farewell

to
the
waves
,
which
were
agitated
by
an
active

.
<EOS>
Deronda
,
sauntering
slowly
within
sight
of
what
took
place
on
the
strand
,
observed
the
groups
there
concentrating
their
attention
on
a
sailing
-
boat
which
was
advancing
swiftly
landward
,
being
rowed
by
two
men
.
<EOS>
Amidst
the
clamorous
talk
in
various

,
Deronda
held
it
the
surer
means
of
getting
information
not
to
ask

,
but
to
elbow
his
way
to
the
foreground
and
be
an
unobstructed
witness
of
what
was
occurring
.
<EOS>
Telescopes
were
being
used
,
and
loud
statements
made
that
the
boat
held
somebody
who
had
been
drowned
.
<EOS>
One
said
it
was
the
_
milord
_
who
had
gone
out
in
a
sailing
boat
;
another
maintained
that
the
prostrate
figure
he
discerned
was
_
miladi
_
;
<EOS>
a

who
had
no
glass
would
rather
say
that

was
_
milord
_
who
had
probably

out

,
according

practice
 
a

in
our

(
as
nonsense
which
 
had
undergone
a

operation
)
,
and

that

.
<EOS>
For

,
terribly

,

,
possible

,

,
with
a
worse
half
undisclosed
 
if
this
woman
apparently

from

Grandcourt
.
  
<EOS>
But

no

:
the

was

,
and

saw
Gwendolen
<EOS>
half

on

,
by

of

pale

,

,

,

some

was

,
and

.
<EOS>
The

;
the

,
close

,

,

gave

,

,

,

.
<EOS>
Suddenly

,

,

,

,

,

,

<EOS>
"
It

,

!
<EOS>
He

!
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

!
"

,

;
"

.
"
<EOS>

"

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

.
  
<EOS>
After

;

,

's

.
<EOS>
Certain

's

.
      
<EOS>
"

,
    
Had

:
  
<EOS>
I

,
    
Nor

.
"
                                    
<EOS>
COLERIDGE
.
   
<EOS>
Deronda
did
not
take
off
his
clothes
that
night
.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,
after
insisting
on
seeing
him
again
before
she
would
consent
to
be
undressed
,
had
been
perfectly
quiet
,
and
had
only
asked
him
,
with
a

,
repressed

,
to
promise
that
he
would
come
to
her
when
she
sent
for
him
in
the
morning
.
<EOS>
Still
,
the
possibility
that
a
change
might
come
over
her
,
the
danger
of
a
supervening
feverish
condition
,
and
the
suspicion
that
something
in
the
late
catastrophe
was
having
an
effect
which
might
betray
itself
in
excited
words
,
acted
as
a
foreboding
within
him
.
<EOS>
He
mentioned
to
her
attendant
that
he
should
keep

ready
to
be
called
if
there
were
any
alarming

of
symptoms
,
making
it
understood
by
all
concerned
that
he
was
in
communication
with
her
friends
in
England
,
and
felt
bound
meanwhile
to
take
all

on
her
behalf
 
a

which
it

the

for

to
assume
,
because
he
was
well

to
Grandcourt
's
valet
,
the
only
old

who
had
come
on

late

.
  
<EOS>
But
when
fatigue
from
the

various

of
the

at
last
sent
Deronda
to
sleep
<EOS>
,
he
remained
undisturbed
except
by
the
morning

,
which
came
as
a
tangled
web
of
yesterday
's
events
,
and
finally
waked
him
,
with
an
image
drawn
by
his
pressing

.
  
<EOS>
Still
,
it
was
morning
,
and
there
had

no
summons
 
<EOS>
an
augury
which
cheered
him
while
he
made

toilet
,
and
reflected
that
it
was
too
early
to
send
inquiries
.
<EOS>
Later
,
he
learned
that
she
had
passed
a
too
wakeful
night
,
but
had
shown
no
violent
signs
of

,
and
was
at
last

.
<EOS>
He
wondered
at
the
force
that
dwelt
in
this
creature
,
so
alive
to
dread
;
for
he
had
an
irresistible
impression
that
even
under
the
effects
of
a
severe
physical
shock
she
was
mastering
herself
with
a

of
concealment
.
<EOS>
For
his
own
part
,
he
thought
that
his

had
been
blunted
by
what
he
had
been
going
through
in

his
mother
:
he
seemed
to
himself
now
to
be
only
fulfilling
claims
,
and
his
more
passionate

was
in

.
<EOS>
He
had
lately
been
living
so
keenly
in
an
experience
quite
apart
from
Gwendolen
's
lot
,
that
his
present
cares
for
her
were
like

of
scenes
familiar
in
the
past
,
and
there
was
not
yet
a
complete

of
the
inward
response
to

.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
he
employed
himself
in
getting
a
formal
,
legally
recognized
statement
from
the
fisherman
who
had
rescued
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
Few
details
came
to
light
.
<EOS>
The
boat
in
which
Grandcourt
had
gone
out
had
been
found
drifting
with
its
sail
loose
,
and
had
been
towed
in
.
<EOS>
The
fishermen
thought
it
likely
that
he
had
been
knocked
overboard
by
the
flapping
of
the
sail
while
putting
about
,
and
that
he
had
not

;
but
,
though

were
near
,
their
attention
had
been
first

which

like

a
man
in

,
and

were

with

,

,
and
saw

in
.
  
<EOS>
On
re
-

,
Deronda
was
told
that
Gwendolen
had
risen
,
and
was

.
<EOS>
He

,

,

.
<EOS>
But

was

,

,

:

,

,

,

,
<EOS>
her

helpless
<EOS>
,

like

that
Gwendolen
Harleth
whom

had
seen
turning

.
<EOS>
The

with

,

the
effects

their

began
to

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

to
rest
 
not

,
"

,

;
and

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Will

?
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
"
I
want

speak

.
"
  
<EOS>
She
was
in
a
large

-

,

near

.
<EOS>
The

:

,
which

,

said
,

,
"
You
know
I
am
a

?
"
  
<EOS>
Deronda
himself

as

said
,
"
I
know

.
"
<EOS>
He
did
not

.
  
<EOS>
"
He
is
dead
.
"
<EOS>
She

same

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
His

,
"

,

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
No
.
"
  
"
Not

any
one
else
 
only
by
me
 
a
dead
face
 
I
shall
never
get
away
from
it
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It
was

inward

-

that

,
while

something

a

from

.
<EOS>
She
was
seeing
the
whole
event
 
<EOS>
her

included
 
through
an

?
<EOS>
Was

in

into

and

-

?
<EOS>
Such

glanced

as
a

hope
.
<EOS>
But
imagine
the
conflict
of
feeling
that
kept

.
<EOS>
She
was
bent
on
confession
,
and
he
dreaded

.
<EOS>
Against
his
better
will
he
shrank
from
the
task
that
was
laid
on
him
:
he

,
and
yet
rebuked
the
wish
as
cowardly
,
that
she
could
bury
her
secrets
in
her
own

.
<EOS>
He
was
not
a
priest
.
<EOS>
He
dreaded
the
weight
of
this
woman
's
soul
flung
upon
his
own
with
imploring

.
<EOS>
But
she
spoke
again
,
hurriedly
,
looking
at
him
    
<EOS>
"
You
will
not
say
that
I
ought
to
tell
the
world
?
<EOS>
you
will
not

I
ought

?
<EOS>
I
could
not

.
<EOS>
I
could
not
bear

.
<EOS>
I
can
not
have
my
mother
know
.
<EOS>
Not
if
I
were
dead
.
<EOS>
I
could
not
have
her
know
.
<EOS>
I
must
tell
you
;
but
you
will
not
say
that
any

<EOS>
MARCUS
    
AURELIUS
.
      
<EOS>
Deeds
are

,

,
    
And
righteous

,

Must

.

No

<EOS>
NICHOLAS
BRETON
.
   
<EOS>
Extension
,
we
know
,
is
a
very
imperfect
measure
of
things
;
and
the
length
of
the
sun
's
journeying
can
no
more
tell
us
how
life
has
advanced
than
the
acreage
of
a
field
can
tell
us
what
growths
may
be
active
within
it
.
<EOS>
A
man
may
go
south
,
and
,
stumbling
over
a
bone
,
may
meditate
upon
it
till
he
has
found
a
new
starting
-
point
for
anatomy
;
or
eastward
,
and
discover
a
new
key
to
language
telling
a
new
story
of
races
;
or
he
may
head
an
expedition
that
opens
new
continental
pathways
,
get
himself
maimed
in
body
,
and
go
through
a
whole
heroic
poem
of
resolve
and
endurance
;
and
at
the
end
of
a
few
months
he
may
come
back
to
find
his
neighbors
grumbling
at
the
same
parish
grievance
as
before
,
or
to
see
the
same
elderly
gentleman
treading
the
pavement
in
discourse
with
himself
,
shaking
his
head
after
the
same
percussive
butcher
's
boy
,
and
pausing
at
the
same
shop
-
window
to
look
at
the
same
prints
.
<EOS>
If
the
swiftest
thinking
has
about
the
pace
of
a
greyhound
,
the
slowest
must
be
supposed
to
move
,
like
the
limpet
,
by
an
apparent
sticking
,
which
after
a
good
while
is
discerned
to
be
a
slight
progression
.
<EOS>
Such
differences
are
manifest
in
the
variable
intensity
which
we
call
human
experience
,
from
the
revolutionary
rush
of
change
which
makes
a
new
inner
and
outer
life
,
to
that
quiet
recurrence
of
the
familiar
,
which
has
no
other
epochs
than
those
of
hunger
and
the
heavens
.
  
<EOS>
Something
of
this
contrast
was
seen
in
the
year
's
experience
which
had
turned
the
brilliant
,
self
-
confident
Gwendolen
Harleth
of
the
Archery
Meeting
into
the
crushed
penitent
impelled
to
confess
her
unworthiness
where
it
would
have
been
her
happiness
to
be
held
worthy
;
while
it
had
left
her
family
in
Pennicote
without
deeper
change
than
that
of
some
outward
habits
,
and
some
adjustment
of
prospects
and
intentions
to
reduced
income
,
fewer
visits
,
and
fainter
compliments
.
<EOS>
The
rectory
was
as
pleasant
a
home
as
before
:
and
the
red
and
pink
peonies
on
the
lawn
,
the
rows
of
hollyhocks
by
the
hedges
,
had
bloomed
as
well
this
year
as
last
:
the
rector
maintained
his
cheerful
confidence
in
the
good
will
of
patrons
and
his
resolution
to
deserve
it
by
diligence
in
the
fulfillment
of
his
duties
,
whether
patrons
were
likely
to
hear
of
it
or
not
;
doing
nothing
solely
with
an
eye
to
promotion
except
,
perhaps
,
the
writing
of
two
ecclesiastical
articles
,
which
having
no
signature
,
were
attributed
to
some
one
else
,
except
by
the
patrons
who
had
a
special
copy
sent
them
,
and
these
certainly
knew
the
author
but
did
not
read
the
articles
.
<EOS>
The
rector
,
however
,
chewed
no
poisonous
cud
of
suspicion
on
this
point
:
he
made
marginal
notes
on
his
own
copies
to
render
them
a
more
interesting
loan
,
and
was
gratified
that
the
Archdeacon
and
other
authorities
had
nothing
to
say
against
the
general
tenor
of
his
argument
.
<EOS>
Peaceful
authorship
!
 
<EOS>
living
in
the
air
of
the
fields
and
downs
,
and
not
in
the
thrice
-
breathed
breath
of
criticism
 
bringing
no
Dantesque
leanness
;
rather
,
assisting
nutrition
by
complacency
,
and
perhaps
giving
a
more

sense

achievement
than
the

whole
_
Divina
Commedia
_
.
<EOS>
Then

was
the
father
's
recovered

in
his
favorite
son
,
which
was
a
happiness
outweighing
the
loss
of
eighteen
hundred
a
year
.
<EOS>
Of
whatever

might
be
the
hidden

first

,

that

dated
from

;

,
Mr.
Gascoigne
was
inclined
to
regard

had

the
year

as

,

which
the
human

.
<EOS>
Rex
had
lately
come
down
for
a
summer

to
the
rectory
,
bringing
Anna
home
,
and
while
he
showed
nearly

old

,

continued
in
his
holiday
the
habits
of
the
eager

,
rising
early
in
the
morning
and
shutting

up
early

carry

a
fixed
course
of
study
.
  
<EOS>
"
You
do
n't
repent
the
choice
of
the
law
as
a
profession

.
<EOS>
Everything

.

the

<EOS>

in

.

,

here

wreck
and
there

.
  
<EOS>
This

nested

,

Rex

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
when
Daniel
Charisi
was
a
stripling
<EOS>
and
I
was
a
lad
little
above
his
shoulder
,
we
made
a
solemn
vow
always
to
be
friends
.
<EOS>
He
said
,
"
Let
us
bind
ourselves
with
duty
,
as
if
we
were
sons
of
the
same
mother
.
<EOS>
"
That
was
his
bent
from
first
to
last
 
as
he
said
,
to
fortify
his
soul
with
bonds
.
<EOS>
It
was
a
saying
of
his
,
"
Let
us
bind
love
with
duty
;
for
duty
is
the
love
of
law
;
and
law
is
the
nature
of
the
Eternal
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
So
we
bound
ourselves
.
<EOS>
And
though
we
were
much
apart
in

later
life
,
the
bond
has
never

broken
.
<EOS>
When
he
was
dead
,
they
sought

;
but
they

not

him
of
me
.
<EOS>
I

him

.
<EOS>
And

the

.
<EOS>
I
will

.
"
  
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
It

,

and

.
<EOS>
The

.
  
<EOS>
"
So
!
"
said

,

"
<EOS>
And

the
curious
key
,
"

.
<EOS>
"
Bestow

.
<EOS>
I

are
methodic

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He

monitory

age

.
  
<EOS>
"
I

"

<EOS>
"

never
before

.
<EOS>
And

.
<EOS>
Have

?
<EOS>
Or

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

.
<EOS>
In

<EOS>
They

<EOS>
"

.

"

England
 
friends

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
But

"
  
<EOS>
"
Good

<EOS>
Me

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
The

changed

since

to

<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Our

evil

;
but
this

;

increase

wealth
in

,

Jewish
brains
 
though

.
<EOS>
Have

's

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

,
"

<EOS>

"
<EOS>
He

could

.
<EOS>
Age

not

youth
needs

know
-
distance
seeming
to

;
and
keenly
active

Joseph
Kalonymos
showed

,
an
inkstand

would

from

.
<EOS>
But
Deronda
's
last

answered

.
  
<EOS>
"
So
-
you
would

yet

.
<EOS>
He

:

.
<EOS>
When

.
<EOS>
I

.
<EOS>
Daniel
Charisi
used

,
"

,

;

;

.
<EOS>
"

he
despised

was

.
<EOS>
He

longer

than
I
can

.
"
  
<EOS>
"

?
"
said

,
with
a

to
the
usual

for
indecision
 
that
it
comes
from
knowing
too
much
.
  
<EOS>
"
Narrow
?
<EOS>
no
,
"
said
Kalonymos
,
shaking
his
head
with
a
compassionate
smile
"
From
his
childhood
upward
,
he
drank
in
learning
as
easily
as
the
plant
sucks
up
water
.
<EOS>
But
he
early
took
to
medicine
and
theories
about
life
and
health
.
<EOS>
He
traveled
to
many
countries
,
and
spent
much
of
his
substance
in
seeing
and
knowing
.
<EOS>
What
he
used
to
insist
on
was
that
the
strength
and
wealth
of
mankind
depended
on
the
balance
of
separateness
and
communication
,
and
he
was
bitterly
against
our
people
losing
themselves
among
the
Gentiles
;
"
It
's
no

,
"
said
he
,
"
than
the
many
sorts
of
grain
going
back
from
their
variety
into
sameness
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
He
mingled
all
sorts
of
learning
;
and
in
that
he
was
like
our
Arabic
writers
in
the

.
<EOS>
We
studied
together
,
but
he
went
beyond
me
.
<EOS>
Though
we
were
bosom
friends
,
and
he
poured
himself
out
to
me
,
we
were
as
different
as
the
inside

outside

the

.
<EOS>
I
stood
up
for
two
notions
of
my
own
:
I
took
Charisi
's
sayings
as
I
took
the
shape

trees
:
they
were
there
,
not

.
<EOS>
It
came

the
same

in
both

;
we
were
both
faithful
Jews
,
thankful
not
to
be
Gentiles
.
<EOS>
And
since
I
was
a
ripe
man
,
I
have
been
what
I

now
,
for
all
but
age
-
loving
to
wander
,
loving
transactions
,
loving
to
behold
all
things
,
and
caring
nothing
about

.
<EOS>
Charisi
thought
continually
of
our
people
's
future
:
he
went
with
all

soul
into
that
part
of
our
religion
:
<EOS>
I
,
not
.
<EOS>
So
we
have
freedom
,
I
am
content
.
<EOS>
Our
people
wandered
before
they
were
driven
.
<EOS>
Young
man
when
I
am
in
the
East
,
I
lie
much
on
deck
and
watch
the
greater
stars
.
<EOS>
The
sight
of
them
satisfies
me
.
<EOS>
I
know
them
as
they
rise
,
and
hunger
not
to
know

.
<EOS>
Charisi
was
satisfied
with
no
sight
,
but
pieced
it
out
with
what
had
been
before
and
what
would

after
.
<EOS>
Yet
we
loved
each
other
,
and
as
he
said
,
he
bound
our
love
with
duty
;
we
solemnly

to
help
and

to
the
last
.
<EOS>
I
have
fulfilled
my
pledge
.
<EOS>
"
Here
Kalonymos
rose
,
and
Deronda
,
rising

,
said
    
"
<EOS>
And
in
being

him

caused

.
<EOS>
It

of

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Be

,

.
<EOS>
What

?
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
This

,

.
<EOS>

"

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
Get

,

.
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
You

?
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
I
shall

myself

Jew
,
"

,

,

<EOS>
"
But
I

.
<EOS>
Our

.
<EOS>
But
I
think
I

.
<EOS>
I
hold

,

to

,
I
shall

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
It

at

,
as
it
has

others
,
that
the

speech
made

.
<EOS>
His

for

would
not

to

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
"
Ah
,
you
argue
and
you
look
forward
 
<EOS>
you
are
Daniel
Charisi
's

,
"

,

.

;
and

,

,

.
      
<EOS>
"
Within
the
gentle
heart
Love

,
    
As

within

.
  
<EOS>

,
in
Nature
's

,
    
Love
was
not
,
nor
the

ere
Love
.
"
              
<EOS>
GUIDO
GUNICELLI
(
<EOS>
_
Rossetti
's
Translation
_
)
.
   
<EOS>
There
was
another
house
besides
the
white
house
at
Pennicote
,
another
breast
besides
Rex
Gascoigne
's
,
in
which
the
news
of
Grandcourt
's
death
caused
both
strong
agitation
and
the
effort
to
repress
it
.
  
<EOS>
It
was
Hans
Meyrick
's
habit
to
send
or
bring
in
the
_
Times
_
for
his
mother
's
reading
.
<EOS>
She
was
a
great
reader
of
news
,
from
the
widest
-
reaching
politics
to
the
list
of
marriages
;
the
latter
,
she
said
,
giving
her
the
pleasant
sense
of
finishing
the
fashionable
novels
without
having
read
them
,
and
seeing
the
heroes
and
heroines
happy
without
knowing
what
poor
creatures
they
were
.
<EOS>
On
a
Wednesday
,
there
were
reasons
why
Hans
always
chose
to
bring
the
paper
,
and
to
do
so
about
the
time
that
Mirah
had
nearly
ended
giving
Mab
her
weekly
lesson
,
avowing
that
he
came
then
because
he
wanted
to
hear
Mirah
sing
.
<EOS>
But
on
the
particular
Wednesday
now
in
question
,
after
entering
the
house
as
quietly
as
usual
with
his
latch
-
key
,
he
appeared
in
the
parlor
,
shaking
the
_
Times
_
aloft
with
a
crackling
noise
,
in
remorseless
interruption
of
Mab
's
attempt
to
render
_
Lascia
ch'io
pianga
_
with
a
remote
imitation
of
her
teacher
.
<EOS>
Piano
and
song
ceased
immediately
;
Mirah
,
who
had
been
playing
the
accompaniment
,
involuntarily
started
up
and
turned
round
,
the
crackling
sound
,
after
the
occasional
trick
of
sounds
,
having
seemed
to
her
something
thunderous
;
and
Mab
said
    
"
O
-
o
-
o
,
Hans
!
<EOS>
why
do
you
bring
a
more
horrible
noise
than
my
singing
?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
What
on
earth
is
the
wonderful
news
?
"
said
Mrs.
Meyrick
,
who
was
the
only
other
person
in
the
room
.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Anything
about
Italy
 
anything
about
the
Austrians
giving
up
Venice
?
<EOS>
"
  
"
<EOS>
Nothing
about
Italy
,
but
something
from
Italy
,
"
said
Hans
,
with
a
peculiarity
in
his
tone
and
manner
which
set
his
mother
interpreting
.
<EOS>
Imagine
how
some
of
us
feel
and
behave
when
an
event
,
not
disagreeable
seems
to
be
confirming
and
carrying
out
our
private
constructions
.
<EOS>
We
say
,
"
What
do
you
think
?
"
in
a
pregnant
tone
to
some
innocent
person
who
has
not
embarked
his
wisdom
in
the
same
boat
with
ours
,
and
finds
our
information
flat
.
  
<EOS>
"
Nothing
bad
?
"
said
Mrs.
Meyrick
anxiously
,

of
Deronda
;

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Not

"

,

"
rather

,

.
<EOS>
I

die

.
<EOS>
Considering

a

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

<EOS>

"

<EOS>
What
_

_

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

"

is

,

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
"
  
<EOS>
"
It

"

<EOS>
"

?
 
<EOS>
that

<EOS>
the

_

_
,

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
All

.
<EOS>
Mirah

<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>
But

:

<EOS>
She

"
<EOS>

"

.

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

.
  
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
She

conscious

,

behind

.
<EOS>

,

.
  
<EOS>
Hans
,

,

.
<EOS>
Mirah
's

had

,
and
with

unpleasant

that

was
a

.
<EOS>
Suppose

's

in

her
own

's

,

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

only

,
and

that

Mrs.

;

,

,

,

,

,

,

's

about

was

.
<EOS>
Some
men
,

such

conviction
,
would
have
avoided
allusions
that
could
have
roused
that
susceptibility
;
but
Hans
's
talk
naturally
fluttered
toward
mischief
,
and
he
was
given
to
a
form
of
experiment
on
live
animals
which
consisted
in
irritating
his
friends
playfully
.
<EOS>
His
experiments
had
ended
in
satisfying
him
that
what
he
thought
likely
was
true
.
  
<EOS>
On

other
hand
,
any
susceptibility
Deronda
had
manifested
about
a

's

being

Mirah
,

to

sufficiently

,

,

;
for
he
credited
his
friend
with
all

unselfish

for
those
whom
he
could
rescue
and

.
<EOS>
And
Deronda
's

that
Mirah
would
never

Jew
necessarily

,

ordinary

,

,
that
Deronda
was
the
son
of
Sir
Hugo
Mallinger
.
  
<EOS>
Thus

felt
himself
in

about

's

;
but
now
,
the

which
really

as

desirable

with
Mrs.
Grandcourt
,
had
called
forth
a

from
Mirah
 
<EOS>
a
betrayal
of
her
passionate
feeling
on
this

which
had
made

melancholy
on
her
account
as
well
as
his
own
 
yet
on
the
whole
less

than
if

had

's

fixed

.
<EOS>
It
is
not
sublime
,
but
it
is
common
,
for
a
man
to
see
the
beloved
object
unhappy
because
his
rival

another
,
with
more

and
a

jealousy
than
if
he
saw

entirely

in

.
<EOS>
At

was

with
the

Hans
,
who
fluctuated

of

,
wounded
because
Mirah
was
wounded
,
and
of
being
almost
obliged
to
Deronda
for
loving
somebody
else
.
<EOS>
It
was
impossible
for

to

any
direct

way

he
had
understood

,
yet

that

should
be

in
a
tender
,

which
is
an
admissible

of
wooing
a
bruised

.
  
<EOS>
Thus
the
two
went
side
by
side
in
a

that
yet
seemed
an
agitated

,
like
that
of

whose

lie
outside

.
<EOS>
But

's

,

"
Good
-
bye
,
"
putting

,

with

,

,
"
Will

in
and

brother
?
"
  
<EOS>
Hans
could
not
but

as

.
<EOS>
He

not

what

's

,

how

.
<EOS>
When

,
"
If

,
"

,
half

,
and

was

of
how

might
make

to
Mirah
in
proportion
as
Deronda
gave

elsewhere
.
<EOS>
This
was
quite
fair
,
since
his
friend
was
provided
for
according
to
his
own
heart
;
and
on
the
question

Judaism
Hans
felt
thoroughly
fortified
:
 
who
ever
heard
in
tale
or
history
that
a
woman
's
love
went
in
the
track
of
her
race
and

?
<EOS>
Moslem
and
Jewish
damsels
were
always
attracted
toward
Christians
,
and
now
if
Mirah
's

had
gone
forth

,

was
another
case

.
<EOS>
Hans
was
wo
nt
to
make
merry
with
his
own
arguments
,
to
call
himself
a
Giaour
,
and
antithesis
the
sole
clue
to
events
;
but
he
believed
a
little
in
what

laughed
at
.
<EOS>
And
thus
his
bird
-
like
hope
,
constructed
on
the
lightest

,
soared
again
in
spite
of
heavy

.
  
<EOS>
They
found
Mordecai
looking
singularly

,
holding
a
closed

in

,
his

with
a

which
in

a
conquest
over

.
<EOS>
After
the

between

and

,

put
her
arm
<EOS>
round
her
brother
's

and

,
without

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
A
letter
from
Daniel
Deronda
,
"
said

,

her

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Brief
 
<EOS>
only
saying
that
he
hopes
soon
to
return
.
<EOS>
Unexpected

have
detained

.
<EOS>
The

,
"

,

;
"

.
<EOS>
For
who
has
two
friends
like

?
"
  
<EOS>
While
Hans
was
answering
Mirah
slipped
away

to
turn
,
when

,

"
Mirah
!
"
  
<EOS>
She

any

;
it
was
the
voice
she
expected
,
and
she
was

expected

.
<EOS>
Her

was
as

,
while
his
was

.
<EOS>
Once

,

,

which
comes
from

accepting

.
<EOS>
He
was
lightly
made
and

,
with
something
of

which

;
and

-
seven
.
<EOS>
His

was
shabby
,
as
when

seen

before
.
<EOS>
The

this

now

with

more

now

was

no

<EOS>

,
"

,

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

,

?
"
<EOS>

"

?

<EOS>

HEINE

_

<EOS>
Imagine

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
how

<EOS>

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
:

.
  
<EOS>
What

<EOS>
Every

.
<EOS>

,

<EOS>
Hence

.
<EOS>
The

It

<EOS>

,

.

<EOS>
He

.
  
<EOS>
It

the

soul
into
soul
,
and
makes
thought
fuller
as
the
clear
waters
are
made
fuller
,
where
the
fullness
is
inseparable
and
the
clearness
is
inseparable
.
<EOS>
For
I
have
judged
what
I
have
written
,
and
I

body
that
I

thought
to
pass

this
fleshly

will
pass
;
but
let
the

again
from
our
fuller

which

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
You

,
"

<EOS>
"

<EOS>

<EOS>
That

A

DANTE

_
<EOS>
Il

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
For

,

,

-

?
  
<EOS>
"

"

even

,

<EOS>

's

.
  
<EOS>
"
Are

,

?
"

(

)
,

.
  
<EOS>
"
Yes
,

;

"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,

;

<EOS>

.
<EOS>

?
"
<EOS>
(

's
in

.
)
  
<EOS>
"
I

,

.
<EOS>
"

.

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>

;

<EOS>
But

"

,

Grandcourt
's

,

.
<EOS>
Perhaps

,

.
<EOS>
He

,

which
,

<EOS>
This
conversation
passed
during
one
of
the
long
unaccountable
pauses
often
experienced
in
foreign
trains
at
some
country
station
.
<EOS>
There
was
a
dreamy
,
sunny
stillness
over
the
hedgeless

to
the
boundary
of
poplars
;
and

Gwendolen
the
talk
within
the
carriage
seemed
only
to
make
the
dreamland
larger
with
an
indistinct
region
of
coal
-

,
and

which
she
would
never
visit
;
<EOS>
till
at
her
mother
's
words
,
this
mingled
,
dozing

seemed
to
dissolve
and
give
way
to
a
more

of
Offendene
and
Pennicote
under
their
cooler
lights
.
<EOS>
She
saw
the
gray

of
the
downs
,
the
cattle
-

fields
,
the
shadowy
plantations
with

where

for

the

Offendene
,
the

where
she
was
gradually

from

,

her
mother

.
<EOS>
All
that

of

had
once

,

,

evil

and

.
  
<EOS>
In
this
way
Gwendolen
's

paused
over

and
made

the

of
many

;
but

.
<EOS>
What

in

day
-

?
<EOS>
Even

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
Altogether

Meanwhile

MILTON

our
own
purposes
.
<EOS>
We
diffuse
our
feeling
over
others
,
and
count
on
their
acting
from
our
motives
.
<EOS>
Her
imagination
had
not
been
turned
to
a
future
union
with
Deronda
by
any
other
than
the
spiritual

which
had
been
continually

;
but

had
not

.
<EOS>
Love
-
making
and
marriage
 
<EOS>
how
could
they
now
be
the

poor

's

could

?
<EOS>
Mighty
Love
had
laid

upon

;
but
what

?
<EOS>
Acceptance
of
rebuke
 
<EOS>
the
hard
task
of
self
-
change
 
confession
 
endurance
.
<EOS>
If

,
what

?
<EOS>
She
cried
as
the
child
cries
whose
little
feet
have
fallen
backward
 
cried
to
be
taken
by

hand
,
lest

.
  
<EOS>
The

pierced
Deronda
.
<EOS>
What
position
could
have
been
more
difficult
for
a
man
full
of

,
yet

?
<EOS>
He
was
the
only

who

's

:
to

from
any

of
hers
would
be
to

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

to
the

of
apparently

her
dependence
on

;
and
yet

he

coming

,
which
all
present

of

would

.
  
<EOS>
He
was

.
<EOS>
He

once
and
again
to
Park
Lane
before

;
but

were
in
the

Mrs.
Davilow
,

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
,

,

,

.
<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
All

,

.
<EOS>
He

,
of

chiefly

.
<EOS>
Her

.

<EOS>
"
One
day
still

'
mid

a

.
"
                      
<EOS>
BROWNING
:
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
The
King
and

Book
_
.
   
<EOS>
Meanwhile

and
Mirah
,
whom

did
not

in
her

about
Deronda
,
were
having
their
relation
to
him
drawn
closer
and
brought
into

.
  
<EOS>
The
father
Lapidoth
had
quitted
his
daughter
at
the
doorstep
,
ruled
by
that
possibility
of
staking
something
in
play
or

which
presented
itself
with
the
handling
of
any
sum
beyond
the
price
of
staying
actual

,
and
left
no

for
alternative

or

.
<EOS>
Until
he
had
lost
everything
he
never
considered
whether

would
apply
to
Mirah
again
or
whether
he
would

son
's

.
<EOS>
In

first

he
had
shrunk
from

Ezra
as

would
have
shrunk

any
other

of
disagreeable

;
and
the
possession
of
Mirah
's
purse
was
enough
to
banish
the
thought
of
future

.
<EOS>
The
gambling
appetite
is
more
absolutely
dominant
than
bodily
hunger
,
which
can
be
neutralized
by
an
emotional
or

;
but
the
passion
for
watching
chances
 
the
habitual
suspensive
poise
of
the
mind
in
actual
or

play
 
nullifies
the
susceptibility
of
other

.
<EOS>
In
its
final
,
imperious
stage
,
it
seems
the
unjoyous
dissipation
of
demons
,
seeking
diversion
on
the
burning
marl
of
perdition
.
  
<EOS>
But
every
form
of
selfishness
,
however
abstract
and

,
requires
the
support
of
at
least
one
meal

;
and
though
Lapidoth
's

for
food

was

,
he
had
slipped
into
a
shabby
,
unfriendly
form
of
life
in
which
the
appetite
could
not
be
satisfied
without
some
ready
money
.
<EOS>
When
,
in
a
brief

at
a

which
announced
"
Pyramids
"
on
the
window
-

,
he
had
first

and

and
finally
lost
Mirah
's
thirty
shillings
,
he
went
out
with
her
empty
purse
in
his
pocket
,
already
balancing
in

mind
whether
he
should
get
another
immediate

by
pawning

,
or
whether

should
go
back
to
her
giving

by
restoring

,
and

had
used
the

in
paying
a
score
that
was

.
<EOS>
Besides
,

was

,

his

,

.
<EOS>
After

,

;

,

.
<EOS>
Luck

;
he
expected

to
turn
 
and

some

of
supplies

through

daughter
's

?
<EOS>
Lapidoth
counted
on
the
fascination
of
his
cleverness
 
an
old

of
mind
which
early

had
sanctioned
:
and

only

who

,

.
  
<EOS>
The

.
<EOS>
But

<EOS>

;

<EOS>

.

Mirah

_
Herz
,

_
,
"

"

<EOS>
"
<EOS>

.

<EOS>

,

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The

that

,

;

.
  
<EOS>
Lapidoth

<EOS>

<EOS>

"

"

<EOS>
If
,

<EOS>
Lapidoth

what

being

for
him
in

son
's

,
but

was

and

that
would

.
<EOS>
This

,
speaking

,
had

which
selfish
levity

to

,
and
until

of

.
<EOS>
Whatever

he

must

,
as

man
finding

from

in

open

might

a
little
religious

that
happened
to

.
  
<EOS>
Lapidoth
was
not
born
with
this
sort

callousness
:
he
had
achieved
it
.
  
<EOS>
"
This
home
that

here
,
"
Ezra
began
,
"
is

by
the
generosity

a

friend
who

me
,
and
partly
by
the
labors
of
my
sister
,
who

.
<EOS>
While
we
have
a
home
we
will
not

from

.
<EOS>
We
will
not
cast
you
out
to
the
mercy

.
<EOS>
For
you
are
our
father
,
and
though
you
have
broken
your
bond
,
we
acknowledge
ours
.
<EOS>
But
I
will
never
trust
you
.
<EOS>
You
absconded
with

,

your

unpaid
;
you

;
you

her

and

;

have

,
and
where

were
there
sits

desire
;
you
were
ready
to
sell

sister
 
<EOS>
you
had
sold
her
,
but
the

was

you
.
<EOS>
The
man
who
has
done
these
things
must
never

.
<EOS>
We
will
share
our
food
with
you
 
<EOS>
you
shall
have
a
bed
,
and
clothing
.
<EOS>
We
will
do
this
duty
to
you
,
because
you
are
our
father
.
<EOS>
But
you
will
never
be
trusted
.
<EOS>
You
are
an
evil
man
:
you
made
the
misery
of
our
mother
.
<EOS>
That
such
a
man
is
our
father
is
a
brand
on
our
flesh
which
will
not
cease
smarting
.
<EOS>
But
the
Eternal
has
laid
it
upon
us
;
and
though
human
justice
were
to
flog
you
for
crimes
,
and
your
body
fell
helpless
before
the
public
scorn
,
we
would
still
say
,
"
This
is
our
father
;
make
way
,
that
we
may
carry
him
out
of
your
sight
.
"
<EOS>
"
  
Lapidoth
,
in
adjusting
himself
to
what
was
coming
,
had
not
been
able
to
foresee
the
exact
intensity
of
the
lightning
or
the
exact
course
it
would
take
 
that
it
would
not
fall
outside
his
frame
but
through
it
.
<EOS>
He
could
not
foresee
what
was
so
new
to
him
as
this
voice
from
the
soul
of
his
son
.
<EOS>
It
touched
that
spring
of
hysterical
excitability
which
Mirah
used
to
witness
in
him
when
he
sat
at
home
and
sobbed
.
<EOS>
As
Ezra
ended
,
Lapidoth
threw
himself
into
a
chair
and
cried
like
a
woman
,
burying
his
face
against
the
table
 
and
yet
,
strangely
,
while
this
hysterical
crying
was
an
inevitable
reaction
in
him
under
the
stress
of
his
son
's
words
,
it
was
also
a
conscious
resource
in
a
difficulty
;
just
as
in
early
life
,
when
he
was
a
bright
-
faced
curly
young
man
,
he
had
been
used
to
avail
himself
of
this
subtly
-
poised
physical
susceptibility
to
turn
the
edge
of
resentment
or
disapprobation
.
  
<EOS>
Ezra
sat
down
again
and
said
nothing
 
exhausted
by
the
shock
of
his
own
irrepressible
utterance
,
the
outburst
of
feelings
which
for
years
he
had
borne
in
solitude
and
silence
.
<EOS>
His
thin
hands
trembled
on
the
arms
of
the
chair
;
he
would
hardly
have
found
voice
to
answer
a
question
;
he
felt
as
if
he
had
taken
a
step
toward
beckoning
Death
.
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Mirah
's
quick
expectant
ear
detected
a
sound
which
her
heart
recognized
<EOS>
:
she
could
not
stay
out
of
the
room
any
longer
.
<EOS>
But
on
opening
the
door
her
immediate
alarm
was
for
Ezra
,
and
it
was
to
his
side
that
she
went
,
taking
his
trembling
hand
in
hers
,
which
he
pressed
and
found
support
in
;
but
he
did
not
speak
or
even

at

.
<EOS>
The
father
with
his
face
buried
was
conscious
that
Mirah
had
entered
,
and
presently
lifted
up
his
head
,
pressed
his
handkerchief
against

eyes
,
put

hand
toward
her
,
and
said
with

,
"
Good
-
bye
,
Mirah
;
your
father
will
not

you
again
.
<EOS>
He
deserves
to
die
like
a
dog
by
the
roadside
,
and
he
will
.
<EOS>
If
your
mother
had
lived
,
she
would
have
forgiven
me
 
<EOS>
thirty
-
four
years
ago
I
put
the
ring
on
her
finger
under
the
_
Chuppa
_
,
and
we
were
made
one
.
<EOS>
She
would
have
forgiven
me
,
and
we
should
have
spent
our
old
age
together
.
<EOS>
But
I
have
n't
deserved
it
.
<EOS>
Good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
He
rose
from
the
chair
as
he
said
the
last
"
good
-
bye
.
<EOS>
"
Mirah
had
put
her
hand
in
his
and
held

.
<EOS>
She
was
not
tearful
and

,
but
frightened
and

,
as

"
No
,
father
,
no
!
"
<EOS>
Then

to

brother
,
"
Ezra
,
you
have

?
 
<EOS>
Stay
,
father
,

.
<EOS>
Ezra
,

can
not

.
<EOS>
How

,
"
Go
and

!
"
<EOS>
"
  
"
I
have
not
said

,
"
Ezra
answered
,
with

.
<EOS>
"
I
have
said
,
stay

.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
Then
you
will
stay
,
father
 
and
be
taken

of
 
and
come
with
me
,
"
said
Mirah
,

the
door
.
  
<EOS>
This
was
really
what
Lapidoth
wanted
.
<EOS>
And

felt

,

.
<EOS>
She

"

,

.
<EOS>
You

,

.
<EOS>
Think

,

that

<EOS>
she

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Mirah
's

,
but
she
could
not

of

.
  
<EOS>
Lapidoth
quickly
recovered
his
composure
,
began
to
speak
to
Mirah
of
the
improvement
in
her
voice
,
and
other

,
and
when
Mrs.
Adam
came

,

,
though
his

were
just
now

.
  
<EOS>
But

,

by

,
and

_
Roulette
_
,
reproducing

,

.
<EOS>
He
had
had
his

to
England
,
but

was
a

.
  
<EOS>
These

of
the
night
with
Lapidoth
,
and
not
the
worn

of
his
ireful
son
uttering

.
<EOS>
Ezra
did
pass
across
the

-

,
and
his

were

;
but
he
passed
like

,
and
his

had
the

of

by
numbers

that
seemed
to

the

tissue
of
Lapidoth
's

.
      
<EOS>
The
godhead
in
us
wrings
our
noble
deeds
  
From
our
reluctant
selves
.
   
<EOS>
It
was
an
unpleasant
surprise
to
Deronda
when
he
returned
from
the
Abbey
to
find
the
undesirable
father
installed
in
the

at

.
<EOS>
Mirah
had
felt
it
necessary
to
speak

Deronda
to

father
,
and
even

as

of

had

,
and

.
<EOS>
She
passed
more
lightly
over
what
Deronda
had
done
for
her
,
omitting
altogether
the
rescue
from

,
and
speaking
of

she
had

in
Mrs.
Meyrick
's

so
as
to
leave
her
father
to
suppose
that
it
was
through
these
friends
Deronda
had

.
<EOS>
She
could
not

to
more

in
her

:
<EOS>
she
could
not

the
breath
of

father
's

.
<EOS>
And

,
for

,
was
not

in

about

.
<EOS>
But

was
much
interested
in
the
fact
of
his
children
having
a

apparently

.
  
<EOS>
It
was
the
brother
who
told
Deronda
of
this
new
condition
added
to

.
<EOS>
"
I
am
become
calm
in

now
,
"
Ezra
ended
,
"
and
I
try
to
think
it
possible
that
my

's

,
and
the
daily
tasting
a
life
of
peace
,
may

him
to
remain
aloof
from

.
<EOS>
I
have
enjoined
her
,
and
she
has

,
to

with
no

.
<EOS>
I
have
convinced

that
he
will
buy

.
<EOS>
"
  
Deronda
first
came
on
the
third

from
Ladipoth
's

.
<EOS>
The
new
clothes
for
which
he
had
been
measured
were
not
yet

,
and
wishing
to
make

favorable

,
he
did
not

in

old

.
<EOS>
He
watched
for
Deronda
's
departure
,
and
,
getting
a

of
him
from
the
window
,
was
rather

at
his
youthfulness
,
which
Mirah
had
not

,
and
which
he
had
somehow
thought
out
of
the
question
in
a
personage
who
had
taken
up
a
grave

and

with
the

Ezra
.
<EOS>
Lapidoth
began
to
imagine
that
Deronda
's
real
or
chief

must
be
that
he
was
in

with
Mirah
.
<EOS>
And
so
much
the
better
;
for
a

to
Mirah
had
more

for
her

:
and

was
not
without
the
hope
of

Deronda
,
and

any

.
<EOS>
He
was
behaving
with
much
amiability
,
and
trying
in
all

at

to
get
himself
into
easy

with
his
children
 
entering
into
Mirah
's
music
,
showing
himself
docile
about
smoking
,
which
Mrs.
Adam
could
not

in

,
and
walking

in
the

with

German

,
and

with

Mirah

.
<EOS>
He
was
too
acute
to

any
present

,
which
Mirah
told

that
she
must

in
as
a

promised
to
her
brother
.
<EOS>
He
was
comfortable
enough
to
wait
.
  
<EOS>
The
next

Deronda
came
,
Lapidoth
,
equipped
in
his
new
clothes
,
and
satisfied
with
his
own

,
was
in
the
room
with
Ezra
,
who
was
teaching

,
as

of
his

,
to

father
's

whenever

was

.
<EOS>
Deronda
was
cold
and
distant
,
the
first

of
this
man
,
who
had
blighted
the

of
his
wife
and

,

a

that
was

.
<EOS>
But
Lapidoth
did
not
let

,
asked

to
stay
and
hear
the
reading
of
papers
from
the
old
chest
,
and
actually
made

useful
in

to

German

.
<EOS>
This
led
him
to
suggest
that
it
might

desirable
to
make

of
the
manuscript
,
and
he

his
services
for
this

,
and
also
to
make

of
any

in
Roman
characters
.
<EOS>
Though
Ezra
's
young
eyes
he
observed
were
getting
weak
,
his
own
were
still
strong
.
<EOS>
Deronda
accepted
the
offer
,
thinking
that
Lapidoth
showed
a
sign
of
grace
in
the
willingness
to
be
employed
usefully
;
and
he
saw
a
gratified
expression
in
Ezra
's
face
,
who
,
however
,
presently
said
,
"
Let
all

writing
be
done
here
;
for
I
can
not
trust
the
papers
out
of

sight
,
lest
there
be
an

by
burning
or

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
Poor
Ezra
felt
very
much
as
if
he
had
a
convict
on
leave
under
his
charge
.
<EOS>
Unless
he
saw
his
father
working
,
it
was
not

to
believe
that
he
would
work
in

.
<EOS>
But
by
this
arrangement
he
fastened
on

the
burden
of
his
father
's
presence
,
which
was
made

not
only
through
his
deepest
,
longest

,
but

through
Lapidoth
's
restlessness
of
temperament
,
which
showed
itself
the
more
as
he
become
familiarized
with
his
situation
,
and
lost
any
awe
he
had
felt
of
his
son
.
<EOS>
The
fact
was
,
he
was
putting
a
strong
constraint
on
himself
in
confining
his
attention
for
the
sake
of
winning
Deronda
's
favor
;
and
like
a
man
in
an
uncomfortable
garment
he
gave
himself
relief
at
every

,
going
out
to
smoke
,
or
moving
about
and
talking
,
or
throwing
himself
back
in
his
chair
and
remaining
silent
,
but
incessantly
carrying
on
a
dumb
language
of
facial
movement
or
gesticulation
:
and
if
Mirah
were
in
the
room
,
he
would
fall
into
his
old
habit
of
talk
with
her
,
gossiping
about
their
former
doings
and
companions
,
or
repeating
quirks
and
stories
,
and
plots
of
the
plays
he
used
to
adapt
,
in
the
belief
that
he
could
at
will
command
the
vivacity
of
his
earlier
time
.
<EOS>
All
this
was
a
mortal
infliction
to
Ezra
;
and
when
Mirah
was
at
home
she
tried
to
relieve
him
,
by
getting
her
father
down
into
the
parlor
and
keeping
watch
over
him
there
.
<EOS>
What
duty
is
made
of
a
single
difficult
resolve
?
<EOS>
The
difficulty
lies
in
the
daily
unflinching
support
of
consequences
that
mar
the
blessed
return
of
morning
with
the
prospect
of
irritation
to
be
suppressed
or
shame
to
be
endured
.
<EOS>
And
such
consequences
were
being
borne
by
these
,
as
by
many
other
heroic
children
of
an
unworthy
father
 
with
the
prospect
,
at
least
to
Mirah
,
of
their
stretching
onward
through
the
solid
part
of
life
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
Lapidoth
's
presence
had
raised
a
new
impalpable
partition
between
Deronda
and
Mirah
 
each
of
them
dreading
the
soiling
inferences
of
his
mind
,
each
of
them
interpreting
mistakenly
the
increased
reserve
and
diffidence
of
the
other
.
<EOS>
But
it
was
not
very
long
before
some
light
came
to
Deronda
.
  
<EOS>
As
soon
as
he
could
,
after
returning
from
his
brief
visit
to
the
Abbey
,
he
had
called
at
Hans
Meyrick
's
rooms
,
feeling
it
,
on
more
grounds
than
one
,
a
due
of
friendship
that
Hans
should
be
at
once
acquainted
with
the
reasons
of
his
late
journey
,
and
the
changes
of
intention
it
had
brought
about
.
<EOS>
Hans
was
not
there
;
he
was
said
to
be
in
the
country
for
a
few
days
;
and
Deronda
,
after
leaving
a
note
,
waited
a
week
,
rather
expecting
a
note
in
return
.
<EOS>
But
receiving
no
word
,
and
fearing
some
freak
of
feeling
in
the
incalculably
susceptible
Hans
,
whose
proposed
sojourn
at
the
Abbey
he
knew
had
been
deferred
,
he
at
length

a
second

,
and
was
admitted
into
the
painting
-
room
,
where
he
found
his
friend
in
a

,
without

,
his
long
hair
still

from
a

,
but
with
a

looking
worn
and
wizened
 
anything
but
country
-
like
.
<EOS>
He
had
taken

and

,
and
stood
before
his

when
Deronda
entered
,
but
the
equipment
and

seemed

have
been
got
up

.
  
<EOS>
As

,

,
"
You
do

in

,

<EOS>
Is

Cambridge
<EOS>
you

?
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"
No
,
"

;
<EOS>
then

I

,

"

,

Nothing

.
<EOS>

<EOS>

,

.
"
                                  
<EOS>
COLERIDGE
.
   
<EOS>
Deronda
's
eagerness
to
confess
his
love
could
hardly
have
had
a
stronger
stimulus
than
Hans
had
given
it
in
his
assurance
that
Mirah
needed
relief
from
jealousy
.
<EOS>
He
went
on
his
next
visit
to
Ezra
with
the
determination
to
be
resolute
in
using
 
nay
,
in
requesting
 
an
opportunity
of
private
conversation
with
her
.
<EOS>
If
she
accepted
his
love
,
he
felt
courageous
about
all
other
consequences
,
and
as
her
betrothed
husband
he
would
gain
a
protective
authority
which
might
be
a
desirable
defense
for
her
in
future
difficulties
with
her
father
.
<EOS>
Deronda
had
not
observed
any
signs
of
growing
restlessness
in
Lapidoth
,
or
of
diminished
desire
to
recommend
himself
;
but
he
had
forebodings
of
some
future
struggle
,
some
mortification
,
or
some
intolerable
increase
of
domestic
disquietude
in
which
he
might
save
Ezra
and
Mirah
from
being
helpless

.
  
<EOS>
His
forebodings
would
have
been
strengthened
if
he
had
known
what
was
going
on
in
the
father
's
mind
.
<EOS>
That
amount
of
restlessness
,
that
desultoriness
of
attention
,
which
made
a
small
torture
to
Ezra
,
was
to
Lapidoth
an
irksome
submission
to
restraint
,
only
made
bearable
by
his
thinking
of
it
as
a
means
of
by
-
and
-
by
securing
a
well
-
conditioned

.
<EOS>
He
began
with
the
intention
of
awaiting
some
really
good
chance
,
such
as
an
opening
for
getting
a
considerable
sum
from
Deronda
;
but
all

while
he
was
looking
about
curiously
,
and
trying
to
discover
where
Mirah
deposited
her
money
and
her
keys
.
<EOS>
The
imperious
gambling
desire
within
him
,
which
carried
on
its
activity
through
every
other
occupation
,
and
made
a
continuous
web
of
imagination
that
held
all
else
in
its
meshes
,
would
hardly
have
been
under
the
control
of
a
contracted
purpose
,
if
he
had
been
able
to
lay
his

on
any
sum

.
<EOS>
But
Mirah
,
with
her
practical
clear
-

,
guarded
against
any

of
the
promise
she
had
given
to
Ezra
,
by
confiding
all
money
,
except
what

was
immediately
in
want

,
to
Mrs.
Meyrick
's
care
,
and
Lapidoth
felt
himself
under
an
irritating
completeness
of
supply
in
kind
as
in
a
lunatic
asylum
where
everything
was
made
safe
against
him
.
<EOS>
To
have
opened
a
desk
or
drawer
of
Mirah
's
,
and
pocketed
any
bank
-
notes
found
there
,
would
have
been
to
his
mind
a
sort
of
domestic
appropriation
which
had
no
disgrace
in
it
;
the
degrees
of
liberty
a
man
allows
himself
with
other
people
's
property
being
often
delicately
drawn
,
even
beyond
the
boundary
where
the
law
begins
to
lay
its
hold
 
which
is
the
reason
why
spoons
are
a
safer
investment
than
mining
shares
.
<EOS>
Lapidoth
really
felt
himself
injuriously
treated
by
his
daughter
,
and
thought
that
he
ought
to
have
had
what
he
wanted
of
her
other
earnings
as
he
had
of
her
apple
-

.
<EOS>
But
he
remained
submissive
;
indeed
,
the
indiscretion
that
most
tempted
him
,
was
not
any
insistance
with
Mirah
,
but
some
kind
of
appeal
to
Deronda
.
<EOS>
Clever
persons
who
have
nothing
else

sell
can
often
put
a
good
price
on
their
absence
,
and
Lapidoth
's
difficult
search
for
devices
forced
upon

the

that
his
family
would
find
themselves
happier
without
him
,
and
that

would

.
<EOS>
But
,

,

of
Ezra
's

,
and

.
  
<EOS>
On
this

,
when
Deronda
had
come
full
of

,
which

in

,

was

that

with

of

,
and

's

.
<EOS>
This

was
at

so

in
what

,
and

.
<EOS>
After

a

,

,
and

all

.
<EOS>
Mirah

not

,

she

,

<EOS>
:

.
<EOS>
There

.
  
<EOS>
"
This

,

,
"
he

.
<EOS>
"
<EOS>
The
week
's
heat
<EOS>
we
sometimes

here
<EOS>
is

Genoa
,

.
<EOS>

.
<EOS>
I

,

.
"
<EOS>
He

,

"
I

.
<EOS>
But

,
who
might

,

,

.
<EOS>
Nevertheless

"
<EOS>
"
  
"

,
"

,

,

.
<EOS>
"

<EOS>
Besides

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
"

have

ring

,
"
he

,

.
"
<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
I

had
summer
rings
 
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
if
_
they
had

.
<EOS>
Now

,
I
shall
get

.
"
  
<EOS>
They
were

again
.
<EOS>
Deronda
was
reading
a
piece

rabbinical
Hebrew
under

's

and

,
and

took

when
Lapidoth
re
-
entered
and
took

somewhat
in

.
  
<EOS>
His
rambling
eyes
quickly
alighted
on
the
ring
that
sparkled
on
the
bit
of
dark

.
<EOS>
During
his
walk
,
his
mind
had
been
occupied
with
the
fiction
of
an
advantageous
opening
for
him
abroad
,
only
requiring
a
sum
of
ready
money
,
which
,

to

in

,

a
question
as

:
and
it

that
Lapidoth
found
the
most

,
there
being
a
danger
in
asking
too
much
,
and
a
prospective

in
asking
too

.
<EOS>
His
own
desire
gave
him
no
limit
,
and
he
was
quite
without
guidance
as
to
the
limit
of
Deronda
's

.
<EOS>
But
now
,
in
the
midst

these
airy
conditions
preparatory
to
a
receipt
which
remained

,
this
ring
,
which
on

's
finger
had

's
envy
,

shone
detached
and
within

.
<EOS>
Its
value
was
certainly
below
the
smallest
of
the
imaginary
sums
that
his
purpose
fluctuated
between
;
but
then
it
was
before

as
a

,
and
his
desire
at
once
leaped
into
the
thought
(
not
yet
an
intention
)
that
if

were
quietly
to
pocket

away
he
would

the
means
of
comfortable

from
present

,
without

,
and
also
without

;
for
any
property
of
Deronda
's
(
available
without
his
formal

)
was
all
one
with
his
children
's
property
,
since
their
father
would
never
be

for

.
<EOS>
The
details
of
this
thinking
followed
each
other
so
quickly
that
they
seemed
to
rise
before
him
as
one
picture
.
<EOS>
Lapidoth
had
never
committed
larceny
;
but
larceny
is
a
form
of
appropriation
for
which
people
are
punished
by
law
;
and
,
take
this
ring
from
a
virtual
relation
,
who
would
have

to

,
would

.
<EOS>
Still
,
the
heavier
gift
was
to

,
if
Lapidoth
could
only
make
haste
enough
in
asking
for
it
,
and

imaginary
action
of
taking
the
ring
,
which
kept

,

.
<EOS>
He
satisfied
his
urgent

by

to
go
below
,
and
watch

moment
of
Deronda
's

,
when

would
ask

to
join

in

and

.
<EOS>
He
rose
and

,
but

he
saw
what
lay
beyond
him
 
the
brief

he
would
have
to
make
to
the
door
close

where
the
ring
was
.
<EOS>
However
he
was
resolved
to

down
;
but
 
by

,
rather

of

,

<EOS>
it

that

his

,
and

.
<EOS>
It

.
<EOS>
The

on

,

his

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda

;

.
<EOS>
But
,

-

.
<EOS>
She

;

.
<EOS>

<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
"

"

.
<EOS>
"

;

.
<EOS>
I

<EOS>
"

,

,

,
"

.

.
<EOS>

"

"

,
"

,

<EOS>

<EOS>
But

.
<EOS>
She

<EOS>

here
?
"
<EOS>
He

,
meeting

with

.
<EOS>
She

back

Deronda
was
still
casting

in
that

which
are

on
over
a

we

examined

.
<EOS>
"
You

?
<EOS>
"

,

.
  
<EOS>
He
,

,

,
"
I

,
"

.
  
<EOS>
She

"

?
 
<EOS>
you

,
"

;

.
<EOS>
Deronda

<EOS>
she
was

father
 
<EOS>
she

<EOS>
she

where

<EOS>
she
turned
with

hands
<EOS>
clasped

her

pale
,

.
<EOS>
Then

,
who
had
not

her
in

.
<EOS>
She

,

<EOS>
the

a

of
the

.
<EOS>
But

,

,

,

"

,
let
me
think
that
he
is
my
father
as
well
as
yours
 
<EOS>
that
we
can
have
no
sorrow
,
no
disgrace
,
no
joy
apart
.
<EOS>
I
will
rather
take
your
grief
to
be
mine
than
I
would
take
the
brightest
joy
of
another
woman
.
<EOS>
Say
you
will
not
reject
me
 
say
you
will
take
me
to
share
all
things
with
you
.
<EOS>
Say
you
will
promise
to
be
my
wife
 
say
it
now
.
<EOS>
I
have
been
in
doubt
<EOS>
so
long
 
I
have
had
to
hide
my
love
so
long
.
<EOS>
Say
that
now
<EOS>
and
always
I
may
prove
to
you
that
I
love
you
with
complete
love
.
"
  
<EOS>
The
change
in
Mirah
had
been
gradual
.
<EOS>
She
had
not
passed
at
once
from
anguish
to
the
full
,
blessed
consciousness
that
,
in
this
moment
of
grief
and
shame
,
Deronda
was
giving
her
the
highest
tribute
man
can
give
to
woman
.
<EOS>
With
the
first
tones
and
the
first
words
,
she
had
only
a
sense
of
solemn
comfort
,
referring
this
goodness
of
Deronda
's
to
his
feeling
for
Ezra
.
<EOS>
But
by
degrees
the
rapturous
assurance
of
unhoped
-
for
good
took
possession
of
her
frame
:
her
face
glowed
under
Deronda
's
as
he
bent
over
her
;
yet
she
looked
up
still
with
intense
gravity
,
as
when
she
had
first
acknowledged
with
religious
gratitude
that
he
had
thought
her
"
worthy
of
the
best
;
"
and
when
he
had
finished
,
she
could
say
nothing
 
<EOS>
she
could
only
lift
up
her
lips
to
his
and
just
kiss
them
,
as
if
that
were
the
simplest
"
yes
.
<EOS>
"
They
stood
then
,
only
looking
at
each
other
,
he
holding
her
hands
between
his
 
too
happy
to
move
,
meeting
so
fully
in
their
new
consciousness
that
all
signs
would
have
seemed

throw
them
farther
apart
,
till
Mirah
said
in
a

:
"
Let
us
go
and
comfort
Ezra
.
"
      
<EOS>
"
The
human
nature
unto
which
I
felt
  
That
I
belonged
,
and
reverenced
with
love
,
  
<EOS>
Was
not
a
punctual

,
but
a
spirit
  
Diffused
through
time
and
space
,
with
aid
derived
  
Of
evidence
from

,
erect
,
  
Prostrate
,
or
leaning

their
common
rest
  
<EOS>
In
earth
,
the
widely
scattered
wreck
sublime
  
Of
vanished
nations
.
<EOS>
"
                         
<EOS>
WORDSWORTH
:
<EOS>
_
<EOS>
The
Prelude
<EOS>
_
.
   
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
carried
out
his
plan
of
spending
part
of
the
autumn
at
Diplow
,
and
by
the
beginning
of
October
his
presence
was
spreading
some
cheerfulness
in
the
neighborhood
,
among
all
ranks
and
persons
concerned
,
from
the
stately
home
of
Brackenshaw
and
Quetcham
to
the
respectable
shop
-
parlors
in
Wanchester
.
<EOS>
For
Sir
Hugo
was
a
man
who
liked
to
show
himself
and
be
affable
,
a
Liberal
of
good
lineage
,
who
confided
entirely
in
reform
as
not
likely
to
make
any
serious
difference
in
English
habits
of
feeling
,
<EOS>
one
of
which
undoubtedly
is
the
liking
to
behold
society
well
fenced
and
adorned
with
hereditary
rank
.
<EOS>
Hence
he
made
Diplow
a
most
agreeable
house
,
extending
his
invitations
to
old
Wanchester
solicitors
and
young
village
curates
,
but
also
taking
some
care
in
the
combination
of
the
guests
,
and
not
feeding
all
the
common
poultry
together
,
so
that
they
should
think
their
meal
no
particular
compliment
.
<EOS>
Easy
-
going
Lord
Brackenshaw
,
for
example
,
would
not
mind
meeting
Robinson
the
attorney
,
but
Robinson
would
have
been
naturally
piqued
if
he
had
been
asked
to
meet
a
set
of
people
who
passed
for
his
equals
.
<EOS>
On
all
these
points
Sir
Hugo
was
well
informed
enough
at
once
to
gain
popularity
for
himself
and
give
pleasure
to
others
 
two
results
which
eminently
suited
his
disposition
.
<EOS>
The
rector
of
Pennicote
now
found
a
reception
at
Diplow
very
different
from
the
haughty
tolerance
he
had
undergone
during
the
reign
of
Grandcourt
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
the
baronet
liked
Mr.
Gascoigne
;
it
was
that
he
desired
to
keep
up
a
marked
relation
of
friendliness
with
him
on
account
of
Mrs.
Grandcourt
,
for
whom
Sir
Hugo
's
chivalry
had
become
more
and
more
engaged
.
<EOS>
Why
?
<EOS>
The
chief
reason
was
one
that
he
could
not
fully
communicate
,
even
to
<EOS>
Lady
Mallinger
 
<EOS>
for
he
would
not
tell
what
he
thought
one
woman
's
secret
to
another
,
even
though
the
other
was
his
wife
 
which
shows
that
his
chivalry
included
a
rare
reticence
.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
,
after
he
had
become
engaged
to
Mirah
,
felt
it
right
to
make
a
full
statement
of
his
position
and
purposes
to
Sir
Hugo
,
and
he
chose
to
make
it
by
letter
.
<EOS>
He
had
more
than
a
presentiment
that
his
fatherly
friend
would
feel
some
dissatisfaction
,
if
not
pain
,
at
this
turn
of
his
destiny
.
<EOS>
In
reading
unwelcome
news
,
instead
of
hearing
it
,
there
is
the
advantage
that
one
avoids
a
hasty
expression
of
impatience
which
may
afterward
be
repented
of
.
<EOS>
Deronda
dreaded
that
verbal
collision
which
makes
otherwise
pardonable
feeling
lastingly
offensive
.
  
<EOS>
And
Sir
Hugo
,
though
not
altogether
surprised
,
was
thoroughly
vexed
.
<EOS>
His
immediate
resource
was
to
take
the
letter
to
Lady
Mallinger
,
who
would
be
sure
to
express
an
astonishment
which
her
husband
could
argue
against
as
unreasonable
,
and
in
this
way
divide
the
stress
of
his
discontent
.
<EOS>
And
in
fact
when
she
showed
herself
astonished
and
distressed
that
all
Daniel
's
wonderful
talents
,
and
the
comfort
of
having
him
in
the
house
,
should
have
ended
in
his
going
mad
in
this
way
about
the
Jews
,
the
baronet
could
say
    
"
<EOS>
Oh
,
nonsense
,
my
dear
!
<EOS>
depend
upon
it
,
Dan
will
not
make
a
fool
of
himself
.
<EOS>
He
has
large
notions
about
Judaism
 
political
views
which
you
ca
n't
understand
.
<EOS>
No
fear
but
Dan
will
keep
himself
head
uppermost
.
"
  
<EOS>
But
with
regard
to
the
prospective
marriage
she
afforded
him
no
counter
-
irritant
.
<EOS>
The
gentle
lady
observed
,
without
rancor
,
that
she
had
little
dreamed
of
what
was
coming
when
she
had
Mirah
to
sing
at
her
musical
party
and
give
lessons
to
Amabel
.
<EOS>
After
some
hesitation
,
indeed
,
she
confessed
it
_
had
_
passed
through
her
mind
that
after
a
proper
time
Daniel
might
marry
Mrs.
Grandcourt
 
because
it
seemed
so
remarkable
that
he
should
be
at
Genoa
just
at
that
time
 
<EOS>
and
although
she
herself
was
not
fond
of
widows
she
could
not
help
thinking
that
such
a
marriage
would
have
been
better
than
his
going
altogether
with
the
Jews
.
<EOS>
But
Sir
Hugo
was
so
strongly
of
the
same
opinion
that
he
could
not
correct
it
as
a
feminine
mistake
;
and
his
ill
-
humor
at
the
disproof
of
his
disagreeable
conclusions
on
behalf
of
Gwendolen
was
left
without
vent
.
<EOS>
He
desired
Lady
Mallinger
not
to
breathe
a
word
about
the
affair
till
further
notice
,
saying
to
himself
,
"
If
it
is
an
unkind
cut
to
the
poor
thing
(
meaning
Gwendolen
)
,
the
longer
she
is
without
knowing
it
the
better
,
in
her
present
nervous
state
.
<EOS>
And
she
will
best
learn
it
from
Dan
himself
.
"
<EOS>
Sir
Hugo
's
conjectures
had
worked
so
industriously
with
his
knowledge
,
that
he
fancied
himself
well
informed
concerning
the
whole
situation
.
  
<EOS>
Meanwhile
his
residence
with
his
family
at
Diplow
enabled
him
to
continue
his
fatherly
attentions
to
Gwendolen
;
and
in
these
Lady
Mallinger
,
notwithstanding
her
small
liking
for
widows
,
was
quite
willing
to
second
him
.
  
<EOS>
The
plan
of
removal
to
Offendene
had
been
carried
out
;
and
Gwendolen
,
in
settling
there
,
maintained
a
calm
beyond
her
mother
's
hopes
.
<EOS>
She
was
experiencing
some
of
that
peaceful
melancholy
which
comes
from
the
renunciation
of
demands
for
self
,
and
from
taking
the
ordinary
good
of
existence
,
and
especially
kindness
,
even
from
a
dog
,
as
a
gift
above
expectation
.
<EOS>
Does
one
who
has
been
all
but
lost
in
a
pit
of
darkness
complain
of
the
sweet
air
and
the
daylight
?
<EOS>
There
is
a
way
of
looking
at
our
life
daily
as
an
escape
,
and
taking
the
quiet
return
of
morn
and
evening
 
still
more
the
star
-
like
out
-
glowing
of
some
pure
fellow
-
feeling
,
some
generous
impulse
breaking
our
inward
darkness
 
as
a
salvation
that
reconciles
us
to
hardship
.
<EOS>
Those
who
have
a
self
-
knowledge
prompting
such
self
-
accusation
as
Hamlet
's
,
can
understand
this
habitual
feeling
of
rescue
.
<EOS>
And
it
was
felt
by
Gwendolen
as
she
lived
through
and
through
again
the
terrible
history
of
her
temptations
,
from
their
first
form
of
illusory
self
-
pleasing
when
she
struggled
away
from
the
hold
of
conscience
,
to
their
latest
form
of
an
urgent
hatred
dragging
her
toward
its
satisfaction
,
while
she
prayed
and
cried
for
the
help
of
that
conscience
which
she
had
once
forsaken
.
<EOS>
She
was
now
dwelling
on
every
word
of
Deronda
's
that
pointed
to
her
past
deliverance
from
the
worst
evil
in
herself
,
and
the
worst
infliction
of
it
on
others
,
and
on
every
word
that
carried
a
force
to
resist
self
-
despair
.
  
<EOS>
But
she
was
also
upborne
by
the
prospect
of
soon
seeing
him
again
:
she
did
not
imagine
him
otherwise
than
always
within
her
reach
,
her
supreme
need
of
him
blinding
her
to
the
separateness
of
his
life
,
the
whole
scene
of
which
she
filled
with
his
relation
to
her
 
no
unique
preoccupation
of
Gwendolen
's
,
for
we
are
all
apt
to
fall
into
this
passionate
egoism
of
imagination
,
not
only
toward
our
fellow
-
men
,
but
toward
God
.
<EOS>
And
the
future
which
she
turned
her
face
to
with
a
willing
step
was
one
where
she
would
be
continually
assimilating
herself
to
some
type
that
he
would
hold
before
her
.
<EOS>
Had
he
not
first
risen
on
her
vision
as
a
corrective
presence
which
she
had
recognized
in
the
beginning
with
resentment
,
and
at
last
with
entire
love
and
trust
?
<EOS>
She
could
not
spontaneously
think
of
an
end
to
that
reliance
,
which
had
become
to
her
imagination
like
the
firmness
of
the
earth
,
the
only
condition
of
her
walking
.
  
<EOS>
And
Deronda
was
not
long
before
he
came
to
Diplow
,
which
was
a
more
convenient
distance
from
town
than
the
Abbey
.
<EOS>
He
had
wished
to
carry
out
a
plan
for
taking
Ezra
and
Mirah
to
a
mild
spot
on
the
coast
,
while
he
prepared
another
home
which
Mirah
might
enter
as
his
bride
,
and
where
they
might
unitedly
watch
over
her
brother
.
<EOS>
But
Ezra
begged
not
to
be
removed
,
unless
it
were
to
go
with
them
to
the
East
.
<EOS>
All
outward
solicitations
were
becoming
more
and
more
of
a
burden
to
him
;
but
his
mind
dwelt
on
the
possibility
of
this
voyage
with
a
visionary
joy
.
<EOS>
Deronda
,
in
his
preparations
for
the
marriage
,
which
he
hoped
might
not
be
deferred
beyond
a
couple
of
months
,
wished
to
have
fuller
consultation
as
to
his
resources
and
affairs
generally
with
Sir
Hugo
,
and
here
was
a
reason
for
not
delaying
his
visit
to
Diplow
.
<EOS>
But
he
thought
quite
as
much
of
another
reason
 
his
promise
to
Gwendolen
.
<EOS>
The
sense
of
blessedness
in
his
own
lot
had
yet
an
aching
anxiety
at
his
heart
:
this
may
be
held
paradoxical
,
for
the
beloved
lover
is
always
called
happy
,
and
happiness
is
considered
as
a
well
-
fleshed
indifference
to
sorrow
outside
it
.
<EOS>
But
human
experience
is
usually
paradoxical
,
if
that
means
incongruous
with
the
phrases
of
current
talk
or
even
current
philosophy
.
<EOS>
It
was
no
treason
to
Mirah
,
but
a
part
of
that
full
nature
which
made
his
love
for
her
the
more
worthy
,
that
his
joy
in
her
could
hold
by
its
side
the
care
for
another
.
<EOS>
For
what
is
love
itself
,
for
the
one
we
love
best
?
 
<EOS>
an
enfolding
of
immeasurable
cares
which
yet
are
better
than
any
joys
outside
our
love
.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
came
twice
to
Diplow
,
and
saw
Gwendolen
twice
 
<EOS>
and
yet
he
went
back
to
town
without
having
told
her
anything
about
the
change
in
his
lot
and
prospects
.
<EOS>
He
blamed
himself
;
but
in
all
momentous
communication
likely
to
give
pain
<EOS>
we
feel
dependent
on
some
preparatory
turn
of
words
or
associations
,
some
agreement
of
the
other
's
mood
with
the
probable
effect
of
what
we
have
to
impart
.
<EOS>
In
the
first
interview
Gwendolen
was
so
absorbed
in
what
she
had
to
say
to
him
,
so
full
of
questions
which
he
must
answer
,
about
the
arrangement
of
her
life
,
what
she
could
do
to
make
herself
less
ignorant
,
how
she
could
be
kindest
to
everybody
,
and
make
amends
for
her
selfishness
and
try
to
be
rid
of
it
,
that
Deronda
utterly
shrank
from
waiving
her
immediate
wants
in
order
to
speak
of
himself
,
nay
,
from
inflicting
a
wound
on
her
in
these
moments
when
she
was
leaning
on
him
for
help
in
her
path
.
<EOS>
In
the
second
interview
,
when
he
went
with
new
resolve
to
command
the
conversation
into
some
preparatory
track
,
he
found
her
in
a
state
of
deep
depression
,
overmastered
by
some
distasteful
miserable
memories
which
forced
themselves
on
her
as
something
more
real
and
ample
than
any
new
material
out
of
which
she
could
mould
her
future
.
<EOS>
She
cried
hysterically
,
and
said
that
he
would
always
despise
her
.
<EOS>
He
could
only
seek
words
of
soothing
and
encouragement
:
and
when
she
gradually
revived
under
them
,

"

discovery
was
far
from
being
painful
to
me
,
"
he
said
,
"
I
had
been
gradually
prepared
for
it
,

I
was

.
<EOS>
I
had
been
prepared
for
it
by
becoming

with
a
very
remarkable
Jew
,
whose
ideas
have

much
that
I
think
of
devoting
the
best
part
of
my
life
to
some
effort
at
giving

effect
.
"
  
<EOS>
Again
Gwendolen
seemed
shaken
 
again
there
was
a
look
of

,
but
this
time

was
mingled
with

.
<EOS>
She
looked
at
Deronda
with
lips
childishly
parted
.
<EOS>
It
was
not
that
she
had
yet
connected
his
words
with
Mirah
and
her
brother
,
but

with

for

.
<EOS>
Great

,
and

-

.
<EOS>
He

;

least

.
  
<EOS>
"

,
"

"

-

for

.
<EOS>
I

will

East
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
Here

something
clearer
,
but

.
<EOS>
Gwendolen
's
lips
began
to

.
"
<EOS>
But
you
will
come
back
?
<EOS>
"
she
said
,
tasting
her
own

as
they

,
before

.
  
<EOS>
Deronda
could
not
sit
still
.
<EOS>
He
rose
,
and
went
to
prop

against
the
corner
of
the
mantel
-

,
at
a
different
angle

her

.
<EOS>
But

she
had
pressed
her

against
her

,

and
looked
up

,

.
  
<EOS>
"
If
I
live
,
"
said

<EOS>
"
_
<EOS>
some
time
_
<EOS>
.
<EOS>
"
  
<EOS>
They
were

.
<EOS>
He
could
not

to
say
more
unless
she
led
up
to
it
by
a
